output: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I apologize once again for my delay.
This year marks the European Year of Intercultural Dialogue.
The involvement of all and the perception that the education, knowledge and interconnection of different cultures with each other is crucial is already a fact as acquired.
That is why the different areas of action and intervention have carried out multiple initiatives associated with this year.
In this context, the Erasmus Mundus programme also plays its part and, in this new perspective, a new funding is already in place.

The Erasmus Mundus programme is an important contribution to the creation of centres of excellence in the EU, which will somehow support the flight of Serbs outside the European Union, as well as playing a significant role in the

In promoting European values, together with third-country nationals who come here to study and who find in the old continent an impasse cultural and linguistic diversity that function as an attractive pole and different from existing models in the rest of the world.
However, dialogue and interculturality have suffered enough to survive.

The problem of visas for Erasmus students in the world and the frequent difficulties in obtaining and renewing them often lead them to live in a semi-clandestine situation in the European Union, as they often visit teachers but with tourist visas and sometimes with a visa.
I consider it of the utmost relevance and urgency to seek a solution that allows for solidity, transparency and effectiveness in the issuance of pre-student visas.
Also, the knowledge of the language that allows cultural appreciation and mutual coexistence, beyond the strictly academic domain, is crucial, so we can guarantee this premise at all.
In conclusion, a word of thanks to Mrs De Sarnez for the way in which this whole process has been conducted and for the balanced report she has produced.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, authorisation for the collection of State aid for the modernisation and renewal of fishing fleets in the outermost regions should only be possible until the end of 2009 or should be valid for an indefinite period.
The peculiarities of fishing activity in these regions justify that these aid can be granted beyond 2009 without the marine environment being minimally damaged.
State aid for the modernisation and renewal of the fleets of the outermost regions for an indefinite period does not mean permanent and internal aid.
They would be immediately interrupted if the studies and evaluations of the Scientific Council and the Regional Advisory Councils highlighted this need.
This is the solution that would best suit the very specific reality of fisheries in the outermost regions.

The same reasons that underpin for the fishermen of each group an exclusive reserve of fish up to the seed also justify a differentiated treatment with regard to aid for the modernisation and renewal of the fleet.
Fortunately, the Committee on Fisheries has found the best solutions to meet the specificities of fisheries in the outermost regions.

Mr President, Commissioner Almunia, President of the Eurogroup, I would like to congratulate not only the rapporteurs but also the Commission on the initiative of producing this text, the ten-year review of economic and monetary union.
It's a strategic text and this analysis was fundamental.
The euro, as was said here today, is an undeniable success.

From Lisbon to Helsinki, from Dublin to Bratislava, the euro has shown resilience and solidity, even during the serious turbulence we are witnessing, and it is clearly important that the borders of this club are widened.
But the passing of time is a daily test of the strength of the European project in many other respects.
The euro, as I said, is a central instrument for the functioning of the financial system.

However, the text itself, the Commission text, clearly points to the fundamental conclusion that neither real economic growth nor convergence, in both social and spatial terms, accompanied this success.
On the contrary, the Commission clearly concludes that disparities have worsened violently during the decade of the single currency.
This divergence affects regions of my country in particular, in particular northern Portugal, but also other regions of Member States.
The impacts of the single monetary policy, namely the very high exchange rate practiced, have hit the regions most exposed to international competition and the most exporting regions hardest.
Today, the crisis resulting from the deregulation of financial markets is violently affecting the real economy and further aggravating the situation of many citizens and many regions.

These regions, those exposed to international competition, those that depend on small and medium-sized enterprises, those where access to credit is most important, are today victims of this process and even threaten depression.
Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President of the Eurogroup, the success of the euro depends on the confidence that European citizens have in it.
The most powerful European countries have already begun the process of relaunching the national economy.
We have the case, in particular, of the initiatives concerning the automotive industry.
But in Europe, it's more than that.
It has to be much more than the more or less coordinated sum of national policies.
It is time to turn the euro into a central tool of Europe, supporting a robust currency but also a robust real economy and to make the functioning of the euro accompany it.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has already made a number of proposals to the Council and the European Parliament on this subject.
The debate on the coordination of economic policies in the euro area has today a reinforced and unquestionable impact and relevance.
But coordinating national policies is not enough.
I need more.

Having a Lisbon strategy, which is a summary of national initiatives, and a Stability and Growth Pact, which differentially tightens the different countries that use it and which they have to submit to, are limitations to which the limited budget at our disposal adds.
Crises create opportunities.
Monetary union can only be sustained by a convergence of the welfare of the Member States which make it up, independently of their citizens, regardless of where they were born.
What other way would we have to mobilize citizens for the single currency?

The Commission has to be up to date with its own diagnosis and that is why we are eagerly awaiting the concrete proposals that the Commission will bring to this House and present to the citizens of Europe on 26 November.

It is essential that, from this crisis onwards, a new phase of the Union is launched in which the consolidation and strengthening of the financial system is accompanied by effective prosperity, made of cohesion and also of economic citizenship.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this oral question to the European Commission by Mr Gerardo Gagliotti on behalf of this Parliament's Committee on Regional Development is fully justified and pertinent.

In fact, it is necessary to make clear the reasons why the Council is blocking the reform of the Solidarity Fund, as it is unable to reach an agreement on a common position allowing the legislative process to proceed.
It is difficult to disagree on the reasons that may be underlying the Council's position, except perhaps petty financial reasons.
Does the Council not want a more agile and immediate response to the natural disasters that are occurring?
The Council does not want this type of rapid response to be given to other types of disasters, such as serious industrial accidents, terrorist attacks or serious public health situations.

It is important that these questions have a clear answer, as it is also important to clarify what the European Commission thinks about this situation and whether it intends to take any measures to unblock the legislative process.
The value of solidarity must also be fully realised in this area.
The citizens would not understand at all if we were not.
I want to say that I wanted to protest against the statement made by Mrs Lulling, who intends to condition the vote of the Members of this House, and that conditioning makes no sense.

The interpretation you are making is one that we do not share and it is only in this sense that I would like to ask my colleagues who know what they are dealing with, who know that we are defending other interests, which are the interests of public health and the interests of the citizens and the interests of the countries that actually vote in favour of the report.
Mr President, Commissioner, for the past two months the political and media agenda has been dominated by the financial and economic crisis.
The referendum in Ireland or the difficulties in the Czech Republic over the Treaty of Lisbon have almost no expression in the media.

Do you not think that now the Commission's information and communication strategy should be strengthened, with the need and urgency of the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, as well as a political response to face and overcome the crisis in which we live?
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the powers of the world are now in control of the international financial system.
They look for a handshake and it was not without time.
And so maybe it's time to solve another problem that we've been hearing about for decades.
For decades we have heard this music of the ignoble plundering of resources, as now again in the Congo, about the blood of the populations.

I believe that it is also time to pursue these companies, to pursue this shameful trade, to freeze the accounts where the profits of shame of this mining are circulated and deposited at the expense of the blood and suffering of the populations.
I don't understand why these companies aren't listed under the same title as we've already blacklisted terrorist organizations.

And I do not understand why the international community is not able to prosecute these entrepreneurs who are strictly not entrepreneurs, they are real bandits who question regional and global security.
I encourage the French Presidency and the Commission to take an international initiative in this regard.
We've heard it said here several times today that a crisis usually creates an opportunity, and it does.
And if we want to take advantage of the opportunity that is open to us, the agenda is easy to know.
Firstly, we know, at the level of the European Union, the need we have to introduce transparency, regulation and supervision mechanisms in financial markets.
And it is not necessary for Commissioner Macri to launch more consultations, nor is it necessary for the Presidency to analyse and call for more studies.
If there are more proposals, just look at the proposals that were made in time by the Socialists and that many of them ended up being taken up by this Parliament.
Secondly, internationally, Europe cannot be in an international space passively.

It has to be an active agent in the construction of the new international order, it has to be the defender of a new architecture that does not leave black holes in the system, as are at the moment the tax havens.
Thirdly, we have heard the President of the Commission say here today that there is a reluctance to coordinate strategies at the level of the different States.
It is true that if we had not heard from many members of the Commission for so long that the markets are self-regulating, that the State must stay out.
If financial markets did not have an impact on growth or employment, perhaps there would be a more active and active spirit of solidarity at the level of the different countries.
But today, the proposal we have in our hands is a proposal that is only a first step.
It does not define clearly enough what the objective is and the objective must be employment and, thirdly, because a European programme cannot be a summary of national agendas.
Today is the time for us to show the citizens of Europe that Europe is a network of rights, also economic, that protects them in times of crisis, in terms of
Solidarity, growth programme and support for small and mediumsized enterprises, which are currently not receiving the results of the interventions that have been made at bank level.
The real economy is that, and we are here as Europeans to show the citizens that Europe is here too, and especially because of them.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is with particular pleasure that I stand before you to present the work done, which was done together with everyone in this own-initiative report.
For me and for all those who worked to unravel this process, we can say that we did our job.

I would like to thank all of you, in particular the shadow rapporteurs of the various political groups who have worked very hard to reach commitments for the future, the staff of the Regional Development Office, always available, namely Miguel Tel Cremades and Elisa Da Farra.

I would like to thank the staff of the PSE, Lilla and Petros, the European Commission, who, always representing themselves in the many different general directions that such a comprehensive report requires, have constantly and closely accompanied the work and have worked hard to get it to a good port.

To my office, and in particular to Joanna Benzi, and to all of you, my sincere thanks on behalf of a more harmonious and structured development for the coastal regions and for tourism in the European Union.
The 27 Member States of the European Union have more than 89 km of coastal areas.
This presents a variety of very particular characteristics that, according to their location, are marked by cosmopolitanism, if we talk about cities like Lisbon, Copenhagen, Stockholm, or Stockholm.

The difficulties are peripheral or ultra-peripheral regions with problems of links to large cities or with accelerated desertification contexts, such as Algarve, Liguria, the Canary Islands or Madeira.
In one way or another, everyone identifies with the notion of coast and coastal zone and lives daily the advantages and disadvantages associated with it.
According to available data, by 2010, about 75% of humanity will live in coastal areas.
According to the circuits and relationships between them, we define as 50 kilometers in a straight line that go from the coastline to the interior areas.
Yes, regions, not maritime bands, detached from an integrated vision that these subjects so lack and that our ancestors would also subscribe to.
Here, all this population will be concentrated in search of economic opportunities and synergies, and in many cases, with the expectation that they will revolve around tourism.
Thus, the obvious need for a pragmatic and integrated view of the impact of tourism on coastal areas took our minds and led us to put our hands to work.

In the current context of the financial crisis, where the impact on the real economy is becoming increasingly insurmountable, tourism appears as a sector with enormous potential to be directly or indirectly affected in a brutal way.

The regions, which are overwhelmingly or totally dependent on tourism for their development, see their activity as threatened and look to the future with suspicion, especially as tourism is not currently a competence of the European Union.
However, articulated measures can and must be taken, and the spirit in which the Treaty of Lisbon was embodied reflects this same trend.
However, waiting until the Treaty comes into force to start acting is waiting for the stage when we will cry over the spilled milk.
The current political and tourist activity and the fragile reality of the regions that depend on it require urgent and effective action.

The fact that these are structurally dependent areas on tourism as a promoter of employment, although often seasonal, this intensive labour activity cannot be avoided in a context of pressure on urban areas and unemployment.

That is why this report, which we are bringing to you now, which was already the most urgent and opportune when the Committee on Regional Development of this House decided to promote it, now assumes that it should already be seen as a priority for the European Commission and the European Council.

Priority must be given to the many initiatives it incorporates, as well as to those which it expressly supports and which have already been implemented by other institutions, in line with the measures taken in the emergency plan.

I would like to draw attention to the Commission's review of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in which the issues associated with this sector and the shock to which it is currently subject must obviously be covered.

It is crucial to ensure the development of new segments of the economy of these coastal areas, ensuring their social and environmental sustainability and promoting the real integration of the different sectoral policies, such as the maritime sector, transport and energy.

The new quality product policy, which the CAP review incorporates with the announcement of the EFSC report, and the new tourist products in these coastal areas take into account their crucial contribution to the European economy.
The implementation of an adequate and holistic vision for this policy must be a reality in the European Union.

And to conclude, Mr President, only with a clear articulation of these instruments and swift and effective action involving all the partners already on the ground can we ensure that we have a sustainable and future-oriented coastal tourism sector in the European Union.
Madam President, Commissioner, Madam Minister, e Justice is an important step in access to the law, justice and the courts.
I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and the French Presidency on this initiative.

The EGSTAT was one of the projects under discussion and it is Portugal's responsibility, during its presidency, to lead the development and implementation of the pilot project, which will allow all citizens to access the services of other Member States in a simpler, cheaper, more comfortable and in their own language.
This multilingual portal should be designed to serve citizens and businesses seeking legal support and basic legal advice on legal and cross-border issues.
The eJustice must be coordinated and administered by a responsible unit, which will also coordinate the contributions of the various Member States and their articulation with that responsible unit.
"West Justice will serve the citizen and strengthen our democracy."
I congratulate myself on the launch of the portal in December 2009.
Mr President, Mr Barrot, ladies and gentlemen, I congratulate the work of Carlos Coelho, Martin Roure and the other shadows.
In December 2004, the Council adopted a regulation laying down rules for the security devices and biometric data of passports and travel documents issued by Member States.
Now we needed to take new steps to combat child abduction and trafficking.
The use of passports by children, according to the principle of one person, one passport, can be a fundamental means of overcoming this difficult and important fight.
In my country, Portugal, the collection of digital prints on children from the age of six is already a long-standing practice, which perhaps is why I have no objection.
As an advocate of the European cause, I believe that harmonisation is important in this area.
I am reassured to know that Member States such as Portugal, which have long defined the minimum age of six years for collecting digital prints, will not have to change national legislation.
It should be emphasized that the security of passports, which is being strengthened today, is not exhausted by the existence of passports.

The passport itself corresponds to an increased level of security, ranging from the presentation of the documents necessary for the issuance of passports, followed by the collection of biometric data, to verification and matching at cross-border checkpoints.
This report is another step to affirm the rights of the person and guarantee his safety.
Mr President, first of all I would like to welcome the rapporteur, Mr Alexander Lambsdorff, and the shadow rapporteurs, with particular reference to Barbara Weiler.
Ladies and gentlemen, I think it is essential that we make progress towards the integration of national defence markets and even the strategic coordination of their productions.

We must make progress, indeed, with the specificities and precautions necessary to apply the essential rules of the internal market to defence industries, increasing transparency in the competitions organised and in the contracts signed involving the Member States of the European Union.
But at the same time we must help to develop the conditions for greater competitiveness of European equipment and products on world markets.
It seems to me important that this directive can ensure progress in the legal framework for public contracts in the fields of defence and security, advancing the construction of the internal market.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so what is the Commission's position?

I would also like to emphasize the provisions allowing small and mediumsized enterprises easier access to this market, in particular through the improvement of the subcontracting rules and the prospect of making greater progress with greater impact and depth in the decision-making process.

The European Union is committed to the creation of a genuine European market in the defence industry, which can also contribute to strengthening research and development, not only in the defence industry but also in a whole range of European industries that benefit from the development of the defence industry.
In conclusion, I think it is possible to refer to the obvious link between defence industries and the Union's external policies.
But I would like to quote, in respect of this, a recent speech translating a classic Romanian saying if you want peace, prepare for war.

The European Union, as almost a peaceful superpower, we call these industries defence industries and not war industries because we want peace and not war and that is why we also need defence industries.
Mr. Vice President Barrot, I agree with you, I agree with you with dissatisfaction.
In fact, we have to be dissatisfied with the set of measures, which are vast.
The truth is that irregular immigration continues to Europe, human trafficking continues, there are areas where there are many
France has made progress with a set of important bilateral cooperation, but other Member States have not.
It is necessary that the Commission continue without losing its enthusiasm for this policy of cooperation and aid to the United States.
Mr President, Commissioner, I shall try to put the questions in a very synthetic way.
Firstly, the question of the European Union's special monitoring mechanism for texting, which ended, as has been said here, on 31 December 2008.
It is necessary, Madam Commissioner, to publish timely and routine statistical data on imports, exports and prices, as is the case in the United States.
Without this data, the European Union is unable to react to possible unlawful practices and the Commission itself is unable to define its strategy.
I would ask him to pay attention to this, to the assumptions that other colleagues have already made.
Secondly, producing within the European Union increasingly requires compliance with safety, social and environmental standards.
RITES, for example, is a recent initiative that creates even more conditioners for us.
It is important that the Commission has a clear strategy and that it is perceptible and monitorable so that imported products have identical requirements.
So in the ongoing free trade agreements, these aspects are being duly taken into account.
And as for Meidine, can Meidine actually help solve this issue?
Thirdly, the European Union has launched an economic recovery plan to combat the current crisis.
What role will trade policy play in this context?

At the moment, what is the Commission preparing to do when a number of other countries, such as China, are beginning to increase the introduction of non-tariff barriers increasingly so that our European imports do not enter the Chinese markets?

What is the proposal for the updating or adjustment of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as well as the support available in the Structural Funds to improve the immediate situation of the European textile industry?
Last but not least, will the crisis we are going through finally make the Commission sensitive to the devastating impact of an overvalued euro on the European economy?
How can the Commissioner raise awareness, I conclude, among her colleagues and the institutions dealing with European monetary policy in the sense of rebalancing?
It is clear to us that we must applaud Obama's decision to close Guantánamo, to ban torture, to ban illegal interrogations and to suspend military trials.
However, ladies and gentlemen, which is no longer present, Portugal and the Portuguese Socialist Government have no sense of guilt.
The Portuguese socialist government did not collaborate with the Bush administration, quite the opposite.

It was precisely now, with the Portuguese administration, with the Portuguese Government, with the initiative of Minister Luiz Amado, that the possibility and the duty of the European Union and the democratic countries to welcome and receive the innocents detained in Guantánamo was unleashed.

This is really important, and this should be highlighted as an example to be followed by the other Member States of the European Union, how important it is that tomorrow the resolution is adopted by the whole of the parties that make up this House so that, as a unit, the decision can have more force.
Mr President, thank you very much to my colleague, Mrs Napolitano, for your excellent report.

Fourteen years after Barcelona and five years after the first Euro-Mediterranean Parliamentary Assembly, we have the Union for the Mediterranean, with economic power, with parliamentary power, with civil society, with heads of government to decide together.
Everyone is willing to do more and better in a territory where 720 million citizens represent a potential for development and peace for the world.
To hide them only on the economic and business side is a clear mistake.

Responding to growth crises naturally requires a political response, but responding to humanitarian crises, emergencies and military crises, such as those experienced at the end of 2008 and the beginning of 2009, is crucial.
Politicians and citizens have to answer the world's problems.
The world asked for answers and months later we are still, citizens and politicians, designated on a platform like the Union for the Mediterranean, taking a long time to react.
I hope that at least this moment has served to learn and move forward, because only those who make mistakes learn, but to move forward in the agility of the reaction is absolutely crucial.
The interest in the approval of this proposal for a directive lies essentially in how it can contribute to boosting economic activity at local level and supporting social action.

This application of a reduced rate is of great importance in the housing sector, both in construction and in renovation, allowing the Member States that adopt it to reduce the respective cost to the end user.

The provision of local services, in particular by small businesses, can also benefit from this reduction in the living wage, securing and generating more and better employment through the promotion of the consumption of goods and services, thus stimulating the economy itself.

Restoration activity, which is fundamental to the proper functioning of local economies and the growth of tourism itself, can thus gain a great deal from the local plan with this reduction in VAT taxation.
These services, ladies and gentlemen, should not be circulated in the European internal market, which will help to reduce the reserves of some Member States already verified in the Council plan.
That is why I cannot agree with the extension of this reduced equipment fee, whatever the pretext.

The prudent way in which this proposal should be dealt with in the European Parliament should not give a pretext to governments which have some reservations about the European Commission's proposal to use in practice the right of veto which European legislation still does not have on tax matters.
Thus, it is prudent to reject large-scale changes that only make it difficult to accept the text.
As has been said, not only is the good the enemy of the good, but he who wants everything loses everything.
This proposal for a directive is important not only for strengthening local economies but also for meeting the ambitions repeatedly expressed by various Member States.
We therefore support the Commission's proposal as it was presented, and that was the meaning of the vote, as I agree, of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection.

I welcome the work of the rapporteurs and call for the approval of this proposal in the exact terms in which it was put forward by the Commission and voted on in the Parliamentary Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection.
I have the floor to disagree with my colleague Edith Estrela, and that is what motivated me to speak.
No one wants to send women home, but there are women who want to stay home.
There are even associations that try to defend them, women who are ignored, despised, discriminated against because they want to devote themselves to the family and we do not listen to them.
And this is a question of freedom, it is a question of freedom of choice that the left so likes to evoke, but that here it forgets.
It is a question of respecting or not respecting the freedom of association of couples.
It is about being able to provide those who want to do so with more quality of life, more fatherhood and more quality motherhood.
That's what our society needs to do, too.
We're not going there, we're not going to solve the problems of birth and people's happiness with prejudice.
We solve with policies tailored to the reality and the spontaneous desires of the people.
We don't see it as an objection to the state and the market.
Let's go there with a fair look at the family.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the difficult situation in Quimonda has been aggravated by the emergence of the financial and economic crisis.
The Portuguese Government has done everything it deems appropriate and useful to help resolve the situation.
And we would like the Bavarian government to know how to act with a great sense of responsibility in this area as well.
Saving the facilities in Munich will have a decisive impact on the Villa del Conde and Dresden units.

The Portuguese Minister, Manuel Pinho, himself, expressed great interest in making this company, which is so important for Portugal and Europe, viable, referring to the fact that Aquimonda can be a globally competitive company.
Mr President, the efforts of the Portuguese Government to find a solution that guarantees the viability of the company are being maintained.
We hope that the German governments, in the federal and state plan, will effectively work to solve this problem.
As far as I am concerned, I would like to emphasize again the strategic importance of maintaining this type of industry on European territory.
that no national or state executive makes the mistake of allowing this company to close facilities and liquidate jobs on Union territory.

Ladies and gentlemen, we understand the need to help restructure the large groups in the automotive industry, but the Union's funds and the European Commission's energy cannot be used up in these aid.

Mr President, Commissioner, to urge the Commission to support Aquimonda by overcoming possible communication gaps, we appeal to Commissioner Vladimir Spila, to whom we have political security ties, and to President Barroso, who will never forget that he is our compatriot and a significant part of Aquimonda's workers.

We must emphasize, before we finish, that the Portuguese President, Cavaco Silva, in Germany, recently said that there was a new hope for Aquimonda and it is still necessary to refer to the importance, as has already been done by colleagues, of the economic sector itself in which Aquimonda operates.
We take into account that the Portuguese Government is ready to support Quimonda with whatever is necessary, taking into account the economic dimension of the country.
Ladies and gentlemen, let's help save the world. Time is of the essence.

Madam President, Commissioner, we have been talking about the Lisbon strategy for years and the times in which we live are perhaps not the right ones to talk about the Lisbon strategy, but we certainly need a strategy.
A strategy that responds to the difficulties and challenges that the current crisis poses to us.
And that is what we also expect from the Commission.
It is essential that the Commission does not move away from this issue and rather has the capacity to coordinate actions with the governments of Portugal, Germany and the Länder of Germany.

It is essential to bear in mind that this is an industry, as has already been said here, which interests Europe for its quality and value, for the research it develops, for the environmental quality which is also associated with it, and it is essential that the Commission does not move away.
I subscribe to the invitation made by my colleague Mr Pineda for the Commissioner and the Commission to move to Portugal.
It is essential that the Commission be aware that at this stage the Europeans are looking to Europe and are waiting for answers from the European authorities.

European citizens do not understand a Europe that washes its hands, they want a Europe that has the audacity to put its hands in the mass and put its hands to work, helping them to overcome difficulties.
Mr President, I also add my word to the tributes to Jammeh, but I asked for the floor to welcome the President for his statement on the European Day in Memory of the Victims of Terrorism.
It was on my proposal that, five years ago, we adopted this directive, which the Council endorsed at a meeting on 25 March to follow up the tragic attacks in Madrid.
But my intervention was an appeal.
Parliament has always been faithful to this date, but unfortunately this date has not yet been projected by the European institutions and the Member States as a whole.
I believe that the celebration of this date is one of the most important instruments we have to pay tribute to the victims, as your President did, but also to raise the level of public awareness.
I know there are celebrations in Madrid today, but little else.
And so my appeal to the Commission, to the Czech Presidency, is that all the Member States should celebrate this date with dignity in the future.
Ladies and gentlemen, my dear colleagues, the crisis is deeper than we expected and unemployment will be higher than we expected.
There are good reasons to believe that the European stimulus is not enough, but it is already clear at this point that it is taking too long to reach the citizens.
Parliament's position is strong and clear, it has been and I hope it will continue to be.
Our objective is to maintain employment and to create new jobs, with cohesion, with solidarity, both territorial and social.
And in this moment of crisis, citizens cannot be satisfied with a Europe that does not give them an answer, with a Europe that is powerless in the face of the problems they are facing.
What is Parliament going to ask the Commission for?

It naturally asks, through these reports, that national interventions be coordinated, that all means at its disposal be used to intervene, and that all conditions be given as a budgetary entity for this to happen.

It asks you to launch a clear European employment initiative and tells you that it is important to have a timetable for implementing financial market regulation measures and to bring credit to the real economy.
But what do you ask the council?
The Council is asked, above all, to rediscover the political will which is at the heart of the construction of the European project.
The European Union is competition, but it is also cohesion and solidarity.
And there can be no single market without this guarantee of solidarity and cohesion.
That is why we have all delegated at European level the national autonomies we had before joining this project.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, those who visit sub-Saharan Africa easily recognise in the generality of countries the enormous weakness of their health systems and the extremely negative impact that this weakness has on the lives and health of the populations that those services should serve.
The indicators continuously published at international level continue to confirm this.
And to this extent, it is absolutely disturbing that simple gestures and practices, even if not very elaborate, not even particularly costly, could be enough to save many lives.

European financial support can be crucial in this respect and we cannot always fail to bear in mind how cooperation in the field of health is truly strategic and directly crosses not only one of the Millennium Development Goals but many of the Millennium Development Goals.

The Court of Auditors found that Community funding for the health sector had not increased since 2000 in the proportion of its total development aid, despite the commitments made by the Commission with regard to the Millennium Development Goals and the health crisis in sub-Saharan Africa.
Finished.

The Commission has made a significant contribution through its funding to set up the World Fund for the Fight against AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, but has not paid the same attention to strengthening health systems as was envisaged as one of its priorities.
The end of the quote.

According to the Court, this will have happened again because the Commission did not have sufficient experience in the field of health to ensure that the funding of the aid granted to this sector was used in the best possible way.
Finished it.
This is therefore a strong challenge that the Court of Auditors is putting directly to the European Commission, and I support it.
For our part, I would like to reiterate this same challenge, which is now supported by the objectivity of this data and this assessment.
Health services are already part of, but must become more and more part of, our development aid priorities, deserving of an increase in their funding.
Optimizing the way aid is provided, given the seemingly antagonistic needs for coordination in its management and proximity to the beneficiary populations, is a service that can save many lives.
The European Commission cannot fail to respond positively to this challenge and that is what I am calling for.
Mr Bowis, just now, made a touching intervention here and was able to put human faces in the dry cold of these Court of Auditors figures.
The challenge for us, Madam Commissioner, is that of our cooperation, of being able to put a look of joy and hope on these very faces.
And for that, Commissioner, it is essential that the numbers in the field of health in our cooperation be different.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, once again, for sad reasons, we are discussing here the situation in Guinea-Bissau, which is a truly painful situation.
It is a country that has been experiencing chronic instability for many years, which tried a path to democracy in the early 1990s.

Nothing went well, there was a coup d'état, a small civil war and they live in great political and military instability, tensions, deep rivalries and now, recently, also the very worrying presence, increasingly evident to all observers, of the interest of drug trafficking.
We strongly condemn these attacks, the bombing of the Chief of Staff, Tagme Naoué, and also the murder, in particularly barbaric terms, not to say savage, of President Nino Vieira.
Regardless of their past, we express our solidarity with their families, with the people of Guinea-Bissau and we deeply regret and condemn these attacks.
We want a return to normality, and the lesson I draw, and which I would like to emphasize in the resolution, is that impunity is not a remedy.
In the past, with regard to the murder of Assoumani Mané and General Alvarado Siabra, how could the eyes be closed so that the culprits would not be found and brought to justice?
It's obviously a new system.
And so we have to make it clear to the State of Guinea-Bissau that the culprits have to be found, the guilty have to be brought to justice and we have to provide all the help that is needed.

I would also like to draw attention, to conclude, to the concern we have heard about the presence of drug trafficking throughout the region, the risk it already poses to the European Union and the shocking presence of it in Guinea Bissau.
I would also like to call for a tightening up of relations with Cape Verde in this context.

We have established a special partnership with Cape Verde, which has very close relations with Guinea, a great knowledge, but it is also very vulnerable, and this is also essential for our own European security.
Therefore, the intensification of the special partnership with Cape Verde is also very important in this context.
Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would first of all like to thank all those who have worked so hard.

The three lines defined in the Green Paper, concentration, interconnection and cooperation, can provide solutions to some obstacles to the harmonious development of the Union, namely the negative effects associated with the lack of competitiveness.

the concentration of economic activity, inequalities in terms of access to markets and services resulting from distance and the divisions imposed by borders between Member States, especially the most disadvantaged, but also between regions.
We must thus promote the improvement of synergies between these policies through effective methods of assessing their territorial impact.

That is why I have always advocated the definition of additional qualitative indicators with the aim of improving the design and implementation of the corresponding policies on the ground, taking into account the different territorial specificities.
For the time being, GDP remains the only eligibility criterion for receiving support from the Structural Funds.

However, this definition of additional indicators and the carrying out of territorial assessments should not be the cause of more bureaucracy or delays, but rather of the simplification of the application of new policies and actions in support of territorial cohesion.

The fifth interinstitutional report, to conclude, Mr President, makes a specific reference to the transition regions located between the convergence regions and the competitiveness and employment regions.
It should be noted that these regions need to have a clearer statute, with more security and stability for their development.

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in the context of this great debate on territorial cohesion and the future of economic and social cohesion policy, I could not fail to mention the very specific problem of the outermost regions.

Regions, by the combination and permanence of a number of geographical factors, reveal a great economic and social vulnerability, particularly felt in a context of serious international crisis such as the one we are currently experiencing.
I would therefore like to appeal to the European Commission, and in particular to Commissioner Hübner, to pay particular attention to the effects of the current crisis on the outermost regions.
An assessment of these effects in each of the outermost regions, namely in tourism, construction and unemployment growth, would be important to allow a specific European response for these regions.

I therefore challenge the European Commission to prepare a European response to the crisis for the outermost regions, which goes beyond the measures already announced in the area of economic and social cohesion policy for the generality of the European regions.
A specific European response to the crisis for the outermost regions

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in response to the global financial crisis, the European economy's growth plan states that cohesion policy contributes significantly to public investment by Member States and regions, and should act as a form of recovery from the current crisis.
It specifically suggests the adoption of actions in priority areas of the Lisbon strategy in order to achieve growth and employment.
All the instruments in place seek to achieve this objective and to accelerate the achievement of results.

In this respect, the expansion of the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and the acceleration of the European Social Fund have a particular responsibility to respond to the multiple social and economic emergencies that lack support.
I am certain, today as in the past, that your action will be as effective as your actions and areas will be complementary.

However, as the deployment of new funds or new lines of action on the ground has not been envisaged, it is particularly important that the European Social Fund be used to its full potential in combating unemployment and rapidly increasing the pressure of competitiveness in the European economy resulting from the current financial crisis and economic slowdown.

I would like to emphasize that the REGI Committee has repeatedly identified simplification as essential for improving the management and implementation of the Structural Funds, as the European Commission is now proposing.

We were, however, called upon to act urgently in this matter, and in adopting this package of regulations we took it into account, and this cause was never prevented from assuming its political responsibilities.

Therefore, despite the many serious views that the particularity of the moment raises, in addition to the guarantees of the speed of the process and the real benefit to the citizens that the proposal aims to achieve, we now refrain from presenting new proposals and amendments.
However, we are aware of the need to start an evaluation process of this fund as soon as possible, with a view to carrying out a supplementary review as soon as possible.
The crisis, among other things, has highlighted the strong imbalances between the countries of the euro area, perhaps the main cause of the crisis.

I would like to thank the rapporteur for his report on the economic and monetary union, but above all for the extreme vulnerability of the countries which, belonging to the European Union, do not belong to the euro area.

That is why the strengthening of the means available at European level to support situations of crisis in the balance of payments is absolutely essential and that is why we are saving the passage from 12 to 25 and hence to 50 million euros of necessary means.
However, the most important thing is to attack the deep causes of the problems and not just their most obvious manifestations.
Today, the enlarged Europe and the euro area must reinterpret the meaning of European solidarity and the objectives of cohesion and real convergence.
It is necessary to look at the capacity of Europe's horizontal policies in this light, but it is also necessary to review new financing instruments such as Eurobonds.
Financial assistance to the balance of payments is necessary, but it is far from sufficient to ensure the sustainability of the European project and the European single currency.
Mr President of the Commission, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, we are in an unprecedented crisis.

It was not, in fact, the time to discuss internally how to organise ourselves, and that is why my votes are for the Treaty of Lisbon to be ratified quickly so that we can face the world scene together and in solidarity as Europeans.

As far as the economic crisis is concerned, the report I wrote and which this Parliament approved by a majority of votes acknowledged that the relaunch plan presented by the Commission was not sufficient.
Today we are sure that it is not enough.
A crisis that began financially extends to the real economy, to employment and to social welfare.
And it's not enough and it's exhausted.

This is the opportunity for the Commission to respond to the real problems of Europeans through serious financial regulation and not through the more light-hearted and partisan regulation that is needed.
It is not the result of national and individualist plans, but of a genuine European initiative, not through scattered means, but by concentrating on the real challenge I am facing.

In every crisis there is an opportunity, this is the opportunity for the Commission and Europe to respond to the real problems of European citizens, and I hope that this will happen through a new approach to the relaunch plan.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I just wanted to express, not only on behalf of the EPP, as has already been done by many Members, but in particular on behalf of the Portuguese Members of the EPP, my great satisfaction with the outcome of the referendum in Ireland.
We believe that this clearly strengthens the prospects for the development and evolution of the European Union, which creates conditions for a new stage.

We naturally wanted to congratulate all those who contributed to the Lisbon Treaty, in particular the Commission and the Commissioner and Vice-President present here, and also, of course, the Portuguese Presidency of the European Union.

"It is with great pleasure that we have verified that, despite all these vicissitudes and still looking forward to the position of the Czech Republic, it will be with great joy that the Portuguese will see the name of their capital linked to the Czech Republic.

It is a decisive step in the evolution of the European Union and I would like to say that we can also count on another flag in this perspective, which will always be the flag of the Portuguese deputies of the PPE, which is the flag of the national parliaments.
We hope that the Treaty of Lisbon will be a decisive step towards incorporating the presence of national parliaments into European democracy.

And that is why we consider that this dimension, which is the most important dimension of democracy, which is the representative dimension and not, as we sometimes hear in this Chamber, the referendum dimension.

While the fundamental and essential feature of democracy is representation and not direct vote, the Treaty of Lisbon is also a major step towards increasing the participation of national representative democracies in the European process.
That is why we are very pleased with this decision of the Irish people.

Mr President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, a brief intervention to welcome the historic and wide-ranging outcome of the referendum in Ireland and to highlight the decisive role played by Fine Gael and its leader and future Prime Minister, Enda Kenny, in taking the lead in this process.
A process in which the need to bring the European Union much closer to its citizens became very clear.
They are, we are all, the main beneficiaries of all the Union's action.
It is essential that everyone is aware of the impact and benefits that Europe has on our lives on a daily basis.
Europe is our vital space.
What is good for Europe is good for each Member State, it is good for its citizens.
This is certainly the case with the Treaty of Lisbon.
With this Treaty it becomes much more evident that one can be both a proud and committed national citizen and a staunch defender of the European project.

And the European Union, after a long debate on its organisation and functioning, will be able to concentrate much more and with new instruments much more effective on the real problems facing Europeans: competitiveness, growth and employment.
I conclude, Mr President, Madam Minister, with a proposal for future generations.

Given the lack of information on the values, competences, objectives and way of functioning of the European Union, the European Parliament should propose, at the end of compulsory schooling in each Member State, a new compulsory European studies discipline.
In an objective, true and concrete way, young Europeans will effectively know our principles, who we are, what we do and where we want to go.

It is through knowledge, from an early age, that they will understand, throughout their lives, the potential and the enormous usefulness of the European identity of this single project of voluntary sharing of sovereignty on a continental scale.

Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, I begin by congratulating you in this first debate on what this new instrument of political control means for the progress and development of parliamentary democracy in Europe.
It is the European citizens, through their representatives, who win.

Taking into account the latest developments, the Irish referendum, the ratification by Poland and the latest statements by the President of the Czech Republic, I ask what assessment he makes of the process of entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon.
There have been diligences on the part of the President of the Commission.
What is the forecast for a possible date of entry into force of the Treaty and, on the other hand, whether at this time and in accordance with this forecast, the Commission

There have already been some transitional procedures for treaties, from the Treaty of Nice to the Treaty of Lisbon, or it is still in a phase of, let's say, expectation, therefore, in a phase of waiting to see.

Mr President of the Commission, having heard this, I would like to know the following: at this stage, when everyone is waiting for the formation of the Commission, what is the perspective of the President?

It is whether we will now have, until this final ratification by the Czech Republic, a committee in charge or whether they will proceed with the procedures for the appointment of the new Commissioners.

Mr President, it is essential that the primary objective of the creation of the European External Action Service be the concrete implementation of the efforts of the European institutions to ensure the creation of an effective service capable of articulating, formulating and implementing a European response to the international challenges of the present.
It must still represent more than the parts that make it up, it must be an added value in relation to the current efforts of the Member States and the European Union.
In this respect, it seems to me essential that what makes the Union specific is at the heart of this new reality, and that specificity is the Community method.
That is why I give my full support to the Brok report, which defends and safeguards a close link between the Commission and the future service.

I would like to make this point to highlight two aspects of the importance of close coordination between the President of the Commission and the High Representative, also Vice-President of the Commission, to ensure its effectiveness and proper functioning.

Finally, there is a need for an alliance between Parliament and the Commission to combat the intergovernmental drift that is being announced and which may jeopardise the effective functioning of the service.
Parliament must therefore be vigilant and ensure that the European External Action Service is a centre of excellence representing the best foreign policy competences.
Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to emphasize the importance of this question put by Mr Lorenz, because it is a question of the most elementary justice.

We all know perfectly well that in a pandemic situation of influenza A, it will be the southern countries that will suffer the most from this problem and the consequences of the spread of the virus, and not the northern countries.
And we witness every year, with total passivity, the deaths of millions of citizens as a result of pandemics that have already been eradicated or are being treated in the countries of the North.
We have no limits to this list and we passively watch this problem.

We actually use the southern countries as free suppliers of samples of the new strains of the virus so that we can improve treatment in the northern countries, but we still have no effective response to these problems, and therefore to the questions that have been raised I would just like to add a few more.
We really want to treat this problem as a public health problem or as a business problem.
Because if it's a public health problem, we have to ensure equal access to treatment in all regions of the world, and to do that, efforts have to be more effective.
On the other hand, I would like to ask, and I hope that this is not the case, whether we are waiting for the vaccine stocks in Europe to be so overloaded.
The secondary schools are so negative about this plan that we have a show of generosity and suddenly we start sending the necessary vaccines to the southern countries.

Finally, I would just like to ask whether the European Union, whether we Europeans and the Commission feel comfortable with a system or a model where the countries of the North treat pandemics through a prevention model and in the countries of the South they treat them as palliatives or only with surpluses.

Mr President, first of all I would like to express my full support for the question put by Mr Reul and, above all, to highlight the fundamental question, the fundamental political question which is here in this matter, which has to do precisely with the joint programming of the inquiry.

What happened in the matter of joint programming on neurodegenerative diseases, and in particular on Alzheimer's, was that in the middle of the process the rules changed, we stopped having a report, we stopped having a resolution, so our capacity for co-decision in this matter was eliminated, we stopped being MPs, we became consultants.
And so I would like to know whether, at least, what we recommend will be taken into account or not.
The programming of research activities, whatever the subject, is a political choice, not a technical choice, and in this respect the role of Parliament must be valued and strengthened.
It seems to me that defining priorities that are political means that they must be coordinated, that they must be transparent and that they must be democratic.
What happened with the process in relation to the joint decision and joint programming of the Alzheimer's investigation is a process that should not be repeated again.
I hope, therefore, that the last thing that can happen to us is that the decisions and recommendations put forward by Parliament in this matter are not taken into account.
Mr President, in the last month the regions of Europe have been particularly evident.
The European Week for Regions and Cities has built the position of regions as a fundamental part of the European response to global challenges.
This is how they concluded, leaving no room for doubt, President Durão Barroso, Commissioner Sameski and the hundreds of debates that took place.

Also at a more specific level, the holding of the important meeting of the Conference of Presidents of the outermost regions of Europe, which for the first time had the participation of Members of the European Parliament, constitutes a framework in regional policy for the construction of Europe.
Global challenges and European responses are a great opportunity for a new strategy for the EU.

These regions, like the Azores, in addition to the permanent constraints that everyone is accustomed to hearing about, present a set of potentialities that provide clear opportunities to make our progress and give Europe a clear advantage in new domains essential to responding to global challenges.

It is therefore necessary for the President of the Commission to put an end to the palace coup that the Commission's No Paper indicates was being prepared while we, Members of the European Parliament and citizens, apologized for the ratification of the Treaty of Lisbon and its importance in defending the cohesion of the European territory.
I would first like to greet the rapporteurs, namely Mr Martin and Mr Corbett, and say that as a member of the PPE, I basically look back on the changes proposed to the regiment.
It was difficult to emphasize the point which seems to me to be important and which has not yet been brought up here tonight, namely the point of the national parliaments.

The democratic strengthening of the European Parliament is undoubtedly the result of this regime and the Treaty of Lisbon, but European democracy is also the result of the link with the national parliaments.
And what this regime, this proposal, is now doing is precisely to create these two democratic legitimacy, to strengthen democracy.

On the one hand, the resulting democracy of the European Parliament's own instruments, its instruments of control of its legislative capacity, and, on the other hand, the democratic collaboration of national parliaments through different instruments.
And that is why I am, let us say, in complete harmony with the proposals made.
I do not agree with Mr Duff when he says that we should leave it to later to interrupt the mechanisms of relations with the national parliaments.
I think we can do that, given the Lisbon Treaty, and that this is very important.
I also wanted to say that I support the proposal of my colleagues Sayer and Brok regarding the representation in the Cossack and, finally, that I am
I am in full solidarity with the remarks made here by Mr Brok and other colleagues on the primacy of Parliament and Members of Parliament in relation to Parliament's services.
Mr President, Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I congratulate the rapporteur on the work she has done on this report and on her recent intervention.
This new microfinance instrument will allow micro-credit to be granted to small businesses and people who have lost their jobs and want to create their own business and their own jobs.
This is very important at a time when the economic crisis is expected to result in the loss of 3.5 million jobs in the European Union alone.
As a consequence of the economic downturn, banks have stopped providing loans for job creation and businesses, and access to credit is more difficult at a time when it should be more accessible.
Now, this new means of microfinance will counteract this current trend of restricting access to credit, facilitating the obtaining of funds needed to launch new businesses and new jobs.
The European Commission's proposal aims to reallocate EUR 100 million from the budget of the Progress programme for this financing instrument.
We cannot agree to this proposal.
The financial and economic crisis is also a social crisis.
Thus, the reallocation of resources from Progress, which targets the most vulnerable groups, is by no means the most appropriate solution.
For this reason, the creation of a separate budgetary heading to finance this instrument is supported, as is an increase in the appropriation to EUR 150 million.

We also agree with the need to clarify in the legislation itself that the target group is vulnerable groups who have difficulty entering or re-entering the labour market and who face the threat of social exclusion.
Thus, the reference to specific groups should be deleted.
Finally, we stressed that it is essential that people who have financial support also have adequate training.

Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating the Swedish Presidency and, in particular, Prime Minister Reinfeldt, both on behalf of the PPE and on behalf of the Portuguese delegation of the PPE.
Our assessment of the Swedish Presidency is of practically absolute success, essentially in four fundamental areas.

The first is in the institutional area, the contribution of the Swedish Presidency to the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, for the very successful election of the President of the Commission.
In particular, all the ratification issues associated with ratification were extremely professional and in line with what is expected to be the best practices of the European Union.
Naturally, for a country like Portugal, which played a decisive role in the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon, this contribution of the Swedish Presidency is invaluable.
A second point is the climate agenda, where, of course, the Commission's work was also very important.
We must say that, from my point of view and from the point of view of many Members of the EPP, it is in the area of climate change that the European Union has had the most success.
It is in the forefront of global combat, and this is due to the efforts of both the Swedish Presidency and, in particular, the Presidency of the Commission.
We consider this balance to be very positive.

A third point is the point of financial regulation, which, especially with this last Council, has taken a step which we consider decisive and which can have a very big impact on the way out of the crisis.
And so I also wanted to congratulate you on having reached an agreement in this area.
And finally, I would like to say a word about an area which tells me a lot about the Stockholm Programme and therefore about the area of security, justice and freedom.

I believe that I, who accompanied both the Tempera process and, in particular, the DAIA process, consider this Stockholm programme absolutely essential and I would like to congratulate the Swedish Presidency and Prime Minister Ralf Fälte on this.

Mr President, for the recognition of professional qualifications, 15 directives have been consolidated in a single legislative act, as is well known, which has led to a variety of practical problems in the application in the different Member States.
The difficulties are well known and the Commission will have to identify the critical points and analyse the problem areas involved in the implementation of this important internal market mechanism.
Protectionism, which manifests itself at various levels, is an obstacle not only to the free movement of people but also to the internal market.
We must try to identify the blurred points so that the effectiveness of the directive is not distorted by mistrust.
The Union is not asked to do what the Member States have to do, but there is an effort to facilitate it, which helps to overthrow professional corporatism.
An improvement in the application of this Directive should involve the disclosure of the recognition of qualifications on the SOLVIT network and on the EURES network by means of an incentive
common platforms, the implementation of effective contact points and, no less important, the provision of an articulation of this Directive with the Services Directive.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is urgent that a debate be held on the Community budget and how it can contribute to its sustainability and transparency in the future.

The post-2013 financial framework must be built on the basis of solidarity and territorial cohesion, crucial values for regions such as Madeira, which face permanent difficulties and therefore need permanent support.
I would like to share with you some ideas that I believe should always be present when thinking and building cohesion policy.

The Commission has on several occasions referred to some aspects which seem to me to be essential, such as the need for greater flexibility, simplicity, efficiency and more guidance for achieving results in the definition and implementation of this policy.
But there are issues which raise some concern, especially in view of the needs of the outermost regions.
In this respect, let me make three brief remarks. Firstly, the current approach in terms of regions should prevail over alternative orientations, such as the value-added sectors.

A reorientation such as this can put in place Objective 2, which currently benefits about two thirds of the European regions, in addition to potentially being counterproductive in regions with very distinctive economic profiles and competitive advantages.
The allocation and management of the Structural Funds must continue to be favoured from a regional and non-national perspective or even centralised at European level.
The Lisbon Treaty provides for special treatment of the outermost regions in terms of access to structural funds, precisely because of their economic and social situation.
This is aggravated by conditionalities and unique characteristics of a perennial nature, which manifest themselves in such constant difficulties and which therefore require the permanent aid claimed.
Mr President, in view of the urgency, what we witnessed in Copenhagen was several steps back.

It is true that Copenhagen mobilized more heads of state than Kyoto, but it also created more divisions, and as a result, what happened was that we now have a situation where each state can define its own goals and, above all, a voluntary regime.
Referring to the fact that we have a two-degree target or funding targets without any clarification can also not serve as a consolation.
So what I think is that we have to act in terms of the future, and acting in terms of the future is to stop going from rhetoric to action.
The European Union has always wanted to be a leader, it has always said so.
But when we arrived in Copenhagen, he hesitated, did not define or defend the goals that he claimed here to be his goals and of which he would not be lacking.

And so what I ask is whether in the future we will not be more just, whether we will continue to allow the poorest to continue to pay the heaviest bill at the expense of this failure and the decisions of others.
Mr President, I wanted to denounce here what is happening in Portugal at the moment, where it is clear that social communication is a very important part of our society.
A government plan to control newspapers, to control television stations, to control radio stations, which calls into question freedom of expression, has come to light.
This week, a well-known journalist, Mario Crespo, saw his chronicle censored, also at the suggestion or apparent suggestion of the Prime Minister.

In the face of this, Prime Minister José Sócrates has to give substantial explanations to the country, he has to explain that he is not dominating, asserting, censoring freedom of expression in Portugal.

The way we are walking, Portugal is no longer a state of law, it is a formal state of law, where the Prime Minister limits himself to formalities, procedures, formalisms and does not want to give substantive explanations.
For Portugal, we want a material rule of law.

Mr President, the Green Paper on the reform of the common fisheries policy, to which my colleague from the Azores, Maria Ducel·le Patron Neves, is rapporteur, is a unique opportunity for a debate on a sector which is of great importance in the balance of local development in the outermost regions.

Madam President, I am particularly interested in the ongoing debate and believe that it is imperative that there should be a distinction between artisanal and industrial fleets, which should benefit from different fishing regimes.
It is essential to defend a principle of positive discrimination, which is to limit access to territorial waters within the exclusive economic zone only to local artisanal fleets.
In the case of timber, support for the modernisation of vessels is a priority, as is a matter that guarantees the conservation of a comprehensive group of species in the long term.
Only in this way will we be able to avoid unsustainable situations for economic, environmental and social balance.
Finally, we will fight for permanent and non-dated support for fisheries in the outermost regions.
This report on the FEDER aims to extend the eligibility of interventions in the housing sector for marginalised communities in our Member States.
Until now, this support applied only to marginalised communities living in the urban areas of the new Member States.
That is, since the vast majority of these types of communities live in rural areas and in shelters, these communities could not benefit from support to replace poor-quality housing.
It is, in essence, about how to kill a vaccine and give Member States and their regions greater possibilities in the policy of mitigating the specific difficulties of these communities.
I also welcome equal treatment for all Member States, as marginalised communities in need of support and integration deserve our concern, irrespective of the Member State to which they belong.

At the end of this important report on the fight against poverty and human dignity, it is equally possible to quickly implement it in the context of the economic recovery plan, responding swiftly to the crisis affecting us.

Mr President, Commissioner, allow me to begin by highlighting the role of the rapporteur, Mr Van Nistelrooy, for his work in seeking consensus on this matter and also for the availability he has always shown of incorporating other contributions into his report.
Tomorrow we will vote on amendments to the FEDER Regulation which are of particular importance to the so-called former Member States and also to Portugal.

These changes will make it possible to extend the use of the ERDF in the housing sector to benefit marginalised communities, as at present this fund can only be attributed to urban development operations.

The amendments I proposed together with other colleagues and which were adopted by a large majority in the Committee on Regional Development will allow the former Member States, and not just the new ones, as the original proposal provided, to also benefit from this financing possibility.
With this, I tried to avoid a precedent that I consider dangerous and that would exclude all the former Member States from this and probably from other additional uses of Community aid.
This would not make any sense, since housing problems, especially among marginalised communities, exist both in the new and in the old Member States.

I take this opportunity to reiterate that the age of accession to the European Union should not be a criterion for the allocation of Structural Funds and that this criterion should be provisionally abandoned.

The negotiation of the post-2013 cohesion policy should be based on solidarity, with a view to territorial cohesion, and should be aimed at rewarding, rather than punishing, the regions that have shown exemplary use of Community aid.

Mr President, I would like at this point essentially to underline to the Commission and the President of the Commission the way in which they have worked with this Parliament during these months of investiture.

There is no body in the world with executive power and legislative initiative which is subject to the presentation by its President of a programme before Parliament, to an audition with all the groups.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?
Someone who has agreed to negotiate with Parliament a framework agreement in which he has agreed, first of all, to justify and extend Parliament's powers in the legislative initiative.

The European Parliament has accepted the principle of full access to information, whether in legislative and political action or in international negotiations, and has accepted to take account of Parliament's opinion on the Commissioners, on the reorganisation of the Commissioners.
This means, once and for all and from my point of view, that the Commission has shown, from July to now, that it is prepared to have a close link with Parliament and that it is ready to do so.

In doing so, it has clearly and vividly and unequivocally demonstrated that the strategic alliance of the Treaty of Lisbon for the Community method, as spoken of by Mr Sarri Zvolsky, is the alliance between Parliament and the Commission.
And that is why the Commission and the framework agreement deserve the full support of the PPE.
Five years after the Orange Revolution, Ukrainians seem to look at this period as a lost opportunity.
And it's not just the fault of their political elites.
It is true that these were consumed too much in wars of power and influence.
Many reforms have been put in place, many have not gone through the paper.
It is inconceivable that in any democracy the electoral laws should be changed between the two rounds of an election.
It does not dignify those who proposed them, those who voted for them or those who promulgated them.
and translates the unflattering and commendable intentions into its genesis.
And much has to change under the lack of independence of the judiciary, which is subject to too much influence, not only from the political power but also from the economic agents.
Without free and independent justice, there is no rule of law, human rights are not guaranteed, there is no foreign investment, there is no progress.
But the blame for this disenchantment also rests heavily on this Parliament and, essentially, on many Member States.
I would like us to put ourselves for a moment in the shoes of a citizen of a European country which, because of the vicissitudes of history, is not yet a member of the European Union.
The spider is a joke.
It's called solidarity.

But many chancelleries, with the sole concern of not bothering and displeasing Moscow, have used and abused the constant intestinal struggles in Kiev to avoid unequivocally claiming that Ukraine is an independent and sovereign country.
As such, if this majority will is freely expressed by its people and as long as it meets the established criteria, Ukraine can aspire to be a member of the European Union in the future.
It should be noted that in the island regions air transport provides the only access option and that operating conditions are conditioned by the size of their passenger and cargo flows.

There are island regions where the abundance of these flows is desirable for many airlines, attracting competition and low transport prices, thus improving accessibility, and others, such as the Azores, where these flows are still reduced, not being attractive to the interest of operators.

As a result, air fares are higher, constituting an obstacle to the mobility of populations and a condition for the reception of tourists, which allows this enormous potential for development and diversification of their economic base to flourish and be built.
This picture is particularly penalizing in times of crisis, as we are going through.

It is therefore essential to provide temporary support to encourage an increase in flows so that the market can start to function, also sharing these regions with high tourism potential with the objectives of the trans-European networks in the approach to the peripheries of Europe.
Mr President, I took the floor today in this House with a voice that was overwhelmed by the consternation of those who lived and personally witnessed the tragedy that struck the wood last Saturday.
My words are, of course, to associate myself with the feeling of pain and mourning that has struck the families of the dead, who now number 42, to whom I pay my respects for their losses.
