The true scale of this catastrophe is yet to be revealed as the search and rescue teams that have been working uninterruptedly since Saturday in a Herculean effort that I salute only now begin to reach the most isolated populations.
and we fear that the number of victims may increase.
The scenario is one of large-scale destruction, with high material damage to access roads, completely destroyed roads and bridges, and to essential services such as water and electricity supply.
About 600 displaced people have lost their homes and belongings.
The economic and social impact of this catastrophe prevents people from returning to a normal course of life.
You need to look ahead now.
I also need to send a message of solidarity, hope and trust to the people.
We need to help, and it is in this chapter that the European Union and Parliament in particular have a say, and they are fundamental in the process of mobilising the Solidarity Fund.
And when we are called upon to intervene, we must do so quickly, because we cannot ask these people to wait, especially when they need us most.

I appeal to the Commission and its President, Doran Barroso, and in particular to the Commissioner for Regional Development, Johannes Ahn, and I welcome your initiative to visit Madeira in the shortest possible time.
I ask him to be the bearer of this message of hope, help and support for the reconstruction, because now is the time to rebuild what nature has unfortunately and once again mixed.
But I am sure we will, because, as the hymn of the wood teaches me, the people of Madeira are humble, stoic and brave.
It is the people who, among the rocks, worked the land, the hero of the work on the mountainside.
By the wood he will honor his history, and in the way of work he will fight and achieve his well-being and glory.
We begin this plenary session today with a minute's silence.

It was a minute of silence with two meanings: solidarity for the victims of this catastrophe that has struck Madeira and their families, and a sense of homage to all the workers who have tirelessly helped these victims.
But a minute of silence should make us reflect and should also lead to a reflection that goes beyond what we are doing here.
What we hear in the woods is a phenomenon that will tend to repeat itself more and more.
Climate change is causing extreme phenomena to repeat themselves, and we need to have answers to them.
We cannot avoid natural disasters, but we must not be condemned to them having always such dramatic effects on people's lives.
That is why we must fight for policies of planning and order that are oriented to the public good.

But I want to conclude, Mr President, with what is most important and what has brought us here, which is that the European Commission, the European Parliament and the European institutions must have the capacity to respond urgently to an emergency situation, and for that we need the necessary financial resources and the necessary speed.
A tribute of solidarity to the families and friends of the victims of the tragic events of Saturday on the island of Madeira.
As a Syrian, as a Portuguese and as a European, I cannot fail to appeal to Parliament and the Union for their active solidarity in favour of the Autonomous Region of Madeira and its populations.
It is in the regions that the presence of the Union needs to be felt and it is precisely at these moments that its solidarity is most needed, that it is also most important that it is felt.

Mr President, I too would like to express my solidarity with the people of Madeira and urge the European institutions, and in particular the Commission, to use all the means at their disposal to provide this aid.
I would also like to emphasize that when there is such a misfortune, it is much more difficult to deal with its consequences when it occurs in poor countries and in poor regions.

But in the case of wood, we also have to take into account that the economic base of wood is directly affected by the fact that, depending on tourism, it has a double consequence when its natural beauty, its access, its quality of life are completely destroyed.

So there is, in fact, a different situation when we have problems of this gravity in poor countries and in poor regions and, in particular, in mountainous and tourist regions, as is the case with the wood.
It is therefore absolutely essential that all the adaptations that have been planned and requested and that have been mentioned here regarding the Solidarity Fund no longer wait.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has already made a number of proposals to the Council and the European Parliament on this subject.
Commissioner and Council, we are here to talk about the reinvention of the energy system on a European scale through investment in low-carbon technologies.
I think it's one of the very important challenges, as it's referred to, by the way, in the communication that's being made.
And it is one of the challenges that we have to face in a central way, but there is no clarification here and therefore the importance of putting these questions and asking for clarification.
It seems that not only is there a lack of clarification of funding, but there is also a lack of political clarification.
There is talk of energy efficiency, carbon capture, nuclear, biofuels, solar and there is talk of energy efficiency as the cheapest way to reduce emissions.
I am surprised that there are other, much cheaper ways of reducing carbon emissions that are not even part of this communication, such as, of course, reducing consumption.
energy, micro-generation, distribution and different forms of distribution and different projects that don't just have to go through the large structures and access to energy.
I think that would certainly contribute to further financial clarification to make the plan cheaper.

And so, within this political clarification and within this financial clarification, it is still necessary to talk about what seems to me to be an absolutely important point, which is the tonic that is permanently placed in public or private partnerships as if they were the solution to everything.
When you ask where the money comes from, the Commission tells us where it comes from.
I confess that I am no longer enlightened by being told that the money will come from where it is, without being told exactly where it is.

And so this bet on public or private partnerships, which is systematically made when we talk about low-carbon technologies, we are certainly left with the certainty that we don't know where the money is coming from and knowing that it's public or private partnerships, we know from the outset who's going to pay.
Who will pay are the taxpayers at the beginning, are the consumers who, by chance, are also taxpayers at the end.

And we know that the people who pay the least, and the ones who start out, are the private institutions and organizations, and that the people who make the investments are paid by them, but in the end they end up monopolizing the profits.
Without this clarification, it seems to me that once again we are systematically passing on to future generations the bill for the change in the European energy model.

Mr President, the European Union recently concluded an agreement with the countries of Latin America under the World Trade Organisation, in which it committed itself to a substantial and progressive reduction in tariffs on banana imports from these countries.

I draw your attention to the fact that such an agreement has a direct negative impact on European banana producers, particularly on the banana producers in Portugal, but also, even more intensely, on the Canary Islands in Spain.

I would remind you that the situation of the producers in these regions is already seriously hampered by the physical and orographic characteristics of the islands and the size of their exploitations, which lead them to face permanent difficulties that penalize their development.

It is therefore urgent to take action in defence of banana, timber and canary producers, given the serious and immediate impact that the new Geneva Agreement will have on the European import market and, consequently, on the production and marketing of bananas from these outermost regions.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, as rapporteur for the Social Affairs and Employment Committee, I would like to start by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent report.
I would like to congratulate Mr Kirilov, even in his forced absence, and to highlight the way in which he has been able to draw up this important report, thus facilitating the main objective.

This main objective is to simplify procedures without further delay and to accelerate the implementation of the programmes financed by the Cohesion Fund, the Structural Funds and the Regional Development Fund.
In the context of the current financial, economic and social crisis, pressure on national financial resources has been increasing.
This pressure will decrease with better use of Community funding, with the fastest delivery of these resources to the beneficiaries most affected by the economic collapse.
More than 20 million Europeans are unemployed, that is, four million more than a year ago, and unfortunately the trend is to increase.

This situation requires that the good implementation of cohesion programmes be ensured, as they represent the most powerful and relevant leverage for aid to the real economy, in particular in small and medium-sized enterprises and employment.
SMEs are the engine of the European economy and the actors of sustainable growth and the generators of jobs in quantity and quality.

The continuation of the simplification and clarification of the rules governing cohesion policy will undoubtedly have a positive impact on the pace of implementation of the programmes, particularly because it will be
I would like to ask the national, regional and local authorities to make use of clearer and less bureaucratic rules which will allow more flexibility in adapting the programmes to the new challenges.
Mr President, of course this crisis was an unforeseen crisis and of course the precautionary principle had to be given priority.
But there are lessons to be learned, and the first is that for five days there has been no European voice strong enough and politically irresponsible enough.
And this voice was lacking in terms of defending the interests of passengers, clarifying their rights, looking for transport alternatives and coordinating solutions.

A second conclusion is that the way out of the crisis cannot seem, in the eyes of the common citizen, to be a game of strengths between those who want to avoid harm and those who want to defend the precautionary principle.
There must be clear transparency and clear objectivity on the conditions under which a situation of total deprivation of the European space can be overcome.
And so the improvement of scientific tests and coordination also at the level

Mr President, I would also like to begin by congratulating Mrs Thyssen on her work and persistence in this very important matter and on the work she has done to improve the energy performance of buildings and for a more sustainable Europe.
Energy spending in the European Union, as we know, is far above what is acceptable, and that is why it is so important to move forward with proposals of this nature.
It is more than time for us to have an ambitious policy in European terms and to add to this ambitious policy complementary measures, especially in the crisis situation in which we live.
The construction sector is said to be one of the sectors, one of the markets with the greatest potential in terms of the economy and energy, but it's not just that.
And it is not only that, and that is why it is a sector par excellence for the formulation of public policies, and it is in this sense that I would like to conclude, Mr President.
We must therefore seize this opportunity to invest in improving the energy efficiency of buildings and their potential to create millions of jobs in the coming years.
And not only in new buildings, but also in the rehabilitation and recovery of existing buildings, damaged or inadequate.

Let us take advantage of this legislation as a fundamental contribution to the revival of the European economy and let us not continue to waste the investment that can and should be strategic for the recovery from the crisis.

Mr President, Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Manders on the work he has done on this report and thanking the colleagues who have worked with him on this dossier.

In fact, the very fact that this proposal simplifies and improves the existing regulatory framework, that it brings together in a single regulation all existing legislation, three basic directives on the designation and labelling of textile products, is in itself an important fact.

But beyond this, this proposal will have a positive impact on private agents and public authorities and will also allow for the framing of new fibres developed, thus encouraging innovation in the textile and clothing sector.
This review will also intensify the transparency of the process of adding new fibres to the list of harmonised designations of fibres.
There seems to be no doubt that the agents involved will have advantages with this regulation.
Let's see, the textile industry will benefit from an economy of administrative costs and the possibility of marketing new fibres sooner.
For their part, the authorities of the Member States will not need to transpose the amendments to national legislation, which will enable a cost-effective economy relevant to those Member States.
And consumers will be guaranteed that the fibres in question fulfil specific characteristics, while also benefiting from the fact that the new fibres arrive on the market earlier.
For the European industry, it is important to introduce these new fibres as a way of promoting innovation, while also increasing the level of information provided to consumers.
In the current context of a globalised world, emerging economies with increasingly expanded markets, in which millions of products produced by millions of companies circulate,
The commitment to innovation and the speed with which this innovation reaches consumers is absolutely crucial for companies, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.
that the application of this Regulation may increase its competitiveness.
These small and mediumsized enterprises will certainly gain market share with this new regulation and, in this way, will contribute to increasing employment in Europe.
Madam President, Mr Minister, Mr Commissioner, the shortage of organs for transplantation is a major problem.

It has already been mentioned here several times and it is a major problem that poses us with questions of both public health and related issues, such as the strengthening of the parallel market and the trafficking of organs, which in no way enlarges our health systems and not our citizens.

And so we have to fight this crime and fight it through the legislative proposals, such as those we are discussing here, which seem to me to be more important and more relevant, and that is why I want to focus on the most important dimensions and issues raised by these two proposals.
Because the system we have so far, and not having these two proposals, is a system of enormous inequalities.
Inequalities between Member States, inequalities between existing systems, inequalities of access to organs, inequalities between citizens, which it seems to me that we will not be able to bear.
It is therefore important to strengthen the reduction of these inequalities, and these proposals are aimed at combating precisely this.
I think that a European system which retains some of the specificities of some of the countries so that they are not obliged to have more restricted systems is the answer to this problem.
The work carried out by the rapporteurs, by Mr Miroslav László and Mr Perello Rodrigues, is of the utmost importance and contributes to this problem we are facing.
We are talking about proposals which are based on and support issues such as donations, volunteering, I apologise, free, confidentiality, data protection.
I think it is important on the part of Parliament that there should be patient recovery and not just donation and cooperation between Member States, and I think we are on the right track.
I must only refer, however, and in relation to the notions of inter vivos, I am pleased with the inclusion and the enlargement, this enlargement made with rights.

Obviously, all rights and conditions are guaranteed, but it is very important that we go beyond the restricted cycle of the conventional family, because otherwise it would be another way of having other forms of equality.

Promoting data as a key source of transparency and protecting patients' data and safety seems to me to be more than enough reason for us all to be together tomorrow and to vote in favour of these two proposals of the utmost importance.

Mr President, Madam Minister and Commissioner, the ability to replace damaged human organs with organs of another person, preventing their rejection, is one of the great successes of contemporary medicine.

European benchmarking reveals that medium-sized countries such as Portugal are very good at such comparisons and larger countries such as Spain are now recognised as organisational leaders and good practices.

Firstly, the strengthening of scientific knowledge and information, which lead more and more donors to live donation and to the generalization of postmortem donation.
Thirdly, proactive promotion of donation in hospitals as a way of overcoming the shortage.

Finally, Madam President, ensuring equal access to transplantation for all those who need it and qualify for it on harmonised clinical criteria, in accordance with the principle of the universality of access to health, a paradigm of social Europe of which we are proud.
I congratulate the rapporteurs on the work they have done.
I would like to emphasize that it is with great satisfaction that the European People's Party and the Portuguese deputies of the
The European People's Party is about to start this process of accession to the European Union, to the European Convention on Human Rights.

We, a country like Portugal, which has always been at the forefront of human rights, with the abolition of slavery in Portugal in 1761, with the pioneering in the abolition of the death penalty, can only be obviously interested and supportive of this process of accession.

I would, however, like to draw attention to the fact that we consider it very important that the European Parliament should accompany all the negotiations for the accession of the European Union to the European Convention on Human Rights.

We consider that this aspect, from a technical, legal and political point of view, is fundamental because Parliament is also a house of human rights and a house where human rights are of great relevance, and I would just like to point out that we consider it very important.

For us, the Members of the European Parliament, who are in contact with many countries outside the European Union, it is very important, it is a very good signal that we are giving to the members of the Council of Europe, to the members of the Council of Europe who are not members of the European Union.
For these members of the Council of Europe, this is a sign of the strengthening of the European Union's commitment to its situation and to the levels of democracy and respect for fundamental rights.
Madam President, Commissioner, social housing is an economic service of general interest with an important role in the market, creating positive externalities for the benefit of society as a whole.
In accordance with Protocol 26 annexed to the Treaty of Lisbon, it is for the national, regional and local authorities to carry out and organise this type of service.
Hence, it is incomprehensible that this restriction of the target audience to families with incomes below EUR 30 000 is being made.
This is a measurement of poverty that is made in absolute and purely financial terms, which does not take into account the diversity of the 27 Member States, and is simply an argument of solvency.

Social housing responds to cultural and social issues, such as proximity to the workplace, the important redefinition of the role of women in the market, and the mobility of workers in the European space.
The struggle that the European Union is waging to get out of the current crisis is driven by economic growth, which is dragged by an increase in immigration and ethnic minorities.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to point out that we are discussing the first report on the Committee on Agriculture, subject to the new ordinary legislative process provided for in the Treaty of Lisbon.
This is a historic moment which, by confirming in this House the vote I am proposing, will usher in the best possible way this new period of sharing of agricultural competences in the European Union.
I am speaking exactly to Iceland about its outermost regions in a practical demonstration of the will to build a Union that is strengthened by cohesion.
in the spirit of active solidarity, respect for the specificities and differences of the parties, as the only viable way to build our common European project.

I am also talking about introducing fundamental regulation to make the already centuries-old sugar industry in the Azores, the region where I come from, especially congratulations, viable, thus contributing to a better future.
healthy agricultural diversification in a region where the milk supply occupies, as we know, a unique, national, irreplaceable dimension which we must sustain and consolidate.
I would like to thank Commissioner Cioloş and the other officials of the Commission with whom we have worked and negotiated, for the openness and flexibility shown.
The Spanish Presidency of the Council has also made unlimited efforts to ensure that our partisan will to reach an agreement at first reading becomes a reality.

This thanks is obviously extended to the Members of the other political groups, as well as to the distinguished officials of the Secretariat of the Committee on Agriculture of this Parliament, whose cooperation has enabled us to reach a result which I consider to be very positive.

I would also like to emphasize the decisive contribution made by the Azores Agricultural Federation and the regional and republican governments in the way they engaged and worked towards a solution for the Azores sugar.

The Council's proposal for a regulation was presented to the Committee on Agriculture on 2 October at a time when there were no prospects of the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, which was still awaiting ratification by the other Member States.
In this context, the initial idea of the Commission and the Council was that the proposal should be approved in a simplified process, without any changes, to produce effects from 1 January 2010.

With the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon and despite the fact that at the time it dominated the opinion of other political groups, as well as the Council and the Commission, that the proposal should continue in a simplified process, because they understood that

Although this opinion prevailed, I and the Socialist and Democratic Group believe that Parliament should take a decision already within the framework of the Lisbon Treaty, assuming its role as co-legislator.

We did so in good time, because from then on new possibilities opened up, first with the contribution of the Committee on Regional Development and the partnership of my colleague Mr Nuntacheira, who is taking advantage of this.

I would like to congratulate and thank you for the cooperation you have always shown in this whole process, and then for my report introducing new possibilities for sugar in the Azores, as well as for the contribution and support of my colleagues in the Committee on Agriculture.

I should like to say, lastly, in this first speech, that with regard to the amendments proposed by the REGI Committee and voted on in the AGRI Committee and supported by me, we have not succeeded in getting your acceptance of the compromise reached in the trialogue.

It was essential to obtain a commitment at first reading, thus safeguarding the improvements already achieved and the need to enter into force, so as not to compromise its retroactivity since January this year.
However, as the Commission is already preparing a review document for the POSEI, we will certainly have the opportunity to discuss it again soon.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are faced with an acceleration of a global change which has devastating consequences for our economic, political and social systems and, consequently, for all our citizens.
We are witnessing today an unprecedented weakening of the capacity of the Member States to respond.
The European Union therefore has to identify common and allied causes and act clearly and unitedly on the world stage.
Extraordinary situations require the lucidity of joint action.

If we do not take the necessary collective measures of rigor and accountability, Europe will be voted into marginalisation and impoverishment, and only a strong Europe, respectful of its common rules, will be able to give an appropriate response to the new times.
Weak and indebted states have no capacity to protect their citizens.
Therefore, we need to be able to regain the confidence of citizens, to win the battles of stability, budgetary rigor, job creation, stability in monetary union, globalisation and strategic choices.
This is on the grounds that we have our future compromised.
And you win the future by betting on social cohesion, ensuring peace, building a new model based on values of freedom, social justice and responsibility.
Thus, the 2020 Strategy and the Integrated Guidelines Europe 2020 are essential instruments for a new cycle of growth and employment in Europe.
For proper implementation and implementation, quantifiable and clear targets need to be defined in employment, education and poverty reduction.

It is also crucial for the success of the strategy that everything is done to facilitate the transposition by the Member States of their national objectives and to ensure the correct implementation of this strategy.
When the Economic and Monetary Union turned ten, the Commission considered the euro to be the Union's most successful project.
Today we would have difficulty in affirming it without limitations, because the crisis has shown that economic and monetary union is an unfinished project.
Minimum rescue measures have been taken in an emergency climate, but let us not be mistaken the conditions of pressure, the direct interests of the main
The painful nature of the decisions, their slowness, have weakened the image of the euro and the European Union before the citizens and before the world.
We have to face the facts.
The European Union and the euro are a process of integration, not just cooperation between countries.
It's an unfinished project that's either getting stronger right now or it's at very serious risk of disappearing.
There are three issues that need to be addressed. First, it is important to consolidate the instruments that have been launched in this emergency climate.

We need to move forward with Eurobonds, we need to move forward with the European supervision and regulation architecture and we need to move forward with a European dimension in the management of banking crises.
Secondly, it is important to realise that there is no strong currency if the economy is weak.
The 2020 strategy is nothing more than a set of good ideas that have no means of materialization.
Thirdly, Commissioner Oleg Rehn, fiscal consolidation is important, but it cannot coexist with growing divergences between the Member States that make up the Union.
Mr President, several colleagues here from the PPE Group have already made a very comprehensive picture of the situation.
I think it will now be a question of demanding and referring to the role of the national states.
In fact, national governments also have a role to play in imposing on their states the requirements of the
and the conditions for the single currency to be strengthened and for this project of monetary and economic integration to be carried forward.
And here I wanted to say that our party, the party linked to the PPE, which is the PSD in Portugal, is supporting the government in austerity measures, because we consider

I believe that the mistakes that the Socialist government has made in Portugal over the last 15 years and that today, unfortunately, we are all aware that these mistakes need to be corrected and will have the support of the PSD to be corrected.

But if we are supporting austerity measures, we are also criticizing the Portuguese government, and it is a good example for other similar cases, because it is not reducing spending, and what is fundamental is not just

"It is not about raising taxes to reduce the deficit, but it is about reducing spending, it is about demanding from the government that it has the courage to take measures to reduce spending, to alleviate the deficit, to alleviate the public debt.
This applies to Portugal and to other States which are today in a difficult situation, and we as Members of the European Parliament have a responsibility to do the same in our own countries.
I apologize for the measures needed to strengthen the euro and to make this area of integration and this dream, which is a dream of the EPP and a dream of all of us, a reality.
That is why we criticize those governments which do not have the courage to take the necessary measures in their own states.

I would like to begin by saying that the report on the evaluation of the results of the 2006 roadmap for equality between men and women, which aims to influence strategies on this subject for the future, could, in our view, have been more decisive and less controversial.

In fact, the way in which various ethically sensitive issues, particularly the issue of women's sexual and reproductive health, were addressed should have been different if the objective was really to achieve the greatest possible consensus.

I would like to point out that in times of normal economic growth, concern for women's rights, particularly the disparity between the situation of men and women in the workplace, society and the family, is great, but these problems are deeply aggravated by the economic and social crisis we are experiencing.
Hence the need for a stronger strategic commitment by the Member States at the level of local and regional authorities and Community institutions with regard to the protection of the environment.

We must say that, in line with what President Daul and my colleague Werner Langen have said, it is essential that there is an economic government of the Union, but that this economic government is centred on the Commission.

This is the first point I wanted to make, and having said that, I should say that we should not just, as we did this morning, have our debate focused on the immediate issues, but on the immediate issues.
I would also like to emphasize, in particular, the issue of education and training of young people, the issue of innovation, research and development.

Because these are the niches that will allow Europe to be competitive in the global space, and today I must say that, unfortunately, the European educational model has failed, and it has failed when compared to the model of emerging countries.

Like India, China and Brazil, it is today a less demanding and less rigorous model, and that is why it is also asked that in the audacity of this idea of innovation, development, research and education there be rigor and demand in the context of European educational systems.
Only with this rigorous demand will we prepare our young people to compete in the global market.

We cannot just think about the crisis this year or in the next two or three years, we have to think about the strategy for Europe in the next 10 to 20 years, and it depends on an educational system of rigor and demand.
Mr Commissioner, never before has the European project, built with so much effort in the last 50 years, been so threatened.

The frustration of European citizens is enormous, the financial system that was supposed to serve them has destroyed their savings, their pensions, their investment projects, their jobs, in short, their future.
As regards the necessary strengthening of the entire market for financial services, banks, insurance and real estate, the way forward is clear and lies in the architecture we discussed here today.
We need, in fact, a strong European supervision architecture covering all products and actors, equipped with methodologies and instruments.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?

The risk cannot and should not be eliminated from the financial market, but we need regulation that makes this risk more transparent and that avoids the accumulation of bubbles whose explosion affects the whole system and weighs on the real economy.

But if, despite these defences, new crises occur in the future, it is crucial to have mechanisms to limit the contagion, especially with regard to the banking system, because it is vital for the functioning of the economy and the depository of citizens' savings.

It is precisely in the powers and competences of the banking authority that lies the ability to implement a new strategy for managing cross-border crises in the banking sector, which is the subject of my report.
It is not in our hands to prevent the bankruptcy of banks, but to ensure that their reorganization or eventual liquidation is done in a timely manner.
orderly, limiting the side effects in the rest of the system and, above all, preventing the taxpayer from paying the costs of the crises they generate.

To this end, a set of new devices is needed, and rules, definitions, methodologies, instruments and terminology common to all those involved in restructuring, reorganisation or liquidation operations need to be adopted.
It is necessary to harmonise the relevant national legal frameworks for crisis management, namely the bankruptcy and liquidation laws.
It is necessary to grant extended powers of intervention to supervisors.
It is necessary to draw up clear criteria, not only quantitative but also qualitative, which allow interventions to be initiated in a difficult institution.
We need to prepare contingency plans.
This whole process for 27 Member States takes time.
Meanwhile, about 50 of the 12 banks operating in Europe account for 70 of the assets.
Now, this means a huge concentration of risk, but also an opportunity to prioritize them.

There are therefore conditions for us to propose a special and urgent process of confronting banks, which, being cross-border in their size, relations with other banks have a possible systemic impact on the financial system.
Now, for these banks, it is possible to anticipate special supervision by the new European Banking Authority, although operating in the College of National Supervisors.
It is possible and urgent that they, depending on the risk they generate, begin to make contributions to a fund that finances any interventions.
It is important that the banking authority creates a specialised unit to coordinate interventions in the event of difficulties in these banks.

Mr President, Commissioner, I would also like to begin by thanking the rapporteurs for this excellent work.

Deforestation, as we know, is one of the main environmental and social problems on the planet, and every year we lose 13 million hectares of forest, thus contributing to 20 of the world's carbon emissions and constituting a huge threat to biodiversity.

The contribution of deforestation to climate change is undeniable and, as such, is very responsible for the occurrence of extreme and disastrous climate events or even for the desertification of vast areas of the planet.
The loss of biodiversity puts all of humanity at risk, but that risk and that impact are not shared equally by all of us.
The communities with the fewest resources and the communities most dependent on forests and nature for survival are the most affected.
Deforestation disrespects our cohesive existence, the scarcity of natural resources, their distribution, the rights of local communities and indigenous peoples, social justice.
The main cause of deforestation is illegal logging, which accounts for 20 to 40 percent of the world's industrial timber production.
So we are also talking about the transfer of wealth from the producing countries to the consuming countries in the same way.
This illegal practice puts the sustainable exploitation of wood and the companies that make it at risk.
Beautiful words are not enough.
This Parliament must take strong and consistent action in this fight.
This report takes a very significant step in this direction by defining the ban on the timber trade.
Good intentions are not enough either.
Effective means are needed, namely sanctions, which in this case can be of three types.

Mr President, Commissioner, a Europe without economic, social and territorial cohesion is not a Union.

to be repaid.

It reduced dependence, it increased equality and it created jobs.

It is therefore very important to use complementary data, in particular those which reflect the social and economic reality of these regions.
I cannot fail to make a special reference here to the peoples of the Azores, Madeira, the mountainous areas and the depopulated areas of the Portuguese interior.
With their efforts, they contribute greatly to the development and quality of life of all Europeans.
These and all regions have their own context.
Social, economic and territorial cohesion should not be seen as a charitable service.
This is where it is defined whether or not we want a genuine European redistribution policy.
I therefore regard this resolution as an important but first step.

Mr President, Commissioner, the objective of territorial cohesion, now enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon, embodies the value of European solidarity and the commitment of the Member States and the Union to reducing existing disparities between the various regions.
However, it is not enough to express in the text of the Treaties the objectives to be achieved.
There are regions of the Union which have permanent constraints which strongly condition their economic and social development.

It is therefore necessary to put in place specific programmes to effectively and effectively overcome the backlog in these regions by promoting an adaptation of their development model to their potential and resources and to contribute to achieving the objectives of the EU 2020 strategy.

This incentive to these regions should result not only from the means of regional policy, through its structural adjustment instruments such as the Cohesion Fund and the four Structural Funds, but also from the European Union.
It also calls for a different use of the various sectoral policies, which have a relevant territorial impact in each region and can therefore have a dynamic effect on their economies.
In order to determine European assistance to these regions, it is certain that we will have to keep GDP as the main indicator of eligibility.

However, and taking into account its natural disadvantages, it is appropriate to resort to other measurable criteria capable of providing a more realistic framework of its level of development, such as the unemployment rate, population density or the level of education.
Only then will it be possible to have a more complete picture of the complex reality of the most disadvantaged regions.

It is worth recalling the case of the outermost regions, whose status is recognised by the New Treaty and which are a group of regions of the European Union with specific characteristics and also deserve special treatment.
The outermost regions, united by their particular characteristics, also differ in their levels of development.

In relation to these, complementary GDP indicators should also be used, capable of providing a more complete description of their specific reality and thus contributing to a more accurate determination of their level of development.
I welcome this motion for a resolution, which calls for the need for a European strategy which makes it possible to translate the principle of cohesion into a European strategy.

The territorial integrity gains with the Treaty of Lisbon opportunities for the populations of the territories suffering from various permanent natural constraints to participate in the European project.

I come from an area, the Azores, where these constraints are accumulating and intensifying, as in other regions called outermost regions of Europe, in accordance with Article 349 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.
Following the Commission's communication on the outermost regions, a triumph for Europe in 2008 and after the extensive debate in which the RUP itself participated,
Relatively speaking, we are also now waiting for our version of this strategy, which will have to take into account not only our constraints but above all our potential.
I therefore appeal to the Commission to be sober in its presentation so that we can establish the best strategy before the debate on the new perspectives.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?

Mr President, Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, after four consecutive years of reducing the unemployment rate from 2004 to 2008, the current economic crisis has nullified much of the progress made.
Unemployment rates in the European Union have suffered a huge increase, for example in Portugal we reached the record value, unfortunately, of an unemployment rate of 11%.
Another negative phenomenon is youth unemployment in the European Union.
Europe is thus going through a period of transformation and is facing enormous challenges.
The crisis has nullified years of economic and social progress and exposed the fragility of the economies of its Member States and, consequently, of the European Union itself.
The 2020 strategy points the way.
The European Union must step up all its efforts to promote employment and social inclusion as an integral part of its strategy to combat the economic and social crisis.
The motion for a resolution on the future of the Social Fund, which is being debated today, is thus welcomed, as it plays a crucial role in achieving the objectives of the 2020 strategy.

In fact, this fund is the main financial instrument that allows the European Union to realise the strategic objectives of its employment policy by improving the levels of education and qualifications of its citizens.
The ESF should be strengthened as the main engine of the 2020 strategy and should be used by Member States to invest in skills, employment, training and vocational retraining.

Finally, I would like to point out that the reform of the European Social Fund, to be carried out in conjunction with the reform of the other Structural Funds, should facilitate and simplify its management and
strengthen transparency, as well as focus funds on achieving results and on the implementation of objectives that are effectively felt by citizens in their daily lives.

A global approach to the issues to be resolved is fundamental, i.e. a global vision for local action.

This is largely due to the employment prospectus strategy, which defines the factors to be acted on, how to achieve the desired outcome, and also the use of the European Fund for Strategic Investments as an operational instrument of this strategy, acting on education, training and the promotion of employment.
The Eurasian Union's cohesion policy is a unique way of ensuring the strategic integrity of the euro area.
Cohesion policy is the great pillar of European solidarity.
It is through cohesion that the objective of reducing disparities between regions is achieved and that the harmonious development of the European Union as a whole is encouraged.
In the next period, 2014 to 2020, we must define a framework capable of strengthening the effectiveness of regional policy.

Governance at all levels should be encouraged, with greater involvement and participation of regional and local entities, in respect of the principle of subsidiarity and as provided for in the new Treaty of Lisbon.
The special situation of the outermost regions must not be forgotten.
This set of regions faces very important challenges and should continue to benefit in the future from specific provisions in the implementation of European policies.
GDP should continue to be the main eligibility criterion, but we must take into account other indicators that can provide a more complete picture of regional reality.

Industrial accidents can and should be avoided, and that is also why European legislation exists and it seems obvious that the law has been violated.

It's like we're starting from scratch.

Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Commissioner Barnier on the presentation of this important document.

That is why we warmly welcome this communication, which represents a new ambition for single market policies, allowing us to regain confidence in our model of social market economy.

I would even say that I would have no problem in subscribing to it personally, but let us agree that it is contrary to what has been the practice in the Member States, with the cuts and the austerity measures.

I think that only sustainable innovation, if there are rigorous, sustainable and demanding public policies, if it is not a fire that is extinguished, little remains and little response we have to give to these populations.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we welcome the Commission's efforts to put research and innovation at the top of the political agenda.
We are working on an integrated strategy to make the European innovation ecosystem more effective and profitable in the service of a sustainable economy.
The European Innovation Partnerships emerge as an instrument and the major challenges they organise are sufficiently large to avoid controversy.
However, it is not yet clear how sub-thematic priorities will be defined and how the preponderance of each discipline within them will be defined.
What degree of transparency will be expected for stakeholders to participate, how to arbitrate conflicting interests?
What is the relative role of the Commission, the Member States and the regions?
How do we ensure accountability within a complex structure?
What financial dimension will these partnerships have?
The Commission and the Council, Mr President, must ensure excellence in implementation, which is not guaranteed with the few months of pilot testing planned for the first partnership.

workers who are required to access the market, which is more elementary justice, and on the other hand that they are compensated in the exact measure of the damage caused to them.

Or if not, at least have the decency to tell them frankly that they will have to change their lives and look for another job, because it is true that under the conditions that are expected in the future they will not be able to survive and will have to abandon the activity.

We are discussing a very important program
It is a concrete step to help economic recovery and, in this case, in the central domain, which is the energy domain.

We have focused too much on what are the big projects, on what are the big networks, and we have forgotten other intervention channels where it is absolutely essential to intervene.

And that is why I think that this report can help us to invest not only in energy efficiency and renewable energy, which is very important, but also to bring concrete benefits to the local populations, which naturally translates into concrete benefits for the European population as a whole.

That is why I would like to conclude, Mr President, with two final remarks. It is important that we never forget that energy efficiency is also achieved through energy reduction and micro-energy projects.

The life of a worker bee is very short, about six weeks, and it is very sensitive to the attractions of the outer sea.

Mr President, let us be clear: the solidarity mechanism for sovereign debt has not worked, nor does it work.
The process that was created, was created late, is intergovernmental and should have existed in a different format since the beginning of the creation of the euro.
The President of the Commission is now proposing to us a consolidation of this system.
But in the third of the instruments that are proposed to be used, they suggest the involvement of the private sector.
We had already heard this proposal from Chancellor Merkel and it was as a result of this early and inopportune announcement that the markets exploded.
Parliament will make full use of its powers and with the utmost responsibility and spirit of cooperation in the codecision process accompanying the package.
But it will not do so by sacrificing speed, speed, putting quality second.

So let us be clear, Parliament will participate actively, but a matter as serious as the solution of sovereign debt cannot be decided at the expense and at the expense of European citizens and their representatives.
Finally, we Europeans need a clear European vision at this time of crisis.

A European mechanism for the consolidation of sovereign debt is needed, a Eurobond issue is needed and the euro area needs to be sustainably protected through European and non-intergovernmental systems.

We need to strengthen the European budget, we cannot continue with 1 of the level of the European budget, and we need to put real growth and convergence at the centre of European political priorities.
This is the agenda that the Commission and the new President must defend.
And the President of the Commission cannot be an emanation of the Ecofin Council.
This is what we need to present to the citizens of Europe.

Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, I naturally wanted to say that the position of the EPP is clear, it is a position in the sense that it is a position that is not a position.
The solution to this crisis, this serious crisis that Europe and the European Union are experiencing, can only be achieved by deepening economic governance and the Community method.

For us there is no doubt that only with more Community method, only with economic governance, only with the proper instruments of a true single currency in the euro area space is it possible to tackle and attack this crisis.
But this means that each of the institutions, the Council, the Commission and Parliament, must assume its responsibilities before the Europeans.
It must be made clear here that at least the largest groups in the European Parliament are willing to cooperate in a clear way in order to increase
the Community method of introducing economic governance, of giving the single currency the conditions necessary for it to triumph in the face of the European crisis.

And it is also clear today that the same is happening with the Commission and the President of the Commission, who, contrary to what the Socialists and Mrs Elisa Ferreira say, have shown that it is not an emanation of the Council or Parliament, but an emanation of European interest.
It is now up to the Council to assume its responsibilities in December.
That is what we expect and that is your clear adherence to the European ideal, President Van der Rohe.
Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Luan and Mr Manescu on the remarkable work they have done in their respective reports.
Both constitute an important contribution to the ongoing discussion on the new cohesion policy for the 2014 horizon.
Today, more than ever, the achievement of economic, social and territorial cohesion is essential for the affirmation of the competitiveness of the European Union on a global scale.
This goal will only be achieved if we are aware that only by strengthening and developing the regional dimension can we have a cohesive Europe within it and competitive Europe outside it.

In this particular case, I would like to highlight three points which I consider to be crucial: firstly, decentralisation, which ensures that local and regional authorities, especially those with legislative powers, participate more and contribute to a better implementation of cohesion policy.

Member States to invite regional and local authorities to participate in negotiations on the future of the Structural Funds on an equal footing with national authorities and representatives and, finally, to strengthen the role of regional authorities in the preparation, management and implementation of the programmes.
Only in this way, with the greater involvement of these authorities in the whole process, will the principle of subsidiarity be fulfilled.

Another aspect which I consider crucial is the request for a simpler architecture for the post-2013 funds, not as a consequence of the economic crisis, but as a general principle of the future cohesion policy in order to facilitate the absorption of funds.
The great concern underlying the Treaty of Lisbon was to bring Europe closer to its citizens.
Let us then not only do this, but also make your life easier, avoiding unnecessary administrative burdens that are discouraging your participation.
Only in this way will we be able to achieve the objective of genuine territorial cohesion.
Only then will we see the disparities within the European Union, which today are markedly contrasting and with a huge gap between rich and poor regions, reduced.

More participation also means more responsibility, and it is this responsibility that must be taken up and shared by all, doing more and better in order to have a stronger and more competitive Europe.
Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by congratulating my colleagues Edith Bauer and Anne Heth on the excellent work they have done on this report.
Trafficking in human beings dishonors our society and requires a strong and coordinated response from all.
Organized crime, which is behind sexual exploitation, forced labour, the trade in human organs and other despicable practices, must be effectively combated, but must primarily be prevented.
What is at stake is the defence of human rights and the protection of the most vulnerable, namely women and children.
Experience has shown that the legal framework in place was not effective enough and that the European Union needs to do more.
Greater cross-border cooperation, including effective sharing of information and good practice, is essential.
This proposal highlights, and indeed a victim-centered approach.
Policies in this area should include aspects related to social issues and social inclusion, such as the social rehabilitation of the victim.
Mr President, the NATO summit took place in Lisbon and so let me say a few words about what happened in my country on the occasion of this summit.
At that time, the Portuguese authorities banned European citizens from entering the country, and only for one reason: these citizens brought with them critical texts of the alliance.
In those days, the least we can say is that there was an arbitrary regime in Portugal, a genuine police of thought.
A regime so special that it led the Portuguese Government to buy anti-mob material worth five million euros and that it did not even arrive in time for the summit.
And these are the priorities, after all, of a government that is facing a huge social crisis.
In the Europe we dream of, freedom of expression is a fundamental value.
The Europe we dream of does not stand up to military organizations that write their history in blood.
From the NATO summit came the legitimacy of its military intervention on the entire planet.
The European Union's subordination to the military strategy and to North American interests also emerged.
Thirdly, the militarisation of access to energy sources has been consolidated.
Finally, the military defence of the development model that generates environmental imbalances and disrupts the social crisis was instituted.
That is why I want to say, Madam President, that in my view, with this summit we are losing in democracy, we are losing in freedom and we are losing so that some people win with war.
Madam President, the first point I wanted to make clear here and which is important to strengthen in this Parliament is that we have to be very careful about the way we use the budget.
Contrary to what sometimes seems to be read in the press and in the statements of some European leaders, the euro as a currency was fundamental to responding to the current crisis.

Without the euro, we would be in a very difficult situation, with the currencies of the most fragile countries in a huge devaluation and with a possible German framework in an impossible devaluation to withstand the German economy and the European economy.
And so the euro was a factor of stability, especially not only for the countries that are in the euro area, but also for the currencies of the countries that did not want to join the euro area.

And that is why we must defend this community, which has managed to respond to the crisis with nothing, and as we will see in the future, for example, what will happen to the dollar and the United States of America, we will see how the euro actually has advantages.

We now have a responsibility in this Council to do everything to defend the euro, to create a stabilisation fund, in particular, which follows the Community method and is capable of introducing responsibility in the Member States.

There are countries that are in a more fragile, fragile and solidarity situation than those that have fulfilled their obligations and have not always shown themselves, at least by their external statements, available to be in solidarity in the context of the EEA.

I would like to extend my sincere congratulations to Mrs Sorbu on the excellence of the report produced, and I strongly advise the Commission to take this into account, especially in those aspects where the complexity of agricultural issues far exceeds the strictness of the report.

They call for the involvement of other areas, such as competition, the internal market and financial regulation, as well as others, and they also call for their treatment in other non-Community fora, such as the G20 or the WTO.

The absolutely crucial issues for agriculture, for farmers and for the availability of sufficient quantity and quality of food to the populations of Europe and the world can only be dealt with if they are dealt with in all these dimensions.

The ambitious objectives of the CAP reform can only be achieved if the reform goes beyond the strict boundaries of agriculture and its objectives are also taken into account in the necessary interventions in other policy areas and in other global bodies.
This report leaves me with a blank and I salute it.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking all the words that have been left here in relation to the report that Parliament is presenting on Alzheimer's and other dementias.
We all know that the situation we are living in is substantially dramatic and that it is still very underdiagnosed, as has been mentioned here.
And I just want to refer to a question that was transversal to all the interventions, but probably not so emphasized, which is the question of the dignity of patients, of their rights.
And not just from patients, but also from their families and those who care for them, whether formal or informal caregivers, and from professionals who are associated with this type of disease.

I am pleased, frankly pleased, with the Commissioner's words when he says that he shares the same concerns as the European Parliament and that the European Commission sees very positively all the recommendations in the report which Parliament is presenting and that it will do everything in its power to put them into practice.
We know that every day that passes is later than the previous one in this matter, given the urgency of what we have on our hands.
And so we also know that tomorrow Parliament will take a decision on this matter.
We will wait for the outcome of the vote, but we know, Commissioner, that the citizens of Europe expect much more from us than solidarity and moral comfort.

They expect us to take concrete and appropriate action, and I hope, Commissioner, that you will then put it into practice and that the Commission, which has the initiative - which unfortunately this Parliament does not have - will put it into practice.

All this priority that you give to this domain and that you transform into a legislative initiative so that citizens and their families are respected, their rights are respected and they are treated with the equality and dignity that they deserve.

First of all, I would like to say that this Parliament, on the day we are discussing the Hungarian Presidency, without prejudice to being able to deal with all the issues it intends, should concentrate on the problems of the European Union, which is not what it is doing here.
To concentrate on the problems of the European Union, I should read carefully and discuss here whether or not it agrees with the priorities of the Hungarian Presidency, instead of discussing points
or aspects of Hungary's internal life that can, if necessary, be regulated in a healthy and normal relationship between the European Commission and the Hungarian Parliament.
