The Hungarian agenda for this semester is very clear and very ambitious, with focus and priority on three issues that will be essential for the future of Europe.

Food, which is about to enter a serious global crisis, energy, which is essential for our security and for our economic sustainability, and water, which little has been said about, but which will be the next challenge for Europeans.
I wish you to achieve your goals.

Madam President, I think that these two countries, like others in this region, show us how in recent years European leaders have often been more on the side of business than on the side of democracy, more on the side of dictators than on the side of the poor.
I am frankly concerned about the situation in Egypt today and the developments today, and that is why I understand that it is not calm that we should have, but solidarity.
Solidarity with the millions of Egyptian citizens who are in Cairo and across the country, fed up with hunger, fed up with oppression, fed up with unemployment.

And that is why, after today's speech by Mubarak, after the regime's dogs have been released, after an open and clean path to violence has been created, we must say that we must stand by these people.
We cannot allow a strategy of fear to be created for them to return home.
Thirty-six years ago in Portugal, we would have gone home if we had listened to these advice.
It's a good thing we're back, because that's how we had the democratic revolution.
Mr President, Commissioner, I would also like to say that I think this issue is too important for us to continue to live in the deception that we have lived in Europe.
A deception is a false promise, as you may call it, because we have been operating mainly in the matter of collecting terminal cells in the umbilical cords from databases that are misleading.
We know, and it has already been mentioned, that in Europe the collection of terminal cells through the umbilical cord does not reach

However, we also know that their possibilities for treating diseases can be inexhaustible, diseases such as those already referred to cancer, such as Alzheimer's disease, rare diseases, are immense possibilities.

But what we let happen was that a set of private cell-preservation banks were set up, telling parents that they could keep their children's cells and from then on, at the time of birth, and from then on, heal them in the future, if necessary.
I think we should be more responsible than that, because the probability of that happening is very low, as we know.
And this false promise that is sold to the parents costs money.
In Portugal, for example, this false promise costs three and a half minimum wages.
The solution is clearly to create public banks, terminals, because only with public banks can we ensure equal use, equal access.
and effective medical treatment and more research that is equal for all and not just using stem cells as a commodity or a business that is growing but that is only for a few.
That is why I think that solidarity, common sense and impartial information are not, after all, things that can be classified as more demanding.
We don't have the power to impose, we have the power to promote.
This is within our competence, and I think we should do it in the name of equality.
Mr President, the price of food has reached its all-time high and is rising for the seventh time in a row.
There are several factors that can explain this increase, the first being a short-term factor.
This has to do with the coincidence of bad weather conditions in some countries, such as Russia and Argentina.
But there are two factors that are structuring, they are of structuring order and that is why I bring these two factors here.
The first has to do with the fact that some food producers and consumers who were exporters become importers, as is the case in China.
The second has to do with the fact that the weight of some large multinationals managed to get prices to be judged in their favor.
The example of cereals is very clear at this level, it is dominated by six large multinationals.
This situation therefore puts farmers in a huge uncertainty about the prices of food products.
Europe must therefore do what it has stopped doing for some time, namely protect its producers and consumers.
In a world where everyone turns to forms of protection and where multinationals manipulate prices, we cannot continue to be naive.
I would like to thank my colleague Marisa Matias and all those who collaborated with her.
Unfortunately, over the past few years we have seen an increase in counterfeiting of medicines in Europe.
According to data from the European Union, 1.5 million boxes of counterfeit medicines are sold annually through the legal supply chain.
This is a criminal activity which poses a serious threat to European patients and to European industry.
The objective of this Directive is to prevent the introduction of counterfeit medicines into the supply chain and thus to protect public health.

I would like to highlight in the paper I have drawn up the following key points: the introduction of the definition of counterfeit medicinal products, clearly placing the tonic in consumer protection, the application of the

the safety of medicines subject to medical prescription, the accountability of all those involved in the distribution chain and, finally, the application by Member States of effective sanctions to deter this criminal activity.
Mr President, I obviously want to thank all the comments that have been made by all the colleagues.
I'm not going to comment on it. That's not what it's about.
I think if there were any doubts about what the word "commitment" means, it became very clear here what "commitment" means.

We don't all have the perfect proposal, but much more important to know if it's the perfect proposal is to know that we have an instrument in our hands that will allow us not to postpone the protection of patients' health any longer.
And we have an obligation not to postpone its adaptation either, we have an obligation not to postpone real action and we can only do this together.
I must also say personally and the Commissioner referred to the question of inspections that I, in my initial proposal, tabled an amendment for compulsory inspections in third countries.
Commitment is that, and yet you gain from some things, you lose from others.
We were explained by the Commission that this would be impossible to obtain.
I would like to leave another note in relation to this commitment.
I think we all see each other again in the commitment, but I also think and I am aware that we will all be demanding that it be fulfilled, because otherwise it will not be effective.

In this commitment safeguards are guaranteed so that we can monitor the process, evaluate and have systematic information that allows us to verify whether it is being implemented or not, properly or not and whether changes need to be made.

I would therefore like to conclude by thanking the European Commission for its cooperation and, in particular, the Spanish Presidency and the Belgian Presidency, which have been working together for the last six months.
There are no perfect proposals, there are no perfect interventions, there are failures, but I think we have a strong and robust commitment to enabling us to fight and defend the health of patients.
And since my speech is also full of flaws, I failed to thank my colleagues Regina Bastos and Amália Sartori, the partners of the other committees.
Thank you for your support.
Mr President, Commissioner, it is not worth repeating that the present moment is the most serious test for the survival of the euro and therefore of Europe.
The Polimata report opens up constructive solutions and that is why I also want to congratulate our colleague on the ideas she has put forward.

The gravity of the moment is not the fact that the euro area as a whole has an excessive deficit or external debt, but rather the fact that the economies that make it up diverge persistently and severely under the impact of the common policy.
And we lack the instruments to allow convergence between these economies, to allow Europe to regain its balance, to allow Europe to grow.

Let us be clear that the euro area and the European Union do not survive with the current degree of integration and the diversity of the economies that make it up, with a budget of 1 of collective wealth.
In practice, after the crisis, the only solution we were able to build was the austerity revenue, and it is the workers and companies who are paying today.
the deficits generated by the speculative crisis in the financial sector, in the rescue of which 26% of the wealth of the European Union has been committed.
The financial transaction tax, with a very low rate, for example, of 0.05 on transactions in highly speculative high-risk products, is true that it will have to be paid by its consumers.
But why shouldn't they pay if ordinary citizens pay a VAT on bread, on milk and on the most basic products?
The tax burden must be redistributed in such a way as to harm fewer workers and companies and to be shared more equitably by the financial sectors, in particular speculators.
And, Commissioner, I do not think it is for the Commission at the moment to refuse or run away from the clear message that this Parliament is giving it politically.
The public consultation cannot exclude the analysis of the tax on financial transactions, on the contrary, it should be analysed with the highest priority.
We know what happened to the flu and it should be a lesson to all of us.
I don't know if you remember how this all started, but the truth is that it started in a way and then the answer was completely disproportionate to the size of the problem.
That is why the report which was voted on here today is so important, because we must learn from what has been done so that what has been done is not repeated.
We have the right to know who made the decisions, how the whole thing happened and who decided it should have happened that way.
We have a right to know which countries responded in a certain way, why they responded without transparency and without letting us stay.
We have to have the guarantee that no risk is left if there is a business related to this flu.
That is why I understand, Madam President, that all threats to public health must be dealt with, but it does not matter how they are dealt with or who pays for them.
Mr President, Commissioner, we are here to talk about proposals on wages and proposals on the age of reform, and the least we can say about these proposals is that they are frankly unfair.
They are unfair and they insist on recipes that have already been proven for more than once, because they are failed recipes.

What's happening in Ireland, in Greece, in Portugal, in Spain, in Italy and you know how many other countries because this is an endless cadence, there are different situations between each of these countries, but there are some things in common.
One of the things we have in common is an unprecedented transfer of the value of work to financial capital.
We couldn't accept that.
The other thing we have in common is that the people who are paying for this crisis are the workers and the reformers and the pensioners, and a whole generation of the poor is also paying for it.
There is no guarantee in this society in which we live, and that is why I would like to conclude, saying, Mr President and Commissioner, that we cannot continue to condemn people to poverty.
I hope so.
Mr President, I would like to begin by saying that I fully support what my colleague has said.

The prevention of natural and man-made disasters is of enormous importance and of growing importance, and the European Commission systematically presents us with a number of procedural and calendar intentions.
But there is a very complicated problem, as has already been mentioned.
The Solidarity Fund is an instrument which normally responds to these situations, but responds in a very, very long time, nine months to a year, and this after the catastrophe.
As has also been mentioned, and I repeat and we will repeat the exhaustion as long as it takes, in the case of the wood, a year ago it had a huge catastrophe and has not yet received any support.
I ask for this and I reinforce this question will the Commission not be able to review the procedure for the Fund itself and the financing model itself?
How can we maintain a reserve fund to deal with situations that are becoming more and more chronic?
We don't know where it's going to happen, but we know what's going to happen, and climate change is there to prove it.
So, except, you can never respond to a situation of regularity, thank you very much.

Mr President, the concerns raised here in the area of disaster prevention and response are matters of great sensitivity and of the utmost importance to our peoples, which should not and cannot be ignored.

We are talking about very sensitive situations that affect the safety of people and their property, which often excite everyone by the loss of lives, by the families destroyed, by the destruction of entire lives of work.

But all our demonstrations are of little use in the face of the dramas that, in a media way, impress everyone and make everyone aware, if we then fall asleep on the work we must do so that those situations can be avoided, minimized or, better, helped.
Commissioner, the subject here is very well focused by my colleagues.

It is a matter where the European Union can better demonstrate its presence with its citizens, helping them to prevent disasters, especially when they occur, and standing by them in times when they are most in need and most vulnerable.
I will respond with pleasure, although I do not want to turn a debate in the European Parliament into a debate on Portuguese policy.

If the Portuguese politician Edita Estrela wants to debate Portuguese politics, she has a simple solution: we must have elections, candidates for the Portuguese parliament and have the opportunity, in opposition, to debate with the PSD government the policies it intends for Portugal.
I say only this: we can no longer endure a government that has failed four times in two years.
It's impossible, it's unsustainable, it's not credible to the markets, there are no more solutions with the socialist government.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I begin by congratulating Mr Schwab on the negotiating perseverance which has led to this important commitment and I also congratulate all those who have collaborated with him on this report.

We want not only to ensure a high level of protection for European consumers, but also that European companies, whatever their size, can provide goods and services to consumers in the 27 Member States without unnecessary legal obstacles.

This new directive will put an end to the legislative fragmentation which has been detrimental to the participation of our companies in the cross-border market and will give an important boost to the internal market.
It highlights the new provisions on information to be provided to the consumer, requiring that this information be clear, understandable and timely.
It is also important that the burden of proof in relation to compliance with information requirements falls on the trader.
As for contracts concluded remotely, especially contracts concluded by telephone or Internet, their rules and the consumer protected by simple and effective mechanisms must be defined.
We are confident that, at the end of the institutional negotiations, the new directive will help to make the European Union more competitive and dynamic, as it is in a global economy.

Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, first of all I would naturally like to congratulate you on the results of the Council of 24 March, namely the consolidation of the European Semester.

But much more than that, whether it is because of the institutionalization of the European Stability Mechanism or because of the, let us say, the closure of the Europass pact, which had already come from the top of the euro area on 11 March.
I believe that these are very positive results for Europe and it is a pity that this process has not been fully concluded by 24 March.
I believe that if we had given this signal, if the States had given this signal in the Council, by completely closing this package of reform of the Fund, we would be in a position today.

We have to be stronger to face the next three or four months, and in part we would have to mitigate the effects of the crisis that my country, Portugal, is currently experiencing, and about which I also do not want to say a word.

to say that, in the case of the fully integrated EDP, there is an absolute and total availability for the fulfilment of those which are the requirements and obligations of integration into the European space.
That's what we've done, even now, at this time, when there are difficulties with short-term financing.
Unlike the Socialist Government, the Social Democratic Party has shown its full willingness to give Europe the guarantees it needs in the context of this crisis.

And with this I want to give this signal, without bringing the internal policy to the European Parliament, of the commitment, of the commitment, of the total guarantee of the Social Democratic Party in the rigorous agenda that the country will have to have after its elections on June 5th.
Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Stefan Füle, the historic moment we are experiencing calls for firm and determined action.
Like many of you, it is with a mixture of hope, concern and expectation that we witness the events unfolding in the Mediterranean basin.

However, I am satisfied with the proactive position that Parliament is preparing to adopt with regard to the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy, which I hope will lead to a greater presence of the Union in this area, not only as a payer but also as a committed partner.
"We are here to affirm the absolute need to defend our founding values in relations with neighbouring countries.
We can no longer compromise in defence of democracy, nor in defence of human rights, much less in defence of social justice.

We will no longer be able to give priority to short-term stability at the expense of the superior interests of citizens and their uncompromising defence of their individual and collective freedom, with particular attention to women's rights.
In the future, the Union must give priority to a bottom-up approach in its neighbourhood policy.
It is essential that this happens.
Only greater involvement of local communities and civil society will ensure maximum effectiveness in its implementation.

But I cannot help but express my frustration that this Parliament and the Commission do not want to take this opportunity to differentiate, in turn, the Eastern Neighbourhood policy from the countries which could potentially become our partners in the Union in the future, the Southern Neighbourhood policy.
I also challenge the Commission to demonstrate in its April 20 review process the ambition that the present moment calls for a neighbourhood policy.

The Commission's proposal is based on a tailor-made approach to each Member State, with clear benchmarks and a careful assessment that allows a future Mediterranean economic space with the new democracies of the South.

In conclusion, Commissioner, we hope that the good atmosphere and the cooperation that has characterised the work on this subject will lead to the permanent involvement of the European Parliament in the planning and evaluation of this policy.
Mr President, the reports we are debating and which I congratulate the rapporteurs on today reinforce a set of initiatives which aim to relaunch the internal market.

the Consumer Protection and Internal Market Commission to give priority to market competitiveness and dynamism, a fundamental pillar of the 2020 strategy.

the relevance of the development of e-commerce to strengthen consumer and business confidence in this type of trade, the commitment to innovation

I would also like to join my voice to all those who have expressed concern here about the low incomes of fishermen, aggravated by the historic prices of fuel, particularly in recent months.
As has been said here, fuel costs have a very high impact on the survival of our small and medium-sized shipping companies, aggravating in particular the already fragile yields of fishing.
This vestigial rise in prices is also bringing us deep negative effects: reduced sea outlets, miserable yields on the part of fishermen, aggravated by the low prices paid at the first sale.
Increases in imports from third countries of aquaculture and fishery products into the European market and a consequent abandonment of activity due to financial difficulties with more job losses.
In this context, in order to avoid the continuation of the worsening of the crisis, it is necessary to act and act quickly and deeply on the problems of fisheries.
The Commission must therefore respond positively, with short- and long-term measures, to meet the adversities facing the sector and the serious losses in yield that our fishermen are experiencing.
First of all, I would like to congratulate our colleague from the EPP, Mario David, who is here today because he is absolutely right.
I was not able to attend this plenary and I wanted to say that we have always considered that supporting the victims of floods in Pakistan was an ethical and moral imperative.
That is why we strongly support all the measures that have been taken in the direction of traditional humanitarian aid.
We even consider that work should continue in order to help stabilize the situation of the millions of people affected.
What we cannot accept is that the European Union's trade policy should now be seen as an instrument of its own and appropriate for humanitarian aid.

The truth is that this has two dire consequences, one within the European Union, especially for the countries of the South and their textile and clothing industry, which today is highly vulnerable to an economic, social and financial crisis unparalleled since the end of the Cold War.

And secondly, at the global level, in the WTO negotiations, where this opening up of the world's largest trading bloc, the European Union, to these possible Pakistani negotiations can completely unbalance the negotiations.
And it's not by chance that they find themselves in the impasse they are in.

It is therefore natural that in the face of such a situation we should have something to say about the history of this regulation and the difficulty it has had in these eight months of intense negotiations.

We are working together with the most constructive proposals that we will now have, unfortunately, to take a position which will be a position in the sense of supporting the amendment which, in the end, provides for the end of this proposal for a regulation as we know it.
We will have to do it now, not because of less solidarity with Pakistan, but because we believe that humanitarian aid should be given on the spot and in its own way.
Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to start by saying that, of course, I believe that the agreement reached for Portugal is a balanced agreement.
It is a very tough agreement for the populations, but it puts its fundamental point in structural reforms to increase growth and competitiveness.
And I swear, that's very positive.

I do not take the attitude of others here, who consider that countries like Greece, Ireland and Portugal have done everything right, have not made any mistakes, have not exaggerated, have done everything right, and it was only the international crisis that caused problems.

No, our governments have made mistakes and had wrong policies, but this does not mean that there is no opportunity now, in the context of the Union, to have the possibility of returning to the right path and the right path.

And that is why it is important to remember here that, in fact, it is necessary to tell public opinions that are against supporting countries in difficulty that they are not giving money to these countries, they are just lending money to these countries.
But they are lending them at very high interest rates and therefore they are doing a business that is positive for their budgets and for their populations.

But I also say here that perhaps it is time to have a global European response, with the admission of Eurobonds, with the admission of the possibility of selling on the primary market, to respond to international markets.

And it would perhaps be time for the European Commission itself, the Fund and the IMF to review interest rates, so as to give these rates a chance to see sustained growth in these countries which are in difficulty today.
Mr President, Commissioner and rapporteur, this strategy is important for all European countries, especially those whose economies lack more competitiveness.

The framework programme on innovation, with instruments aimed at small and mediumsized enterprises and entrepreneurship, of which the most successful is the Eurostar programme, which should be extended.

We know that this is not the case, and that is why I hope that there will be serious consequences and that we can tell our citizens that we are taking care of their safety and not just pretending that we are.
I expect this European Council, especially in view of the climate in which we are living in the last few weeks, to take a very responsible decision.
And more responsible than the one that existed in the last Council, in which it was sought to postpone a problem for three months, just because of electoral calendars.

I hope that this decision of responsibility will essentially make it clear that economic and financial issues are crucial and decisive for Europe, but that economic and financial issues are instrumental for what is Europe's main objective, which is to maintain peace.
If you make an approach to the problems, it only leads to the states starting to distrust each other, to instill distrust between the different states.
To create and foster differences and rivalries between the southern and northern states, between the central and peripheral states, what we have led to is the decline of the European Union.

I believe that what is at stake in this European Council, regardless of the technical solutions, regardless of the political disagreements, is to know whether we believe or not that the European project remains a valid project for the peace strategy in Europe.
That's what's causing it.
I note in many speeches of leaders, both those who are in countries in difficulty and those who are in countries that are paying.
It is an irresponsible speech, which often even appeals to some characteristics of nationalities that are extremely negative.
I therefore appeal, and only appeal, to the sense of responsibility of the leaders of the European governments to find solutions that lead Europe to a way out and a solution.

Madam President, Commissioner, my first words are to highlight the work done by the rapporteur, Mr Giorgio Stravakakis, who has done an extraordinary job in identifying future synergies for enhanced effectiveness between the various structural funds.

Your report also fits into this joint debate on cohesion policy, a debate which is of the utmost importance, not only because of the substance of the subject but also, above all, because of the timing of its discussion.
Indeed, we are currently in the process of approving the Commission's proposal, not only for the new financial perspectives but also for the future cohesion policy after 2013.
The policy of quotas is a fundamental policy for the European Union.

It is a horizontal policy which, through its instruments of excellence, the Structural Funds, finances projects and programmes in the Member States in order to reduce the disparity between the levels of development of the various regions.
Experience, however, has shown us the difficulties in terms of efficiency and results resulting from the fragmentation and complexity of this policy.

A single strategic framework for the various funds, with an integrated and results-oriented approach, is the starting point for more and better synergies between the various instruments and for strengthening their effectiveness.
It is also essential for better coordination between the various sectoral policies and for better efficiency in the application of resources.
We must seize the danger of crisis to find new alternatives.

It is true that all these reports that we are discussing here today will pose enormous challenges and that we know that in order to respond to these challenges we also need a good budget, but we have to make a clear distinction between what are the budgetary aspects and the political objectives.
The political objectives are well known and, in fact, I am saying that these political objectives are that we can offer a future to the regions.
And if that is the case, then we have to put the budget at the service of the future of the regions and the citizens, and not the citizens and the regions at the service of the budget.
Mr President, cohesion policy is the key policy for the future of the European project.
The construction of a common space with an internal market, a currency of its own, requires a certain level of convergence between its Member States and its regions in order to function.
The current divergences in competitiveness and asymmetries in development have inevitably led to the fragility of the European space and the crisis affecting the euro area.
That is why this vital need for convergence requires a powerful cohesion budget that cannot be weakened to finance other policies.
The European Union, in order to do more, must have more, and this is achieved by increasing its budget and not by reducing, albeit slightly, the cohesion budget.

I therefore ask the Commissioner whether the creation of the Fund for Infrastructure and the new innovation policies, which will be linked to cohesion and regional development, which I support, without an increase in the Community budget, will not be able to be transformed into the Trojan horse introduced into the cohesion budget.

The modernisation and renewal of the energy infrastructure are essential factors for the sustainable and smart growth objectives we seek with the 2020 strategy and for our energy security that we need.
It is essential to involve all regions in this challenge.

To this end, the incentives provided for in the regulatory systems should be improved, in particular those applicable to more risky and more innovative projects, such as those being developed in the Azores in renewable energy.

The regions should be associated with the phases of granting and implementing the projects, in the definition of the priorities, in their elaboration and execution, because this guarantees better results and, hence, a better defence of the European interest.
The current economic momentum further emphasises the need to adopt an innovative and integrated approach to energy issues, taking into account all economic, environmental and social aspects.
It is essential not to lose sight of its medium and long-term effects, seeking to ensure that all European citizens have safe, sustainable and affordable energy.

Mr President, the report we are debating is of particular importance in view of the influence that social services of general interest have on the daily lives of European citizens, as well as on social cohesion, job creation and economic growth.

The collaboration with the rapporteur, Mr Próncias de Rossa, was very useful and clarifying, as the rapporteur himself has just said, allowing the adoption of several commitments in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs.
For the result we have here today and for the debate we have had, I congratulate and congratulate the rapporteur.
In fact, our main concern was to make it clear that the powers in this area are vested in the Member States.
National authorities are the holders of the powers to define, organise and finance social services of general interest.
It is therefore unnecessary to create harmonising legislation at European level, since the realities of these social services of general interest in the 27 Member States are very different.

It is enough to look at health, social security, employment and social housing services, which are examples where proximity and knowledge of the contexts are the cornerstone for the adequate and fairer provision of these services.

Mr President, as rapporteur for the REGI opinion on the future of international social services, I would like to congratulate Mr De Rossa on the fact that we are facing an essential pillar of the model of the social market economy which we defend for Europe and in which the SIG plays a fundamental role in its cohesion.

Social cohesion at European Union level is advised not to disregard the existence of minimum levels of protection in all Member States, without prejudice to the competence of their national, regional and local authorities.

European regions play a very important role in the provision of these services to the populations and their opinion must be taken into account, given the nature of their constraints, in order to guarantee the populations their provision.

At a time of crisis such as the one we are now experiencing, international social services constitute a social protection network for the most disadvantaged or for those whose incomes do not allow them access to private services.

It is therefore important to ensure that Member States that decentralize powers make them accompanied by their respective financial means so that regional and local authorities can ensure their good performance to the populations.

NATO and the United Nations have overridden all resolutions, even those voted by the United Nations Security Council.
It is this silence in relation to Libya, this repudiation that we must make, and it is because it is not in this resolution that I cannot subscribe to it.

Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur and all those who have contributed to this work.
There is no doubt that this report constitutes and will constitute a reference in terms of solid and coordinated recommendations and responses to the challenges of the crisis.
If there is a conclusion to be drawn, it is that the crisis we are experiencing will only be overcome by deepening European integration.

In a time of serious financial, economic and social difficulties and painful austerity measures in some Member States, such as my own country, Portugal, it is tempting to take refuge in a protectionist and nationalist attitude.
But I know one thing.

The European response to the crisis is to have a genuine European economic government that pursues sustainable growth, promotes job creation and develops the social market economy, with long-term responses with defined objectives with which the Member States identify.
The crisis exit strategy needs to be financed with a sufficiently ambitious Community budget.

In order to avoid a new crisis of sovereign debt and the euro, closer coordination of budgetary policies is needed, as well as the creation of a system for issuing bonds of public debt and euro bonds.
I conclude by stressing that in this difficult period it is also necessary to maintain levels of social protection, especially for the most vulnerable citizens.
Madam President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, it is common to say that crises help to strengthen Europe.
Historically, it was, but today I'm not so sure that this is still true.

The slow, improvised, reactive way in which the Union is reacting to the Greek crisis is worsening the situation every day and adds to the distrust and lack of confidence in the Union and its currency in a frightening way.
This, despite the problems in the euro area, resulted from obvious failures in the construction of the single currency, which today focuses on its most fragile links.

In order for the current crisis to result in the strengthening of the Union, a strategic vision is needed, as there has been in the past, and which unfortunately neither the Commission nor the Council have been able to impress on the European programme and project.
However, this Parliament's report gives us this view: more Europe, and no less, is the solution.
Parliament recalls that the single market and the single currency generate unbearable divergences between economies and must be counteracted by specific policies.

It recognises that the functioning of the euro requires a European budget reinforced by its own resources, it requires a European debt solidarity agency capable of protecting States from market speculation and
It also recognises that diplomas and the transferability of workers between countries require mutual recognition of social rights and pensions.
Parliament has united to send clear messages, let us hope that the Commission and the Council will listen to them.

The first question I wanted to say is that in the crisis that we are in, in the economic and financial crisis, the question of smart regulation, smart regulation, better legislation is a central question.

There is no doubt that in the so-called structural reforms, which can make the economic and financial start of the European space, improvement at the level of legislation and regulation is also absolutely essential.

It is clear that a Europe that aims, on the one hand, to be dynamic and competitive, must have simple regulation and be accessible to businesses and, of course, to citizens, and therefore must be oriented to their needs.
The truth is that in this sense it is essential today that, first of all, the programme of reducing administrative burdens be achieved, that all efforts be made in the direction of
We must promote consultations with market agents, representative associations of citizens and companies, and we must assess the impact of our own legislation, which is also extremely important.

The decision-making process can essentially be based, let's say, on the opinion of those who are the beneficiaries of the legislation and can be done without administrative tasks and with less economic and financial costs.

It is important to say that, for the Committee on Constitutional Affairs in particular, the idea of the principle of proportionality and subsidiarity is relevant, the idea that European intervention should be an adequate intervention and not an intervention that promotes the complexity of the system.

And that is why we pay particular attention, in our view, to the strengthened role that national parliaments play in this dynamic, precisely because of the principle of proportionality and the principle of subsidiarity.

It is therefore essential that, also at the level of smart regulation and at the level of improving legislation, we now involve national parliaments so that, at both European and national level, legislation and regulation are in place.

Let them be more agile, more intelligent, more efficient, and therefore this is a good time to put into practice what we announce every day, which is a more competitive Europe and a more agile Europe through more intelligent reasoning.
Mr President, the number of homeless people, as well as those living below the poverty line, has been increasing in recent years in several Member States.
The economic, financial and social crisis and the increase in unemployment have exacerbated this problem, as everyone has already diagnosed.
We also all agree that this phenomenon is a denial of important values of the European Union, respect for human dignity and respect for fundamental rights.
In my country, for example, which is subject to a strong measure of austerity, the concept of homelessness, according to the national plan, includes people who will ask for help to take a meal.
The number of people seeking food aid has increased by more than 20 percent since 2008.
There is a greater increase in needy families and people who have seen their living conditions altered by unemployment and also by bank debt.
This is just one example of the seriousness of the situation.
Last year, the European Parliament adopted a written declaration on a European Union strategy for the homeless.

With this declaration, this Parliament warned of the need for the European Union to have a strategy supported by national and regional strategies with the long-term objective of ending the situations of people sleeping on the streets and the long-term homelessness.
National strategies should focus on preventive measures, but also on concrete actions to improve the quality of services provided to the homeless and the availability of affordable accommodation.
It is also clear that this European strategy must be compatible with the social housing policy of the Member States.

How does Europe live so well with this double criterion?
We are so quick to repatriate and so slow to help, Commissioner.
It can't go on.

Mr President, I would naturally like to congratulate you on this supplement of hope which you have given to all the Members of the European Parliament and, in particular, to the citizens of the European Union whom we represent here.
Having said that, I wanted to say that we now expect the Commission to take a very, very determined action with the Council so that this sovereign debt crisis can be resolved in the short term.
We know it's a marathon, but we need immediate signals.

And so, without prejudice to the fact that we have all already begun to think of an amendment to the Treaties which gives political translation to the whole project that we have brought here today, without prejudice to this, something must be done already.

This set of measures and perhaps an agreement between the States, what I have called a kind of parasocial agreement, which goes beyond the Treaties and which can, from this moment on, put all these ideas into action.
Congratulations on your courage and determination.
I think we're on the right track and we're leaving today with another detective.

Mr President, the crisis facing the European Union has had serious consequences in all the Member States and thousands of workers are affected by the displacements caused by globalisation and the crisis.
We cannot fail to express our solidarity with these workers who have lost their jobs and to say that Europe must help the Member States to maintain an employment rate and to combat unemployment.
A rapid reintegration of workers into the labour market is a priority objective.

An example of the usefulness of this fund is my country, Portugal, which has used it four times, although we are aware that access to this fund could be improved, especially in the countries most affected by the crisis.

Thanks to the existence of this Globalisation Adjustment Fund, it has been possible to help thousands of workers through vocational training measures, help to set up businesses and recruitment incentives.
This proposal is positive because it will allow Member States to request the intervention of this fund to support workers dismissed as a direct consequence of the economic and financial crisis.

We support the extension of the deadline and understand that it should be the Member States most affected by the crisis that have greater access and easier access to this Globalisation and Crisis Support Fund.
I congratulate the Polish Presidency and also Commissioner Wally Rehn, just to say that I consider that the European Union is a force for good.
Today, in the sequence and in the development of what was done in the State of the Union speech, a very, very big step was taken to be able to solve the problems of the eurozone crisis.
Because the Commission has here assumed its commitment to use its power of initiative and to use it together with the Council to solve this crisis.
I believe this is an extremely important step and it is the only way we have at the moment to resolve the crisis in the euro area.
There is no possibility of resolving this in the short term, just through an intergovernmental approach, and therefore it is necessary that the states, the governments of the states, give
The Commission has the instruments and the mandate to lead this resolution process, to put into practice, to execute and develop this roadmap that it has presented here.
But I did not want to say that this is not incompatible with the fact that we are doing at the same time, that we are developing at the same time our capacity to change the Treaties.

I am also convinced that in the medium term we must change the Treaties, but we will have to do so in the sense of strengthening, in the sense of giving more strength and a better position to the Commission.

It is through reinforcing the Community's metric now in the short term and then with a change of treaties in the long term that we will achieve more integration and a solution for the 17 countries of the euro area and for the 27 countries of the European Union.

Mr President, Dr Durão Barroso came here today to announce as one of the measures that banks which do not have capital requirements must present plans to obtain them and, if they cannot present them, they must then suspend dividends and bonuses.
I could not help but agree with this presentation made by the President.
This week we saw what happened with the Bank of Exia and a few months ago, an administrator of this bank received a prize of 600 euros for his wonderful administration, as we know.
But to be serious, Mr President of the Commission, you have to ask the governments to present the full package, and the full package is what is essential.
The essential thing is that the taxpayers' money has a growth credit policy in return.
The essential thing is that the banks start paying taxes on their profits, which is not the case in many countries, especially in my country, Portugal.
In two years, or rather in three years, it's the second time they've asked us to save the banks with the money of the taxpayers, the unemployed.
Banks that also save the economy by helping to create jobs.
Madam President, Madam High Representative, there are times when I think I need little and make balances, and this seems to me to be one of the heights.
And it seems to me that we are always in the cadence of events and the response of event to event, and we lose a bit of what is the perspective of the whole.

It is true that each case is a case and each country we are talking about here is a specific case, but I am sorry to say, Madam High Representative, that it seems to me that it is difficult to scrutinise what criteria the European Union has used to act on each of the cases.
I am afraid that we are often held hostage to the interests of the countries of the European Union, by some of these countries of the European Union and not by all of them.
And that's why we use the expression "two weights and two measures" so many times in this House, and we continue to use it.

Sometimes it is sanctions yes, sometimes it is sanctions no, sometimes the interference goes to the limit of the bomb, as was the case in Libya, other times it is total silence, as was the case in the invasion of Bahrain by the forces of the United States.
I have studied all the ACTAs carefully and I have not yet seen a single statement from the European institutions condemning the invasion of Bahrain by the military forces of Saudi Arabia.

They are death sentences, endless violence, doctors and nurses who are sentenced to up to 30 years in prison by a military court because they were supposedly against the regime and not helping the wounded who needed them.
In relation to the dictatorial monarchy of Bahrain, in relation to the dictatorial regime of Yemen, the regime of Saleh, we have had much more silence than action.

I am not in favour of management, I never was, but I am afraid that we are put in an uncomfortable position, the position seen from the outside, Mrs Baroness, which is instead of helping us to develop, to aspire.
Instead of helping the Arab world, what we are doing is preventing it from spreading, whether by excess or by defect, and I don't think we should be left with that sin.
I hope that the awarding of the Nobel Prize to a Yemeni activist can serve as a sign that our side is on the side of the peoples who are in revolution.
Madam President, Commissioner, this is a good report by Mr Casa.
First of all, we have to ask why the VAT is being reviewed in the European Union.
First, there is a need to make it compatible with the single market.
The more regimes and varieties of VAT, the less liquid the market will be.
A VAT reform favours e-commerce, focusing competition on the value and price base of goods and services, not on tax differences.
It fights fraud and ensures the necessary confidence, especially in cross-border transactions, improves the economy of SMEs and reduces administrative burdens.
What other measures are being taken by young people in the single market that can be linked to VAT?
Firstly, a simple, clear and transparent digital support mechanism, the single market's measure seven.
Measure 5 on services: the need to review the legislation on standardisation and the implementation of the Services Directive
The new measure is intended to remove tax obstacles and to explicitly review the VAT system and the equalisation of VAT in online and face-to-face trade, which we all feel when ordering books.
The pressures for VAT reform have two basic reasons.
First of all, the economic crisis.
More revenue is needed, including, probably in some countries, the reduction of contributions on labour to promote economic development, by passing this task on to VAT.

Secondly, the second major source of pressure is population ageing, demographic ageing and the trend of shifting from indirect taxes to direct taxes, due to the reduction in the population base of incidence.
It is necessary to rethink the balance between this direct and indirect taxation.
Finally, in these reforms we must reconcile subsidiarity with harmonization.
It is necessary to restrict the interval of variation in the normal VAT rate so that we can all understand it better.
Greater transparency is needed in the definition of the reduced VAT rate and its scope, a clear and widely disseminated list of reduced rates.
It is necessary to study exemption thresholds for SMEs, knowing well that each exemption entails a procession of small or large fraud.
Finally, I welcome the Commission's recent proposal to create a European VAT.
Madam President, I thank Mr Rübig for the excellent report he has prepared.

The advantages of public procurement are certainly known, but the obstacles are also evident: conflicts of interest between European legislation and the objectives of the Member States undermine competitiveness.
The dichotomy between price quality and the complexity of laws and procedures is evident.
It is essential to look at existing good practices, particularly in Portugal, where e-employment has worked well and has facilitated public recruitment.
Effective European public procurement is a privileged means of controlling the public deficit and further growth.
To this end, it must have a stable and predictable legal framework, less bureaucratic procedures to attract SMEs and defend social and environmental values.
That is why I welcome the intentions of Commissioner Barnier to present us here for the review of public procurement, which is still this year one of the twelve priorities of the Single Market Act.
to congratulate colleague Rula and all those who collaborated with her.
An important issue in the field of public contracts is the issue of electronic public procurement.
Unfortunately, the targets proposed by the European Union for 50 electronic procurement procedures in 2010 failed, falling short of the average of 5
Only a few countries, such as my own Portugal, have succeeded in this domain.

The advantages of e-employment are also evident and have been stated here. It allows to replace the expensive access processes with a simple consultation of the e-platform, i.e. it reduces many costs for companies, especially for SMEs.

The dissemination on the Internet and the ease of receiving procedural pieces expand the number of suppliers, increasing competition and allowing better purchasing, and return to the process of awarding public contracts.

The more easy and flexible system simplifies access to public contracts in the European Union, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, thus facilitating the participation in the market of public contracts of these important drivers of the economy.
In this respect, we welcome and encourage the European Commission to strengthen the mechanisms to transform electronic public procurement into an increasingly comprehensive reality.

We are living in decisive hours for the fate of Europe, and if the situation has quickly shifted, before everyone's eyes, from a problem of the Greeks or the Portuguese to a problem of great European dimension, the truth is that the inadequacy of the solutions proposed and their delay have produced no effect on the rapid deterioration of the situation.
The search for solutions aimed at the States, at the expense of truly European solutions, allowed the markets to continue to speculate on sovereign debts and imposed deadlines and rhythms.
These are absolutely impossible goals that some States are trying to achieve with measures of unimaginable brutality applied to people, businesses and the public sector.

It is absolutely essential to find a common solution, already found for the risk of European sovereign debts, which removes the pressure of markets and speculation and gives time for the adjustment which is essential to be made.
Without this, what we will have in the end will be countries that will continue without more to pay the creditors, economies destroyed and much, much suffering.

I would like to thank my colleagues, the shadow rapporteurs, with whom I have had a fruitful collaboration, and I would also like to thank the rapporteurs of the partners of the four committees involved.
We received 400 amendments and drew up 47 commitments, all of which were approved.
This shows the importance and interest aroused by this issue of new skills and jobs.
It is, after all, about preparing Europe's human resources, anticipating the needs of the labour market in the next decade.
The key strategy for the preparation of the report was to reformulate the common ideas in order to avoid repetition and to ensure the coherence of the report.
I think that objective has been achieved.
We all know that the crisis that is currently affecting us has highlighted the fragility of the European economic and social model and has undone many of the progress made in the past.
Since the first effects of the crisis began to be felt in the labour markets in 2008, Europe has already lost more than 5 million jobs.
Today, there are almost 23 million people without jobs.
Young unemployment is even more frightening, with the youth unemployment rate close to 21 and more than double the overall unemployment rate.
On the other hand, in all Member States unemployment rates vary with the level of qualifications.
This means that people with higher qualifications get a job more easily.
We also know that in the near future, skills, competences and qualifications will increase in all types and levels of occupation.
In this context, Europe faces four challenges: first, job creation; second, the need to develop and remain competitive.
Secondly, the sustainability of social security systems and, finally, the difficulty of finding people with the appropriate skills to fill job vacancies.

This report thus has a double objective: firstly, to underline the need to act quickly in order to close the skills gaps in Europe; secondly, to better anticipate the skills needs of the labour market.

To this end, several measures are highlighted. Firstly, to ensure the availability of skilled labour, it is necessary to improve basic skills, as well as skills in the sciences, innovation, information and communication technologies, as well as in foreign languages.
As I have already mentioned, the skills needs must be identified early, within a minimum of 10 years.
The potential of a new sustainable economy, the green economy and the need to invest in ecological qualifications are now known.
Participation in lifelong learning and vocational retraining and in reducing school dropouts should then be increased.
Another important issue is the mutual recognition of diplomas and professional qualifications and the urgency of moving forward with this recognition.
Fourthly, we draw attention to the link that must exist between educational establishments and the needs of the labour market.
Internships must be of high quality and supervised by tutors so that they can lead to employment and end any abuse of the situation of interns.
Particular emphasis is also placed on the role of the social partners and social dialogue.
The report also proposes measures to promote job search and creation.
We have a future ahead of us and we have to create jobs.
Small and medium-sized enterprises play a decisive role in this respect.

It is also necessary to strengthen the single market in order to facilitate the free movement of workers and, therefore, the need for coordination of social security systems so that workers can see their acquired rights, in particular the portability of pensions, guaranteed.

Finally, on the question of labour market flexibility, in order to improve the functioning of the labour market, the flexicurity rules must be adapted to the socioeconomic contexts of each Member State.
Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking all my colleagues who have taken part in this lively debate.
All the colleagues have had very useful interventions and have contributed to a very constructive discussion on an agenda which is ambitious at a time when we are experiencing a serious crisis.

In fact, this discussion is taking place on the very eve of the European Council, which will show whether or not there is a political will to overcome the difficulties we are experiencing and whether there is a will to
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has already made a number of proposals to the Council and the European Parliament on this subject.

New jobs in the next decade, new jobs that lead to young people who are unemployed today and those who are training to have hope in the labour market, to have hope in an inclusive labour market that gives them a response to their needs.

They have the ambition to achieve dignity through work and they also have the opportunity to be in a permanent dynamism to accompany the challenges of a globalised economy and with a dynamic that has no parallel in recent generations.

So our ambition is really to create jobs, to have economic growth, to respond not only to those who are unemployed as a result of the crisis, but also to those who are going to enter the labour market.

It is a response to the great challenges that are facing the green economy, with healthcare services, with transport and housing services, which require from all of us a different vision, an intelligent vision and an inclusive vision of the labour market.
Thank you all very much.

Madam President, what we were told today, here in the Council statement, is that for technical reasons democracy should be sacrificed in the matter of the European Semester, but what we are talking about is a political issue and the question I ask is whether there can be political coordination without democracy.
Where is the European Parliament's scrutiny at the end?
Where is the scrutiny of national parliaments on their big budgetary options?

But if the question is technical, as has been said here, then we are talking about a variable technique, because we know how the Council substantially eased the conditions of the four countries on the waiting list, France, Italy, Hungary and Spain, but did not do the same with regard to the countries under rescue.
So the model of intergovernmentalism is this one, which allows Germany to give opinions about Portugal, but not Portugal to give opinions about Germany.
And, Commissioner, please, just pay attention to this, there is no problem of democratic legitimacy to be solved by asking the Members who are going to consult the information on the Internet.
This is a problem of exclusion, not a problem of democratic exclusion. That's what we're talking about.

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, a first word to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Dardenne, on the quality and timeliness of this report and also Commissioner Andor on the initiatives announced.
Poverty is indeed a very serious problem which requires effective and rapid action to stem the increase in the phenomenon which is currently affecting more than 80 million Europeans.
The serious crisis we are already going through has worsened this situation and made the times we live in dramatic, as Commissioner Andor said.
The number of people in unemployment continues to rise and we all know that unemployment is a passport to poverty and social exclusion.
This scenario requires resources, will and a lot of effort from the European Commission and the Member States.
If this does not happen, the goal of lifting 20 million European citizens out of poverty during this decade will not be achieved.
That is why I very much welcome the initiative of the Platform against Poverty, which is a very important instrument for ensuring social justice.
But no one doubts that the best antidotes to poverty and social exclusion are job creation and the promotion of economic growth.
Internet access must now be seen as a new fundamental right of citizens and not just as a mere object of trade, because this right is a fundamental right of the European Union.
They depend on essential things, such as freedom of expression, access to and sharing of information, access to and sharing of culture and knowledge, as well as democratic and media pluralism.

And that is why this access cannot be subject to speculative tariffs or contracts that block free choice and the possibility of easily changing suppliers, particularly in the world of mobile telecommunications, as we also know.
Active citizenship therefore requires that complete and transparent information be provided.
The blocking of the free use of the Internet is not only exclusive to political regimes that fear their people.
It can also happen as a result of economic options, by offering privileges to special customers and a less equal treatment to customers who are not so profitable.
That is why I wholeheartedly support Parliament's clear commitment to net neutrality and to the defence of its overall character.
We told the truth.
We've been taking the medicine to get out of the crisis for three years, and the situation is getting worse by the day.
Instead of healing, we create two fatal vicious circles.
The first is between banks and states.
In Europe today, the bankruptcy of a state is more easily discussed than that of a large bank, but you continue to expect banks to finance states and states to save their banks.
This spiral tends to be broken.
The Commission must move forward with European legislation to protect taxpayers from banking crises.
But it is also vital to protect the debt of states from the attacks of speculators.

And to do this, it is urgent and it is already taking time to prepare the coordinated sovereign debt issuances, call them Eurobonds or stability bonds, and to guarantee them through robust instruments of a Community and non-intergovernmental nature.
In short, we also need to review the involvement of the European Central Bank.
But the second vicious circle results from the argument that some states are rich because they are virtuous, while others are poor because they have sinned.
This narrative is politically explosive and technically wrong.

It ignores the essential fact that a single market and a single currency, built by political choice and between unequal people, necessarily aggravates the imbalances of competitiveness between the centre and the periphery.
And this is what has to be attached to economic governance.
No, Mr Rompuy, through sanctions that promote the crushing of wages and incomes with control from one country over another.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission's proposal for a directive on the protection of workers from the risks related to exposure to carcinogens and mutagens has been rejected by the Council.
The sanctions have only generated unemployment, disillusionment and a wave of unemployment that we have not been able to contain.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, integrated maritime policy advocates a coordinated approach to the management and governance of the oceans, seas and coasts, with a global and coherent perspective of all European policies related to the sea.

Having a global perspective and an integrated approach implies the interaction of European policies linked to the sea and calls for better governance through greater involvement in the European decision-making process.
The success and relevance of this policy have been demonstrated over the past few years through the various initiatives financed in the form of preparatory actions and pilot projects.
The integrated maritime policy must therefore continue to benefit from adequate funding during the next few years of the current financial programming period.
In this respect, I am in favour of adequate funding until 2013, not only to consolidate previous projects, and I support the definition of a stable framework for the objectives of this programme.

The issues of policy, governance, sustainability and maritime surveillance are, for obvious reasons, issues of particular interest to some regions of the European Union, such as the outermost regions.

The ROP are regions, with the exception of French Guiana, which are small and depend on a small number of economic activities and where activities related to the sea and fisheries are of particular importance.
In addition, the outermost regions contribute to the European Union having the largest exclusive economic zone in the world.

The RUPs account for more than half of the European Union's exclusive economic zone of some 15 million square kilometres, together with the coastal regions, being fundamental to the economic growth of the European Union and its Member States.
A programme such as the Integrated Maritime Policy Constant should benefit these regions, with a focus on transnational coordination of maritime policies and relevant international cooperation.
It is therefore necessary to ensure continuous and sufficient funding, not only for the next two years, but also and above all for the next financial framework from 2014.

Mr President, I would like to take this opportunity, when we are talking about an integrated maritime policy, to underline the enormous potential of the Atlantic and island dimensions for the European Union.

The Atlantic, being Europe's western maritime border, also establishes its link with North and South America and Africa, giving Europe a strategic dimension indispensable in the architecture of a maritime policy designed with the eyes on the future.

And it is thinking about the future that the integrated maritime policy, in addition to promoting the articulation of maritime activities, must put at the forefront of its priorities the potential of the Atlantic in its three-dimensional dimension based on science and technology.

The study of the Mediterranean, the Atlantic, the deep sea and the seabed constitutes a new frontier whose potential exists in biotechnology and mineral resources and is of inestimable value to the knowledge economy.
The Union must therefore take advantage of the privileged position of the Azores and the expertise of its marine department to set up a deep-sea observatory there.
Enough of this road.
When the diagnosis is wrong, the remedies don't work.
And in the case of the euro area, excessive remedies have even led to death.
The successive miraculous solutions that have been proposed have also been equally discredited by the markets.
the Financial Stabilisation Fund, the successive reinforcement packages of the Stability and Growth Pact, the Troika revenues in the countries under the programme.
Blind discipline, without growth, has generated a recessive wave between fully interconnected economies, which have therefore become contaminated with bankruptcy and unemployment.
And in the hands of the markets, that is, the rating agencies and speculators, governments are falling one after the other and the solvent countries are becoming insolvent.

To change the Treaties now is another step in this disastrous trajectory, with an aggravating risk of destroying what remains of national sovereignty by placing the countries in the hands of the European Court of Justice.
No, you don't have to change the treaties.
In this emergency we are in, we need to make two decisions.
Firstly, a genuine agenda for growth and sustainable cohesion needs to be put in place.
Where is the 2020 agenda?
Where's the resumption budget?
Where are the project bonds for Europe's structural investments?
And secondly, we need to protect sovereign debt.
Of course, air bonds are necessary, but in this emergency we are in, it is urgent that the European Central Bank, directly or indirectly, defend the sovereign debt against speculators.
Not in a shameful way, but with a definitive, decisive position, as befits any central bank that defends its currency and the economy that supports it.
This does not require changing the Treaties, it requires political will and European conviction.
We will move the Treaty when we have withdrawn all the lessons of the present crisis and there are not many lessons to be withdrawn, but this is certainly not the time.
Mr President, Commissioner Dalli, the first Single Market Forum, the idea of which comes from the Greek report, took place in Krakow in
It was rich in content and fruitful in the debate conducted by the Polish Presidency with European, national, regional and local authorities and civil society.
We have a roadmap, outlined in the Commission's April 12 communication on the 12 levers.
The EU needs to be put on the right track, as does the strategy of the other 38 priorities identified in the Single Market Act.
For a market to exist, trust is needed.
The confidence of citizens and consumers cannot be seen as an acquired fact, it lacks to be stimulated, fed.

The single market is not just a buying and selling operation, it involves horizontal policies such as health, social protection and consumer protection, labour law, the environment and sustainable development.
The Single Market Forum must therefore become an emblematic event of the European Union, with an annual event and a diverse and increasingly participatory audience.
Mr President, I think we are at a tipping point in the policy of austerity which has affected so many countries and also in the so-called structural reforms.
And it is in this context that I think we cannot help but see how they have generated so much social commotion.
It has generated social mobility not only in the countries with the greatest difficulties, in the countries of the South, not only in the so-called peaks and also in other contexts in Europe.
Last week we had in Portugal the biggest general strike ever, both in the public sector and in the private sector, a strike that went out into the streets.

But if we look at what happened today in the United Kingdom, we see that we are witnessing the biggest strike ever, especially if we take into account that people took to the streets as well as they did in Portugal.
We expect a big demonstration in Brussels on Friday.

What this proves, Mr President, and what the strikes prove in the departure of people from the streets, is that the causes and the problems we have faced are common and that is why the reaction is also common.
The crisis in the European Union is infecting all the Member States, reaching incredible proportions.

We are witnessing chaos in the financial markets and the growing inability to provide the essential financing for the activities of our small and medium-sized enterprises, even though they are healthy, leading them to despair, bankruptcy and unemployment.
It's a spiral that feeds the recession and is destroying the economy and society.

No one denies the rigorous need for budgetary cuts, for deep restructuring, for more economic governance, but these are necessary conditions which, in the short term, are no longer sufficient to counteract the ongoing degradation in the Union.

And if it is true that policies are needed to boost employment and growth, without which we will never be able to control sovereign debt, the central question today is to ensure the financing of our companies and our economies, without which the Union will fall.
That is why, more than ever, more than the revision of the Treaties, we need today a strong and secure intervention by the European Central Bank.
Madam President, Commissioner, we are here today, all of us together, around a resolution with a set of very important requests in terms of intervention.
We are talking about the World Day against HIV and AIDS, and this assessment of the 2009 resolution and communication is fundamental.
It is fundamental precisely because of things that have already been mentioned.
We repeat ourselves, because unfortunately there is still room for repetition, which means that there is much to do.
There are many new cases diagnosed every year in Europe and in the European Economic Area.
If we look at the neighbouring countries, we are talking about more than 100 new cases.
And if we think that there are things that can't get worse, they can always get worse.

And one of the issues that I want to make very clear here has to do with the disinvestment that has been made in the health sector as a result of the economic and financial crisis that we are currently experiencing.
And this investment has seriously affected domains that are fundamental to the fight against HIV AIDS.
That is why, Commissioner, I think that the Commission has a fundamental role to play here in asking the Member States to fulfil their obligations in these areas.

A second issue is also related to the increase in discrimination, also evidenced by the economic and social crisis, discrimination against workers who have lost their jobs because they are carriers of this virus.
Prevention, treatment and care must be the same for everyone, regardless of gender, age, or region.
I hope that we will be able to implement these measures with the support of the Commissioner.
Welcome to this Parliament, Mr Draghi.
We are experiencing special and dramatic circumstances and they require certain and urgent measures.

The spiral between the debt of the States and the debt of the banks must be broken, but at the moment the priority is to defend the States, to ensure that the countries of the euro area and the euro itself are not destroyed by the rating agencies and by speculators.
In the report we are going to adopt, Tremoz and Basels, we have proposals to rethink the architecture of the euro area, to create Eurobonds and a European treasury, but all this takes time.
At the moment we are talking about an emergency and, in this context, the only solution is in the hands of the European Central Bank.
Technically, the European Central Bank knows what needs to be done.
Today, he must not be inhibited in his intervention and action by limited interpretations of his mandate.
Your mandate is to safeguard the euro, not to deal with inflation.
At the moment there is no doubt that saving the euro and doing what is necessary is what this Parliament and the citizens expect from the European Central Bank.
Good sort of courage, my dear.
The European Neighbourhood Policy's guidelines already very explicitly stated the positions that the European Parliament has come to take.

It was with great satisfaction that we saw inserted in the subsequent communications of the Commission and the Council a large part of the principles and proposals which we have come to defend in this House.
I am grateful, moreover, for the excellent and permanent cooperation and coordination we have maintained throughout this time with Vice-President Ashton and with Commissioner Füle and his offices.
Of course, because of the upgrade we have achieved in our relationship with the neighbouring poor.

By privileging relations with the population in general and with civil society organisations in particular, we will be giving greater objectivity and greater effectiveness to our neighbourhood policy, which is intended to be based exclusively on the universal values we defend and share.
However, I would point out that the European Union does not intend to impose a predefined model or formula for political reforms in third countries.
But when it comes to our taxpayers' money, we should give more to those who are doing more, in the approach to the values we believe in.
This principle means that the sooner a country progresses in its internal reforms, the more support it will receive from the European Union.
The principle of more for more is therefore correct, fair and coherent.
Which means, of course, that we also anticipate the possibility that there will be cases or countries where we will have less for less.
Neighbourhood policy now focuses on the defence of the prosecution of common values and on the commitment to democracy, human rights, the rule of law and good governance.
But this search implies greater accountability.
Our partners are called upon to take greater responsibility in the process, which is why we defend the principles of greater differentiation, greater conditionality and so on.
By taking a bottom-up approach to our partners and tailor-made policies, we make development and institutional capacity more effective.

It is an institutional building that we both want to defend and that is at the heart of the rule of law and the democratic process and that we want to see implemented as quickly as possible in the societies, economies and communities of our neighbours.

The idea is to give the floor to the citizens, as well as to all civil society movements that identify with our values, supporting organized movements that strive to achieve positive and democratic changes in their societies.
countries, improving the rights of women and children, building and deepening the principles of freedom of expression, association, religious belief, press, choice, etc.

With fair elections, with the fight against corruption, with the rule of law, with greater social justice, with respect for minorities, with environmental protection and with the efficiency of resources.
The serious economic and social problems facing our neighbours must also be the subject of immediate action.
It is clear that without our concrete help, the ongoing democratic processes may fail.
These were the ideas we have always defended for the future European Neighbourhood Policy.
These are the proposals contained in the report we are putting to you for vote.
Now is the time to act.
