For our part, we will continue to be attentive and to exercise our powers of monetization and taxation, now vested in the European Parliament.

In conclusion, I would like to thank my colleague, co-rapporteur and friend Marek Siwicki, to whom I leave a very special word of appreciation for his remarkable work on the eastern side of the neighbourhood policy.
I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and all of you for the immense suggestions made in the amendments you have tabled, which I believe have enriched our work.
And a final word to the Secretariat of the Commission and to the political advisers for the excellent support work I have had.
In the European Neighbourhood Policy, without including the outermost regions as active borders of Europe in different parts of the world.
As external borders, the outermost regions convey our values of democracy, peace, respect for human rights and fundamental rights, together with the third countries of these regions.
"Regions such as the French outermost regions have an absolute need for greater inclusion in their geographical areas.
This insertion is fundamental to its development and constitutes a huge potential for deepening the neighbourhood policy with the neighbouring third countries.

Neighbourhood policy requires a new impetus, an impetus which also takes advantage of the privileged historical and cultural relations which the outermost regions of the Azores, Madeira and the Canary Islands maintain with North and South America.
A more active role for the European Union can and should be played by these regions in the context of a new European neighbourhood policy.

It has been a year since last September, after a deep debate in which I also took part as responsible for this matter in the Socialist Group, promoting meetings and debates with European, national and regional organisations linked to the European project.

Parliament approved the BOV report, which contains a comprehensive set of recommendations from the European Commission with the aim of achieving a fair return for farmers and a better functioning of the food supply chain.

Since 2008, in fact, communications, reports, recommendations and the creation of high-level forums and groups have been produced in the Commission and Parliament to solve this serious problem, without, in practice, anything being changed beyond greater awareness.

Let us return to the subject, and it must be said without hesitation, that a significant part of the problems faced by farmers is due to highly punitive behaviour imposed, above all, by modern distribution operators.
The problems are more than identified.
What the Commission and the Member States lack is an effective political will to implement the solutions.
Until then, we will continue to harm farmers and consumers.
I have to say that this treaty is useless.
Unfortunately, it is especially dangerous.
First, because it will reinforce, with more punishments and rigid rules, a recipe that does not work.
The recessive spiral is launched.
Who can trust a doctor who doesn't distinguish between weight loss and anorexia?
A doctor who, the more the patient weakens, the more he insists on the remedy, while openly discussing the probability of his death.
How many more countries have to go into recession so that the Commission and the Council realize that the diagnosis is wrong?
But it is also dangerous, because we here represent the citizens of Europe.
23 million 700 thousand are unemployed.
Nearly six million young people have no hope of finding employment.
Will the Council and the Commission not realise that ignoring this fact, not giving an adequate response, reveals an autism and an insensitivity that are politically exclusive?
Let's be clear about this.
The Great Recession is not a fatality, it is an ideological obsession.
There is an alternative agenda, it has to be, however, not words but action.
Where are the project bonds to finance European investment?
Where is the reinforcement of the European budget with the tax on speculative financial products?
Where is the barrier that should protect countries from the ruinous interest rates that the markets impose on them, leading them to ruin?
Citizens demand options, not words, but competent options. Thank you very much.
Madam President, the Commission and the governments are now pledging to reprogram the Structural Funds to support SMEs and create jobs.
However, it is worth recalling that at the end of last year the Commission also decided to suspend the allocation of structural funds to countries that did not meet the deficit or debt targets.
You don't have to be a genius to realize that either the promise comes or the punishment comes, but both are not the same thing.
That is why, Commissioner, I wanted to ask you a very direct question: is the decision to suspend the allocation of structural funds still standing, has it been frozen or has it been annulled?

In other words, Greece, Portugal, Ireland and other countries will still be able to use the funds to which they are entitled if they do not meet the objectives which are being imposed by the Commission and by you?
Answer, Commissioner, please, is that in Portugal we are very tired of promises, right?
Mr President, Commissioner, the proposal made by President Barroso is to redirect the available Structural Funds to support our SMEs.
But stimulating employment, especially youth employment, could not be more welcome, especially for economies that are being subjected to strong austerity measures, such as the Portuguese economy.

With the agreement on external intervention and the great difficulties in financing the economy, and in particular our small and medium-sized enterprises, by the banking system, this proposal is of particular importance for regions as users with high absorption and good use of funds, but inserted in a recessive context.

The European Union can achieve a real opportunity to stimulate its economy through small and medium-sized enterprises and the indispensable contribution of our generation of young people, better prepared than ever, in the best response to growth and employment that these funds can provide.
The dream is gone.
What we need to know, Commissioner, is how we will actually access these funds and how our regions will participate in their reprogramming.

The IT package presented here as an instrument for the organisation of the sector contains important positive elements, such as the strengthening of the role of producer organisations and inter-branch organisations in contractual matters, which in some Member States may, for example, leave the

However, there are quite a few instruments that the sector needs to prosper in the coming years in the context of agriculture, which we want to have in Europe access to a fair distribution of value in the food chain, which does not turn into a large-scale intensive farming concentrated in a few Member States.

If improving the condition of self-regulation in the relationship between actors in the sector is desirable, it is enough to think that this in itself is a serious mistake which can drive away thousands of milk producers, dozens of regions and even some countries of dairy activity.
The debate on the regulation of the internal sector in the perspective of a sustainable economic, social, environmental and territorial sector is still ongoing.
And we cannot abandon the milk quota regime without ensuring that there are real instruments for managing supply.
Mr President, Commissioner, since May 2010 until today we have seen how a problem which seemed manageable has become uncontrollably serious.

It is true that the fight against the crisis opened up by the financial markets has aggravated the indebtedness of the countries of the euro area and that the most vulnerable have become particularly vulnerable.
However, will it be possible for countries sharing the same currency to be left to the mercy of attacks by financial operators and winners, betting on the likelihood of euro countries going bankrupt?
The terrible consequences of the Commission's inability to respond have generated problems which are unquestionable today.
Speculative interest rates on individual countries have rendered any strategy to get out of the crisis unviable.
The consequent aggravation of the country's economic problem justifies a new interest rate hike until the total credit cut kills a country's economy and the contagion does the rest.
And this Parliament has much to say about a common way of managing sovereign debt, subject to demanding but clear rules.
We welcome the fact that the Commission has finally produced a green paper on the subject, which has been called

Today it is clear that without some kind of obligation of this kind, properly articulated with the European Stability Mechanism, the so-called barriers to the protection of sovereign debt do not exist, and as long as they do not exist, the euro is in danger and so is Europe.

In the resolution which this Parliament adopted by a majority on the new treaty, it was absolutely clear that it was unacceptable to continue to impose more rules on fiscal stability, budgetary discipline and sanctions on euro countries without taking concrete and urgent steps in the solidarity management of sovereign debt.
The two processes will have to evolve in parallel.
That is what we expect from the Commission and it is too late now.

I would like to think that this House of European Democracy will unanimously reject the behaviour of President Assad and the Syrian authorities in the murder of their own people, which we witness every day.
Because it is important that Europe can speak with one voice on the meaning of the values of respect for human life, make an indiscriminate massacre, ignoble orchestrated.
The entire international community must maintain pressure on the Syrian regime through the application of new restrictive measures.
The murder will be investigated and nothing is negotiable.
insist on dialogue, without a doubt.

A democratic Syria needs a period of transition and guarantees for all its minorities, but the application of more restrictive measures to the Syrian regime is not possible if all countries do not move in the same direction, and this has not been clear and unfortunately happened.
In addition to thousands of dead, between the two resolutions shamefully rejected in the UN Security Council
We continue to reproach China and Russia, who are increasingly isolated in their incredible support for the Syrian regime.
A rotten, desperate and entangled regime continues to rule a country and we, the international community, remain powerless to stop the genocide of a people.
We are already too late in strengthening the action of the European Union and the international community.
We must give more concrete support to the Arab League in its interventions and its intentions to send a peacekeeping force to Syria.
We must unreservedly support the work of the Red Crescent in its efforts to minimize the suffering of the populations.
The International Criminal Court must immediately initiate proceedings to punish those responsible for the crimes being committed against humanity.

And as a form of pressure on the countries that have maintained support for Assad, to also already ban trade exchanges of the European Union with all Russian or Chinese companies that have trade relations.
and start yesterday.
Mr President, Commissioner, welcome to discuss this very important subject.
In fact, we are talking about key issues relating to data protection and, above all, in a context where there may be conflict between two different jurisdictions.

Data protection is in fact one of the sensitive areas and that has generated so much controversy and, in my view, should continue to generate, because we are talking about what can be the shock between the two.
the rights and guarantees and safeguards of European citizens who are protected by European legislation and then overtaken when legislation from other countries overrides European legislation.
It is sensitive for several reasons.
Is it sensitive because there is a breakdown and there is a doubt about what is a contract that, for all intents and purposes, exists between European citizens and the European institutions?

When they give up their personal data, they give up on the understanding that they will be protected by the European entities and institutions and that they will not be distributed for other purposes.

So there is a breach of trust here, and this is a data that is difficult to manage, and on the other hand there is also a serious and dangerous situation, because the European Union ends up transferring personal data to third countries, thus breaking the trust that is generated.
So if citizens accept that the European institutions can be guardians of their personal data in so many different areas, from health issues to other issues, as has been mentioned, of companies,

I am speaking specifically, for example, of the case of the United States, which systematically requires data from the European Union, what we are doing when citizens start from budgets that are being ceded and, as you said, for the European Union to be the guardian of their data, is a breach of trust.
I would also like to say to you, Commissioner, that these issues have often been problematic for different reasons, but I will always be on the side of the citizens' demonstrations.

They want to safeguard the protection of their personal data and if there are demonstrations that intend to be held because the European institutions do not comply, I think we should be on the side of the citizens and not the other way around.

It is almost a kind of betrayal that is being carried out and that is why this question we are asking, these questions we are putting to you, Commissioner, is a pity that it can clarify us once and for all, because no community is built with destruction as its basis or foundation.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the European Parliament has not yet been consulted on this matter, and if so, to what extent can we ensure that European legislation overlaps with that of third countries?
Because if it is true that European legislation overrides the legislation of the countries of the 27 Member States of the European Union, and citizens abstain from it?
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this matter, and if so, what is the reason for this?
This needs to be clarified because it is a very sensitive and serious matter and it is one that we must take into account.

And finally, Commissioner, I would like to ask you, please, to tell us what the Commission is doing to prevent this from happening, to prevent it from happening again and to ensure that the personal data of all citizens and

The data of the companies and various sectors that are referenced in these issues are in fact data that people can trust that they are protected by what we protect, and by this I mean that I do not even share that all the information that is stored should be stored, but this is another debate.

In relation to this, as it is a serious issue and as it is a precarious issue in terms of what are the rights of citizens, I would like you to give us these clarifications so that we can all rest more, thank you very much.
Mr President, I would like to say that we expect the next Council to make a major economic decision for the countries which are very much concerned about the question of the Structural Funds.
We need to make structural funds more flexible.
There are many that are yet to be used, many of which were used only for large infrastructure.
They have to be turned to competitiveness, to small and medium-sized enterprises, to the relaunch of the economy.
The only investment that countries like Greece, Portugal, Ireland and others can have is what is currently resulting from these structural funds.
It also left a political note for all politicians in the Union, those who are in good faith in the European process.
When we talk about these issues, we must respect, be very careful about respect for national identities and for the Member States.
There are politicians, sometimes many of them with good intentions, but not all of them have met this challenge of strict respect for the national identity of each Member State.
Mr President, Mr President, Mr Commissioner, I congratulate the rapporteurs, but I would like to say that there is no need for pious speeches on employment and growth.

Today, with the first results on macroeconomic imbalances in Europe, the veil is beginning to be lifted over why in the European Union, and in particular in the euro area, some countries are growing while others are fatally defiant.

Europe is losing competitiveness in the external markets and this agenda needs to be reviewed because this is where much of the insufficient internal growth is happening, but concentrated in the internal market.
Four countries, including Germany, accumulate surpluses year after year, while 20 other countries, I repeat 20 countries, accumulate deficits year after year.
As deficits accumulate, the external debt of these countries increases unsustainably.
Of course, this process has to be controlled.
Of course, discipline is needed.
But it is important to ask today whether, in this context, the solution of crushing the most fragile with recessive policies is the only possible solution.
Is the tax competition of some winners within the internal market still tolerated?

Can the best European economy continue to develop common policies that favour it and internal economic policies that, while being right for its economy, capture most of the gains in the internal market in its favour?
Can the Commission and the Council continue to impose recessive policies that squeeze the economies of the most fragile by discussing
openly to the possibility of the bankruptcy of sovereign states in the euro area, when they know that the firefighters have never left the intention file
Are the Commission and the Council fully aware of the explosive political and economic risk this speech poses to Europe?
Yes, we need to radically revise the revenues.
But for that, there must be political will.
While this will does not exist, out of respect for fellow citizens, let us stop saying that we defend growth and employment, because it is not true.
And citizens cannot continue to be deceived.
Thank you, Mr President, I begin by greeting the rapporteurs.
To say that we are experiencing the most serious financial, economic and social crisis since the creation of our modern international financial model is already common.
To stress that unemployment rates in the European Union have reached historic records is never too much to demand that the fight against unemployment be a priority.
Youth unemployment is dramatic in my country, Portugal, where more than one in three young people are looking for work and have no prospects of getting it.
Our citizens are incredulous.
It is urgent to restore their trust.
After years of reckless management of public finances, it is time to adopt budgetary consolidation reforms and put the accounts in order.
But let's not get carried away. Austerity without economic growth is just a partial solution.
The creation of more and better jobs is the great European design.
Measures to ensure that young people who will not be without a job or training offer for more than four months, as well as to reduce the risk of poverty and social exclusion, must be a reality.
A year ago, we witnessed the tragic combination of an earthquake, a tsunami and a nuclear industrial accident, all in sequence.
Today we pay a heartfelt tribute to the many thousands of victims of Fukushima.
To honor the victims is to tell them that we have learned the lesson that we must learn to deal with natural disasters, with nuclear disasters we have an obligation to avoid them.
But unfortunately, that doesn't seem to be the case.
A year after Fukushima, new nuclear power plants continue to be built.
A year after Fukushima, new nuclear power plants are still being planned.
Japan, unfortunately, has the memory of the tragedies that continue, Hiroshima, Nagasaki, and we Europeans also have the memory of a tragedy that continues, Chernobyl.
Fukushima forces us, for all this, to reopen a debate that should never have been closed, the debate on nuclear energy.
A year ago, nuclear power was unquestionable to the Japanese, today two-thirds of the Japanese do not want it.
They know it costs lives, and they know that this cost has no price, on the contrary, it is a cost that increases from generation to generation.
The stubborn policy in favor of nuclear is the policy of arrogance.
Here in Europe too, we have a majority of public opinion against nuclear power, and yet nothing seems to change.
There are 320,000 refugees in Japan today, of which 100,000 will never be able to return home.
What used to be familiar is now dangerous, what used to be comfortable is now ruined.
It is the ruin of a building or a house with radioactive vegetation, the ruin of the soil or the contaminated water.

Fukushima cannot be visited as other ruins are, for example, a Maya ruin or a Roman ruin, but nevertheless, like these, Fukushima also portrays a civilization, and the ruin of Fukushima portrays our civilization.
The one that chose to include in its development model a deadly technology.
An earthquake and a tsunami have no culprits, but a nuclear disaster has perpetrators.
In Japan, as in Europe, many citizens have decided to create a farewell to nuclear power.
They know better than anyone that safe nuclear energy is something that doesn't exist, they know better than anyone that there are no stress tests.
They can't simulate what happened in Fukushima, and that's why we know that energy policies are national, but in heaven.
As mentioned, diabetes affects more than 30 million people in Europe.
And these are, in fact, the numbers of an epidemic.
That is why I understand that it is also justified to make a specific resolution on diabetes, even more so since this is the first time that this Parliament has dealt with this subject.

It is the result of collective work and it is work that does not undo the work done so far on chronic diseases, but on the contrary strengthens and reinforces this capacity that we have to intervene together.
We have about 325 deaths a year associated with diabetes, because we know that diabetes is the leading cause of, for example, heart attacks, blindness, amputations, failure of vital organs.
And given this data, we have two options, in my opinion.
The first is to say that it's not so serious, that we can live with it and that each government treats itself.
The second is to say that the absence of a European strategy in this area is part of the problem.
I understand that on this side we have a lot to do.
And we have a lot to do in early diagnosis, in coordination, in investment in research.
And that is why this resolution has the value of a start and of joint work in this direction.
Mr President, what I wanted to draw attention to, basically, was to congratulate myself on the Council's results.
Not because the measures are ideal, but because they are possible.
There is no doubt that today we have come much further and we can be more optimistic than we were three months ago and six months ago.
Many States have made a tremendous effort to stabilize and consolidate their public finances, and this effort has only been made in some States by the European Union.
It is essential for them to regain their credibility in international markets and it is essential for them to grow in time.
With these guarantees that the states have given, among which the Portuguese state stands out in the sense of making fiscal consolidation the budgetary consolidation, I am in favour of
I am convinced, also with the new Treaty signed between the 25 Member States, that we will be in a position to seriously revive growth in the next steps of the European Council.
But only with this confidence that is being generated little by little is this growth to be made.
That is why I say that solidarity between the richest and the poorest is important, but the poorest and the richest are also important, giving these guarantees.
Mr President, I would basically like to say that it is with great joy that we have verified that steps have been taken to integrate Serbia into the European Union.

This is very important because the experience of countries like Portugal, Spain or Greece, which were countries that experienced dictatorships and had a set of very serious problems, is the experience that European integration was the way to consolidate democracy.
And that is why Serbia also deserves this opportunity.
I would like to give a note here a little different from the one given by my colleagues.
I know and welcome the concern for minorities, but we must not forget the Serbian majority.
This cannot be forgotten.

There will be no peace in the Balkans without Serbia, and therefore, no matter how much we emphasize the rights of minorities and how much they must be respected, we cannot forget the Serbian majority, their identity and their full right to be European citizens, equal to all others, with their own state and national pride.
Mr President, Portugal voted last week for the Treaty, or rather the budgetary ultimatum, which is not, by the way, a European Treaty.

The favorable vote of the governing parties reflects the accumulation of decades and decades of stupidity and a typical attitude of a good student, a racist one, who does not think and obeys bad teachers.
The position of the PS and its leader was to move from a very dangerous violent abstention to a crawling vote in favour.

This alliance makes our Assembly of the Republic of Portugal the first parliament to accept the humiliation of being deprived of one of its most important functions for which the people elected it: to decide annually the budget of the country.
This is another blow from the European Union, another blow in which the power of money is increasingly out of the reach of the votes of the citizens.
And I ask, Mr President, is it democratic for someone to vote so that they can no longer vote?
Mr President, budgetary consolidation is imposing almost unbearable demands on some European citizens.
However, every day there are fewer and fewer people who have to bear a greater burden.
The tax burden affects workers, small and mediumsized enterprises, consumers, and in the meantime there is a completely excessive tax evasion and avoidance.
The European Socialists' Group wanted to know how much this tax evasion and tax evasion is worth in the 27 countries, and it's worth 1 billion euros, in English 1 trillion euros.
This is more than the countries of the European Union spend on health.
This means that if we spent only a fifth of this amount on investment, investment in Europe would go up from 2.7 of GDP to 3.5 we are therefore talking about an exceptionally high value.

The purpose of the resolution we are about to adopt, initiated by this Parliament, is precisely a very clear demand to the Commission and the Council to speed up concrete action to combat tax evasion and fraud.

This means, in particular, concrete initiatives for tax cooperation within the European Union, for tax cooperation with our neighbouring countries, in particular Switzerland, but negotiated by the Commission and not country by country in a bilateral manner.
This means reforming and harmonising accounting rules, increasing transparency and reporting.
This clearly means reactivating the fundamental issue of combating fraud and tax evasion through tax havens.
Europe is not a minor partner.
Europe is a great partner in the international context.
Europe has an obligation, within the framework of the G20, to clearly defend a common fight against fraud and tax evasion.

Without this, we lose the credibility of our citizens together, and that is why my last words in this debate are to encourage the Commission and the Council to initiate an effective fight against tax fraud and evasion.

Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mrs Niebler on her excellent work and by pointing out the coincidence that on Europe Day, which we are celebrating today, we are debating and tomorrow we are approving measures which go against the legitimate wishes of our citizens.
What is at stake in this regulation is to impose limits on the mobile tariffs charged to European consumers when roaming, with the main objective of ending roaming in the European space from 2016.
Our citizens are benefiting from a sharp drop in prices in terms of calls, SMS and data.
If there are operators today that charge 3 euros per mega, from July the maximum price they can charge is 70 cents per mega, passing this value to 20 cents in 2014.
As for the calls received, the maximum price that can be charged will be 8 cents this year and 5 cents in 2014.
In July 2012, a family with two mobile phone users will save, as the Commissioner said, 200 euros on their bill.
Second benefit: higher quality of information for consumers.
As early as the summer, operators are obliged to inform consumers of the prices they pay when they travel outside the European Union.
Until now, the obligation was only for the European space.
The third advantage is the possibility of more operators entering the market, which means increased competition that will stimulate better services and better prices.

Finally, in the near future, the consumer will be able to have two contracts, one for services in the national territory and one for services abroad, keeping the same mobile number and having only one invoice.
It will also give the consumer, our citizen, the opportunity to enter into a contract with any European operator that offers him the best price.
This report is the perfect example of a Europe of citizens, a Europe of freedom of movement and freedom of establishment.
Mr President, in February 2009 this Parliament adopted a report supporting the European Commission's proposal to relaunch the European economy.
There were clean energy projects, transport, new technologies, innovation and already at that time the role of the European Investment Bank and the Structural Funds was being equated.
After more than three years, we were able to produce the Six Pack, the Euro Plus Pact, the budget pact, the two pack, all of them full of reinforced discipline and sanctions.

But in the meantime, while unemployment, especially among young people, is reaching frightening levels, the European economy is in recession and more than seven of its Member States are experiencing negative growth.
And yet, while Greece is only a first stone that threatens to tear down the castle, the relaunch agenda seems to have been forgotten.
At the moment, this agenda is clear.
What matters at this point is no longer to give it an emergency character, it's an emergency character in a situation that threatens to explode.
There is an urgent need to intervene on a set of pillars.
Firstly, the European Marshall Plan needs to be set up with investment to promote growth, employment and convergence.
Project bonds are one of the possible sources.
Secondly, we need to stabilise the interest rates at which countries finance themselves.
Let us at least prepare ourselves to coordinate the issuance of sovereign debt and jointly manage the accumulated debt.
Thirdly, the European Stability Mechanism and the European Central Bank must prepare themselves to function, in fact, as real firecrackers in the defence of European sovereign debt.
Fourthly, the credit that has been transferred by the European Central Bank to the commercial bank must reach the companies.
It is one billion euros that is held in the banking system, while thousands of viable businesses die every day from lack of funding.
Fifth, investment doesn't make sense without searching.
The most fragile economies are crushed by austerity plans.
It is the strongest economies that have to free up internal demand.

It is that almost 80 of the trade is done within Europe and it is up to the Commission, Commissioner Oleg Hahn, to make recommendations aimed not only at the most fragile economies but also at the most dynamic ones.
And finally, Madam President, there must be a limit on the revenues imposed by the troika.

I would like to ask the President-in-Office of the Council whether he is aware of the fact that the Council of Ministers of the European Communities has adopted a resolution on the situation in the former Yugoslavia.
Mr President, Mr Minister, Mr Commissioner, what I wanted to say is very clear: naturally, the Portuguese Members of the PPE fully support all measures that can contribute to growth.
But sometimes, when I listen to some colleagues here, I get the feeling that they think that there can continue to be growth with excessive deficits and with more public accounts.
Now we must continue to insist on reducing spending and structural reforms, we can do everything on the growth side, but we cannot abandon the path of containment and reduction of public spending and
More growth cannot be more relaxation, more rest, more growth and more growth policies must go hand in hand with great rigour in public accounts and with great rigour in structural reforms.
If we start just talking about growth and thinking that there are magical solutions to growth, we will end up again in an unsustainable public debt and we will continue without structural reforms.

That said, I wanted to draw attention to the fact that at tomorrow's summit this issue of long-term or medium-term growth will not only be at stake, but the urgent issue of Greece will be at stake, and I think it is essential that the European states somehow stand by Greece.
We are responsible for finding a solution to the Greek problem, and I wanted to refute here the statement of the British Member who spoke about the Portugueseization of Europe.
The Portugueseization of Europe, at least in terms of values, would not be a negative thing, and therefore I reject this idea of trying to humiliate or try to reduce any people.
We are all Europe and we all have a place in it.
Mr President, Commissioner, I have come here to tell you that every euro more spent on debt is one euro less for job creation, so explain to us why we should continue in this obsession.

He also came here to tell us that one of the priorities of the summit is to keep Greece in the euro area, and I ask you, Commissioner, do we believe in ourselves or do we believe in Dr Doron Barroso or Mr Trichet, who went, I do not know how many days ago, to say exactly the opposite?
You spoke about the maintenance of the euro area, I ask you in which euro?

In the euro that we currently live in, in this area that we currently live in, or in the euro that was announced yesterday by the Deutsche Bank in a study referring to a second-class euro, in case the left wins these elections in June in Greece.
This is a trap, Commissioner, a trap for a Europe that is held hostage by governments and a trap for a Europe that is held hostage by financial interests.
Let's not let people live on fear, because it's not a way of life, Europe can be something else, Mr. Wise, there's no shortage of money, there's no shortage of shame.

Mr President, Mr Minister Vlamin, the first thing I would like to say is that it is regrettable that in a debate of this importance the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative, Mrs Ashton, are not present.
In any case, we have the pleasure of working again with Minister Vámen, who made a statement here in which I look back on it in full.

I wanted, first of all, to give a word of comfort and solidarity to the people of Guinea, who have been basically the people of Guinea-Bissau, a people systematically massacred by democratic instability, political instability and great insecurity.
It is no longer enough that the poverty of the people who are on their knees has been systematically affected by these evils.

I would like to say, on the other hand, that the EPP Group, in its presidency, has been following this issue from the outset and that it is also unfortunate that the European Parliament can only have a debate on this matter at the end of a month.
This has to do with the invisibility of the Guinean people and the Guinean issue.

And this invisibility is only the fact that, unlike other matters, which are also very serious, there are no major economic interests at stake here, which motivate the European, American and world powers to discuss the situation of the Guinean people.
But I must say that if an external motive is needed, if misery and political instability are not enough for us to have a global humanitarian and political action, there is no other way.
At least the situation of drug trafficking in Guinea, which directly affects the European and American peoples, was a reason for us to commit ourselves to this.
And that is why I am asking the European Union to be stronger.

There is no doubt that the 2048 resolution, there is no doubt that the decisions of the European Union, the Community of Portuguese-speaking countries, the African Union, but perhaps not the Commonwealth of West African States, are going in the right direction.
But resolutions are not enough, action is needed.
We must be more firm, we must be more effective, together with the states that have the capacity to intervene in Guinea-Bissau.
That is our obligation.

I believe that the European Union is responding well in terms of principles at the moment, but it is not responding as it should in terms of the practical instruments of the field operation, and that is what I am asking the Council and the Commission to do.

Mr President, Mr Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, globalisation has brought about a disproportionate growth in the financial sector, whose transactions are today, as we know, 70 times higher than global wealth.
Opacity, frequent transactions, high remuneration, and high risk have not only characterized the world we live in today, but have also been fundamental reasons for the crisis we are going through.
However, this crisis came to hold the ordinary citizens much more accountable and demanding more effort than the sector that had caused it.
So today and this moment is important.

It is important, and I would personally like to see, that the tax is widespread in all the countries of the European Union and subsequently extended to the rest of the world through the active participation of the Commission and the European Union in general in the context of the G20.
I would like it to be inclusive or to cover all products without exceptions.
I would like it to serve as a basis for the necessary strengthening of the European Union's own resources.
In the short term, we have to accept commitments, but we have to keep our minds on where we need to go.
This can only be achieved by a clear identification of these objectives by this Parliament, by the Commission and also by the Council in a spirit of great commitment.

This is what the citizens of Europe expect from us today, and I can only thank here today not only the role of Anne Paldimatta, who was tireless in this process, but also all those who managed to overcome the divergences to reach a common position.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are discussing here for the first time the financial transaction tax and its adoption is the first sign that speculation is not going to go unpunished in this crisis in which we live.
This House and the European institutions must be responsible for the people, not the financial markets.
For decades, financial market lobbies have managed to rule the world without opposition and without any problems.
It is obvious to us that during 2008 and 2012, the crisis of the speculative financial market was at the root of most of the problems we experienced.
And yet, these speculative financial markets have not only succeeded in doing nothing, but in making a direct transfer of citizens' pockets to these same speculative markets.

We have been fighting for this for many years, Mr President, but it was only when the peoples, a little across Europe, began to say enough is enough that there was finally some initiative on the part of the institutions governing the European Union.
And so this is the answer that we have to give to the citizens, it's a first signal that we have to give.
The citizens of Europe, who have everything paid for, do not deserve to be disrespected.
And so this proposal is not complete, it is not perfect, it will not solve the whole problem of financial speculation, but it is an important sign.
We have been, we have not been, European leaders have been apologizing to the financial markets.
They should apologize to the people who have been affected.
And, to conclude, Mr President, a famous politician today, we are talking about these markets, these markets that govern us without ever having been elected.

I sincerely hope that the governments will give people a sign of confidence and I sincerely hope that with this approval and the positive vote of the colleagues we will begin to talk about justice and solidarity in Europe.
Colleagues, get up your courage, we're going to make this project happen.
Mr President, the financial transaction tax should act as a way of controlling and disincentivising high-risk speculative activities in the financial sector.
It aims to reduce speculation and expand healthy competition, which is the basis of the single market, and also to generate revenue.
The Podimata report attempted to bring the European Commission's initial proposal closer to the well-known UK Stamp Tax, making it more attractive to reluctant Member States.
It is hoped that the Council will also understand the message.

If, in the Commission's proposal, the tax applied to transactions by financial institutions located in the territory of the European Union, it is now intended that transactions in European assets, even those carried out by non-Europeans, should also be taxed.
This measure will expand the revenue base and reduce leakage.
It is hoped that the tax revenues will be considered as a source of own resources for the Union or the Member States, reducing the taxes of the Member States, a matter yet to be decided.
I would like to conclude, Mr President, by congratulating the rapporteur on the quality of her work, and I hope that this symbolic text will be adopted.
Madam President, we had more than one request this weekend to save the private bank.

They continue to say the same argument, which is to avoid contagion in the euro area, and what I ask is whether we have learned nothing Greece, Portugal, Ireland and now Spain and yet the contagion continues.
But what ray of containment of contagion is this that is destroying us?

This policy doesn't work, we should have known by now, it's the same rulers who say there's no money for culture, education, health, public goods, that when the banks ask the markets, they make it appear almost by miracle.
This economic policy is not a cure, it is a deadly poison for growth, for employment, for the European economy, for social Europe.
The markets are in charge and the governments are obeying and blackmailing the people, and that's what the governments are doing to Greece right now, in the election period.

I sincerely hope that it is in the best interest of all of us that the Greek people do not allow themselves to be blackmailed next Sunday and that they give us a lesson, because this recipe, Madam President, is a recipe for disaster.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately the proposals we are discussing here today confirm the prohibition of anti-crisis policies in the euro area and further concretise the logic of the budgetary treaty.

There are some statements of intent, but they are very timid. I am referring, for example, to the memo to one day be able to start thinking about ways of defining a possible legislation for the hypothetical introduction of euro bonds.
The problem is that this day is only when all the problems of the euro area have been solved and it takes a long time to arrive.
We support some aspects of this proposal, but at this rate everything will be too little and too late.
Putting a country under legal protection implies maintaining taxes and amounts, as well as giving priority to new loans.
Member States that honour their debt, but withdraw all the instruments that can allow them to grow and find the resources to do so.

We will be frank with each other, the only legal protection that exists in these proposals and that is provided for is for the creators, but even these will not be resolved because it is not effective for them either.
As we have seen in Greece, Ireland, Portugal and now in Spain, this means condemning countries to recession, unemployment and insolvency.

In the face of the complete failure of austerity, the European Commission or the German Government are proposing the same policy, but under a de facto regime and neoliberal fanaticism that is killing the euro.
With the extremely limited time we have, I just want to say to the Commission at the moment that it can count on, as it has always counted on, this Parliament's support.

I would like to ask the President-in-Office of the Council whether he is aware of the fact that the Council of Ministers of the European Communities has adopted a resolution on the situation in the former Yugoslavia.

We have succeeded in adding the conditions for a balanced sharing of gains and sacrifices between the different Member States and between the different citizens, and a hope, a hope that we will emerge from the crisis we are going through.
For this hope to exist, other initiatives are needed, and these are the ones that this Parliament is trying to fill with an initiative aimed at investment, growth and control.
The sovereign debt that has been the calamity of those evident, which reflects the fragility of the economic systems of some of the Member States.
Commissioner, you can count on us, the Council and the President can count on us, but the agenda must be a comprehensive agenda, it cannot be an agenda that makes

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission's proposal for a directive on the protection of workers from the risks related to exposure to carcinogens and mutagens has been rejected by the Council.

Our citizens expect this from us, they can count on Parliament, and I want to thank again my colleagues, the rapporteurs, Mr Gozelski and the other rapporteur and all the colleagues who, as shadow rapporteurs or merely active elements in the construction of this project, have been able to contribute.

I hope that this will be a project of Parliament which is more balanced, more solid and which deserves the respect, the capacity for dialogue and the spirit of construction and commitment which has so far been shown.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent report.

Madam President, in addition to thanking all those who have contributed to this result, I would like to ask that the final vote be postponed so that we can negotiate immediately at the level of the trilogue.
The EU is faced today with three agendas: the growth agenda, the agenda on bank management and the agenda on sovereign debt management.
And dealing with the European Semester involves including these three dimensions.
On the question of growth, I think it is important at this point to emphasize that the Commission's recommendations cannot only affect the European Union.
They also have to impact on the countries that have surpluses, and if some have to crush their internal demand, others have to free it.

I also think that at the level of growth it is essential that the Commission controls the recommendations of the so-called troika, because when a country goes into recession it cannot continue to crush its public investment, to crush public spending as if nothing had happened.
The Troika must have its revenue reviewed and adjusted according to the results, and I want to tell you, Commissioner, that we have today approved here in the European Parliament the
Parliament is urgently in need of launching an instrument for growth and for anti-cyclical activity, of the order of 1% of GDP in the European Union for ten years.
A second dimension, which is fundamental, is the dimension of what is now called the banking union.

A third dimension is the dimension of sovereign debt, without which there is no stability in Europe, and I would also like to tell you that today we approved the TUC here, but we introduced the TUC beyond austerity.
Some of the other dimension that has been missing and that is the immediate establishment of a redemption fund using German terminology so that sovereign debt exceeding 60 can be managed jointly.

This is a legislative text and we look forward to the Commission's good support for this Parliament's initiative so that we can control the completely threatening spiral that is currently destroying the European Union.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, now that we are about to discuss a growth pact, it is essential not to forget the citizens and consumers, in the deepest sense, the human and social dimension of the European Union.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission's proposal for a directive on the protection of workers from the risks related to exposure to carcinogens at work is based on the principle of proportionality.

As important as a test of the internal market will be to make a test of the social impact of all the measures taken to make the single market a reality, a test, yes, a test that will allow us to measure the progress made for the benefit of the citizens of the European Union.
Since 2008, Europe has already lost more than 6 million jobs.
In my country, Portugal, the economy is suffering an unprecedented counteraction and unemployment among men, women and young people is reaching historic lows.
According to the Bank of Portugal, the situation will worsen in the next two years.
It is in this context that we support and welcome the initiative of the new employment package and congratulate Commissioner Andor.
By insisting now and always on the basic premise of the need for economic growth, Member States will really have to concentrate their efforts on job creation.

The means to do this should be through subsidies for recruitment that creates new jobs, by reducing the tax burden on work and support for the creation of new businesses and entrepreneurship, but also for small and medium-sized enterprises that maintain jobs.
National employment policies must take into account that the areas with the greatest potential for job creation are health, information and communication technologies and the green economy.
It is urgent, as stated in the communication, to reduce the gap between the qualifications provided by education and the skills demanded by the labour market.
On the other hand, one of the solutions to combat unemployment is through the mobility of workers.
It is also crucial that the structural funds be used to create jobs and that the EUROS portal be of practical importance as a tool, par excellence, for recruitment and job offers in Europe.
Finally, social governance must be on the agenda because our citizens are eagerly waiting for concrete results.
Madam President, Commissioner, it is true that six months have passed since this scandal with GDP and the most incredible thing is that for ten years a private company has been able to achieve this.
The company has been operating in the market and introduced silicon implants that should be used for the construction and manufacture of collections and were used on women in 71 countries.
This affected hundreds of women, as already mentioned, and it is estimated that about 500,000.

Now we are talking about estimates because there were failures and there were serious failures in this process.We know that what happened to this company is a criminal case, it is a fraud, it is a court case, but we also know that
There is a fraud here that must be controlled by the courts and the courts will deal with it, but there is a legal flaw, there is a legal vacuum and we must deal with it.

For ten years we have not been able to identify what the criminals were able to identify and therefore there was a vacuum in terms of control, in terms of traceability, in terms of archives, in terms of records, everything failed, but these gentlemen of this company were able to put into practice what we were unable to control and that is why

In this process, there is not only the issue of lack of information, which is very important in fact, the lack of information on all issues related to breast implants, but also the humiliation of thousands of women and the humiliation, in particular, of those women who had to undergo tests to know whether they had placed or not the right implants.

We are talking about a public health issue and we cannot be lax in public health matters, we control so much unnecessary, we even control the authenticity of car replacement parts and we have recently adopted a directive on this.

We have to control what is fundamental to people's lives. The revision of the Medical Devices Directive is good news, it was the best news we didn't have to do, but now that we're going to do it, we're going to apply it with

There are conditions, with traceability, transparency, control, sanctions, because unfortunately, even if the sanctions are applied, they will no longer be applied to the women who suffered from this problem, and the States must take full responsibility.

Mr President, I wanted to make it very clear here that it is essential for us that the Council, which will take place at the end of June, and that what is essential is that a European solution is sought to this crisis.
The problem, from our point of view, so far is that we have dealt with each of the issues that arise individually and individually.

It is time to have a global solution for Europe, a solution which, as President Dombrovskis has made clear here, is about more integration, more cooperation, closer European policies and the re-evaluation of the Community method.
It is essential that growth be at the side of stability, but that we do not abandon the concerns of stability.
We therefore count on a global European response, not a divided response for each State or for each region in difficulty.
Productivity and increased production possibilities have led to considerable increases in milk produced, creating critical situations of surpluses and low prices in the milk and dairy market.

In many regions with strong productive potential, these surpluses were put at balance sheet prices in the markets of other countries, creating even greater pressure to lower prices paid to producers in those countries.

This happened, for example, with French milk sold in France at twice the price that was sold in Galicia, and producers, with the sharp rise in the cost of raw materials and production factors, have now seen their resistance to low prices greatly reduced.

This is a bad omen for many farms and many productive territories in Europe and also seems to be a clear omen of what a future without quotas and without adequate supply regulatory instruments may look like.

There is therefore a need for a thorough audit of the territorial impacts on thousands of people across the European Union of the abolition of these instruments which we have today to regulate supply.
Mr President, I should like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on this report.
This is a matter of extreme importance for Europe.
At a time when we are experiencing a serious economic, financial and social crisis, protecting intellectual property rights by combating counterfeit products is fundamental to the European economy.
This protection should strengthen the performance of research and promote innovation, ensure scientific and technological knowledge, and contribute to the development of new products and services.
All this in the sense of generating growth and creating quality jobs.

Unfortunately, in recent years we have seen a significant increase in the violation of intellectual property rights in Europe, which represents annual losses, as has already been mentioned, of EUR 250 million for companies and the destruction of 185 jobs in the European space.

But in addition to these negative effects on the European economy, the violation of these rights also poses a serious threat to the health and safety of European consumers, as many counterfeit products, such as food, cosmetics, medicines, etc., are being sold.
etc., are produced in non-regulated environments.
The customs authorities of the European Union therefore play a crucial role in preventing the entry of counterfeit products into the internal market.
The revision of this Regulation aims to strengthen control of the application of the legislation in question, to strengthen the legitimacy of its intervention and to increase the
legal clarity, adapting the provisions of the Regulation to new realities and developments, thus contributing to better protection of the European economy and consumers.
Intellectual property rights are thus a crucial priority in achieving the objectives of the 2020 strategy in terms of achieving smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

Mr President, in fact, the election of a new Egyptian president, namely, Mubarak, is good news, but we cannot be fooled, and these presidential elections do not in any way close what is the transition process that is taking place in Egypt.

It was well mentioned that the dissolution of Parliament, days before the presidential elections, puts several risks on the table, and in this case, the power that is concentrated in the upper council of the

The armed forces are an exaggerated minimum, they have legislative power, they have reduced the power of the president, and, in addition, they still have in their hands the definition of the changes in the Constitution.

Now, all this raises some concerns and should raise some concerns, because the Egyptians run the risk of being held hostage to military power and the return to the past, with the lack of a fundamental element, which is the democratically elected parliament.
It is not for us to change in Egypt, it is for the Egyptians.
But I think that we Europeans will have to stand by all the changes that propose the repositioning of what is democratic legitimacy and a democratically elected Parliament.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating my colleague, the rapporteur, Mrs Lara Comi, on the excellent work done in this report, which is of vital importance for the future of Europe.
In a world and in a society in rapid transformation, Europe needs a comprehensive, integrative, effective and up-to-date standardisation system.
A system that ensures the proper functioning of the internal market, that improves the protection of consumers and their lives, but also that protects the environment, is essential.

It is also very important to have more innovation and social inclusion and the interaction and communication of networks and systems, especially in the domain of new information and communication technologies, as has already been outlined here.
As Professor Monti said in his report A New Strategy for the Single Market, European normalisation is essential for the governance of the internal market, highlighted in the report.

There is a need for a review of the European standardisation process, which maintains the advantages of the current system and which strikes a fair balance between the European and national dimensions.

In this respect, the report we are discussing now follows and defends these objectives, which are the right ones and adequate, to put an end to the slowness and fragmentation that exist and which cause companies to incur costs.
The Commission is also proposing to strengthen the participation of SMEs in standardisation activities, in particular at national level, and to facilitate their access to these standards.

On the other hand, the participation of the parties representing the interests of society, such as consumers, environmentalists, workers and people with disabilities, while maintaining financial support for the European organisations set up to represent public interests.
I conclude by saying that the adoption of this report will contribute to the relaunch of the European project, to European innovation, to the strengthening and competitiveness of our companies.
Mr President, Commissioner, the future common fisheries policy must give priority to its environmental, economic and social sectors.
synergistic and non-hierarchical way, in favour of sustainable development and in line with the objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth of the EU 2020 strategy.
As rapporteur for the third regime, I would like to highlight the particularity of some regions, such as the outermost regions, whose economies are strongly dependent on the

In these regions, the reform of the common fisheries policy must seek to ensure the survival and future prosperity of their small-scale and artisanal fishing fleets, thus safeguarding and defending the jobs they depend on.

I agree with the European Commission's position on the need for an adjustment of this policy and for specific measures to take account of the disparities in the fisheries and aquaculture sector in the various coastal regions.

I support the fact that this policy focuses on regionalisation as a form of governance, through a strengthening of the participation of the various stakeholders, so that a more adequate response to the needs and sensitivities of each maritime basin is possible in the future.
We are reaching the decisive moments when we are going to shape the new fisheries policy in Europe, and we cannot fail.

The need and urgency to achieve sustainable rebalancing in our fisheries resources, but also in the revitalization of our coastal fishing communities and in the promotion of their socioeconomic level, in the modernisation of the sector and in the supply of quality food, require, as never before, courage and courageous measures.
That's why we have to make choices and prioritize goals.

I proposed protection for the fragility of my region, proposing that the exploitation of its resources be done taking into account the scientific data and giving priority to our coastal communities in its exploitation and restricting external access beyond 100 miles to existing fishing banks.
I proposed to safeguard the fishing capacity of our important fishing communities by rejecting proposals for transferable quotas.

I proposed that our communities should have better intervention in the management of their fisheries issues by creating their own regional advisory council, more appropriate for the inter-peripheral regions.

Given what we know about the application of the third package and part of this issue has already been discussed today, as regards the transposition of its directives, the last information I have is that the Commission is not in a position to present any proposals.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that 18 Member States have been notified, and that this information has probably already been de-actualised for lack of transposition.
The European Union's trans-European networks, including a device, an incentive that conditions a conditionality for the presentation of projects of common interest or that is
The Commission considers that the third package is an extravagant mechanism and should be left to the regular competition mechanisms, Article 101.
I would like to thank the Commissioner for his reply, and I would also like to thank the Commissioner for his reply.
The question is whether, in the preparation of legislation, we can expect to see legislation that is able to protect the rights of the victims.

If you want to introduce an additional and much stronger conditionality, do you understand that this conditionality is an abusive instrument or do you think that this conditionality would be acceptable?
I confess that I share very much the concern that was initially expressed here, namely the democratic legitimacy and democratic control that are related to this proposal.
I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the European Parliament has not yet been consulted on this matter, and if so, what is the Commission's position?
But there is another concern which is also a fundamental concern and it has to do with the following: monetary policy instruments are controlled by the European Union.

Banking supervision also becomes the responsibility of the European Union, and yet, if everything goes wrong, if the banks go bankrupt, the responsibility for paying this bankruptcy remains with the taxpayers of the national states, it remains a national responsibility.

This is not a problem of minor importance, it is a problem of the bottom that is not solved and, finally, I just want to point out that it is also not solved that we continue to tie monetary policy to what is a secondary issue in the context in which we live, which is inflation, and not to job creation and growth as it should be.

Mr President, European leaders continue to insist on budgetary discipline, and I ask for budgetary discipline, so let's go to it, because what exactly are we talking about when we talk about budgetary discipline?
In my view, budgetary discipline is respecting contracts with pensioners and not abandoning the commitments of the State to the medium.
The budget is to respect commitments in health, education, culture and not to close services or close and cancel projects in the middle.
This is the budgetary discipline which I would like to see implemented in the European Union and we will not continue in this market party.

The budget that is being discussed in Portugal at the behest of the Troika is a perfect example, it violates all the commitments that any State must have with its citizens, so as not to violate the agreements made behind closed doors that are destroying Europe and its countries.

Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, first of all, I would naturally like to congratulate myself on the results of the Council, although it seems to me that the final decision is a little late.
The truth is, there's an advance
Now, precisely because I agree with everything my colleague, Mr. Caçulidas, has said, I would like to ask the President of the Council just one question: are the countries under assistance?
The countries that are in difficulty have struggled a lot to have a retroactive application of bank debts in their separation from the state debt.
This apparently wasn't the site.
But we heard yesterday statements from the highest German and French authorities saying that they would treat Ireland as a special situation.
What I am asking is whether the Council has approved any decision on discriminatory treatment for Ireland, unlike that which is reserved for countries such as Portugal, Greece, Spain and others.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it is a privilege to present the report on the 20 concerns of citizens and businesses in the European Union.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the European Parliament has not yet been consulted on the functioning of the single market, and that is precisely what is at stake in this debate with Commissioner Barnier, which marks the 20th anniversary of this market.

A first word of thanks to the colleagues from all the political groups, and in particular to the rapporteurs for opinion and the shadow rapporteurs, for their constructive contributions and their positive attitude.
It was a pleasure to work with all of you, and the report has benefited greatly from our joint efforts.

We are well aware and proud that over the past 20 years the single market has been the engine of great economic and labour opportunities in Europe, which have transformed the lives of European citizens and European companies.
Travelling, residing and working within the Union are freedoms that are available to all citizens of the 27 Member States.
For European consumers, the single market means more choice and lower prices.
For our companies, the single market means more business opportunities with access to 500 million consumers, which means more economic growth and more job creation.
To illustrate the progress that the single market has made in Europe since its creation in 1992 until the beginning of the crisis
In 2008, just look at the 2.7 million jobs that were created and the 2.13% of additional GDP growth.
Today, making a TOEFL or receiving a TOEFL when traveling in Europe is 13 percent cheaper than in 2005.
Freedom of movement for people is most eloquently expressed in the Erasmus programme.
More than 2.5 million students have benefited from this European Education and Mobility Exchange Programme.
In the last five years, companies have also benefited from a 25 cut in administrative charges due to single market legislation.
But one question arises: is everything going well in the single market?
No, not everything works well.
The economic and financial crisis that affects us has had negative repercussions on the functioning of this market.
Our citizens, in some countries, living with the drama of unemployment and facing austerity measures, have become sceptical about Europe and negative about the internal market.
People do not yet know or understand their rights sufficiently, nor do they know where to find information or help.
On the other hand, many Member States are unjustifiably delaying the transposition of European directives and legislation on the single market, thus undermining its full potential.
In certain areas of everyday life, such as the reimbursement of medical expenses after a temporary stay in another EU country, the opening of a bank account for a student of the programme

Erasmus, the change of energy supplier, the transfer of reform pensions, the recognition of qualifications and the registration of a vehicle in another Member State are still very complex, difficult or burdensome acts.
It is important to answer these problems.
That was my concern as rapporteur.
That is why the message written in the report is very clear: more political will is needed, much more political will from the Member States and the European institutions.
The Council, and above all the Council and the Commission, must regain the confidence of people and businesses and facilitate the exercise of their rights in order to govern better and together.

Finally, I would like to congratulate the European Commission, in the person of Commissioner Barnier, on the presentation of the second market act, 12 priority actions for new growth, which marks, I am sure, a new stage for the future.
Madam President, Commissioner Barnier and my dear colleague Regina Bastos, congratulations on your already successful efforts.
When Jacques Delors was President of the European Commission, the single market of the Union was created in 1992.
Delors then synthesised the three basic principles of the single market: competition that stimulates, cooperation that strengthens and solidarity that unites.
Twenty years ago, the economic and financial crisis raised the threat of national protectionism and it became clear that the internal market is not a finished work.

The celebration of these 20 years must be used for the relaunch of the single market, with the concern to put the market at the service of the citizen and not the citizen at the service of the market.
To do that, we need to define priorities, and I'd like to talk about a particular priority.
A common policy is essential to produce and distribute energy at prices accessible to the consumer, with a high level of energy efficiency.
through a European energy market, served by cross-border infrastructures, with the possibility of Community leverage of investment representing European added value.
In the energy sector too, Madam President, the common market will be at stake.
The greatest achievements of the European Union are certainly one of the strongest pillars of the development of the Union, its Member States and its regions.

However, in order for it to be effective and fair, it is necessary to emphasise its policies in the sense of equal opportunities for citizens and all regions, promoting the internal cohesion of the Union.

In this context, it is essential to recognise that we can only achieve greater development in our more remote regions, such as the outermost regions, through their greater inclusion in the single market.

Regions like the United States need to continue to increase their competitiveness by improving their conditions of competition, but we will never be able to do so unless we better solve our accessibility problems in the transport sector.
We can achieve this through specific instruments that best respond to the problems caused by our distance.
We therefore understand that the Commission should consider a specific programme such as POSEI transport as an essential instrument for the inclusion of such regions in the internal market.
Madam President, I would like to begin by saying thank you very much for this excellent debate.
It was a very constructive debate and it was a debate which demonstrated that the single market is really a great achievement of the European project.

I welcome the presence of Minister Mavroyiannis and his participation in this debate, and I thank all my colleagues for their constructive attitude, some for a sceptical attitude which is understandable.
I would like to thank Commissioner Barnier very much for his commitment and enthusiasm in discussing these issues, these problems of the internal market, and for the political will to solve them.
We still have a lot to answer to the citizens.
The citizens are dissatisfied, they are disillusioned and they expect more from us, they expect more from the Council, they expect more from the Commission, they expect more from the Member States.
This balance sheet is very useful, this 20-year balance sheet is important, but, as many have said here, it is important to open the door to a look to the future.
And the look to the future is through the many issues that have been raised here and through the many measures that have already been announced by the European Commission.
The digital single market, the mobility of citizens, the reform of the EURES portal, the European energy market are examples.
We have an important path to take in the future and that path is very important and vital to respond to this time of crisis that we are experiencing.
Citizens are suffering, citizens are expecting a lot from politicians and from the responses that politicians can give to the adverse conditions that they are suffering.
It is therefore important that the single market is one of the responses to the great challenge of competitiveness, employment and economic growth.
I am sure that all of us, after this 20th anniversary celebration, are more eager to give the answers that our citizens need.

Mr President, the Gozets report, together with the report we are going to draw up on the Union's annual growth prospects at the end of this year and ahead of the Spring Council, are two essential parts of the so-called European Semester.
This report addresses the recommendations made to each of the Member States by the Council on the Commission's proposal and these recommendations, as has just been said, are in line with the
The six pack and the future two pack, an extraordinarily strong body that strengthens European control over the economic and budgetary policy of the Member States.

The balance and this control and autonomy and legitimacy at national level is not easy to find and it has fallen to a level of imposition, especially of discipline, and in the last resort can even lead to a serious package of sanctions.

With regard to the two-pack, I would like to comment briefly on the importance of the Council, which is absent here today, giving its negotiators a negotiating mandate compatible with the ambition to finish this package quickly, this two-pack.

But more European coordination, going back to the subject, means less control by the countries over their own destiny, which requires a subtle balance but also an increased demand for the quality of the recommendations made to the countries in at least three or four dimensions.

Firstly, it is important to ensure coherence between the medium- and long-term objectives, which include growth, employment and real convergence, and the short-term recommendations, which focus mainly on discipline and nominal convergence.

with the conclusions to be drawn from the analysis of macroeconomic imbalances, in particular on the asymmetrical impact of common policies and the negative externalities of some national policies on other countries.
Thirdly, we need to agree that there is a minimum threshold for social, economic and labour rights which cannot be exceeded by these recommendations.

I would just like to thank Mr Gozez for his spirit of cooperation and hope that he will take another step in this spirit in order to broaden the consensus around his report and that this spirit will also remain with regard to the next report.
It is true, and it has been mentioned many times, that there are many things we don't know about shale gas extraction.
But there are also many that we already know and should not forget.
We know, for example, that each shale gas extraction operation uses more than 19 million litres of drinking water, which can supply a thousand European citizens in a year in terms of their needs.

We also know that each shale gas extraction that is done in each of the operations is sent to the sun 300 tons of shale can go up to 300 tons of chemicals and about 80 of which remain in the sun and do not come out of there.

We also know that, in each X-ray extraction, radioactive elements and heavy metals are released into the subsoil, which, together with the evaporation of the toxic waste resulting from the process, constitute an effective threat to public health.
This is a danger of contamination of drinking water resources and it is a continuous contamination that is real and that is imminent.

Knowing this, we know that shale gas extraction is also a seemingly easy answer, that it only thinks about the immediate, the industry and profit, and ignores the populations, the future and the environment.

But this is also Europe, which knows in this House that water is an essential, vital and important resource, which knows how to protect the health of its citizens and must protect it, which seeks to make agreements to avoid emissions and to propose energy efficiency, because we know that environmental standards are important, environmental standards and health standards.
So when you don't know everything, being inside is the least of it.
And you may even want to do it, but don't do it on our behalf, or on behalf of the citizens who are here to represent us.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the last few years have shown us how the Economic and Monetary Union has not resisted the crisis.
