We also showed that we had a European institutional architecture full of holes, in particular the institutional architecture of the euro.
And that is why the report presented here and the proposal presented here are so far above in terms of the vision in relation to what is the proposal presented by the governments.
But also, as the rapporteur said, we are in a position to make political choices, and that is why I would like to clarify the reasons why we have some problems and cannot support this report.
The first concerns issues related to conditionality.

We see and continue to have a narrative in which there can only be solidarity between the different countries when everything has been fulfilled in terms of the Stability and Growth Plan, in terms of the intergovernmental agreement, the Pact for

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he is aware of the fact that the Commission has already taken a number of measures to ensure that the European Parliament's budget is not used for the purpose of taxation.
A second reason has to do with the banking union.

The rapporteur is very good at presenting the banking supervision mechanism, but it is so necessary that we cannot run away from the essential and the essential here is running away as we continue to add the

We have a cluster of national systems, which means that we are all together in banking policy, we are all together in banking supervision, but we are all separated when something goes wrong and therefore the contributors will continue to pay.
And a third note has to do with the question of the common debt and the issuance of Eurobonds.
Here, once again, the possibility of a common water supply is considered, but only when it is too late.

Because we need the common debt, and now it is not only when the excessive debt deficits have been corrected, because with these policies that we are pursuing they will never be corrected, on the contrary, they will be increasingly aggravated to the despair of an entire population.

That is why I want to end, Mr President, by saying that, despite all the efforts, I think we have here a very clear example that together we could still rise, but divided we will surely fall, and that is why it was important to have gone even further.
Madam President, there are always room for progress, but for Portugal the support of the European Union in recent years has been fundamental.
Portugal has transformed from a country based on cheap labour, to a highly skilled, highly sophisticated country.
But when the country exports, you have to have conditions for where.

And that is why it is important that some countries that have surpluses open their doors to the re-qualified exports of countries that started from a specialization profile that was absolutely unsustainable.

A final note to say that it is not possible for immigration to be the solution, that the retrained workforce and where European Union support has been used is now lost through a massive export of the most qualified to the countries that have room to accommodate them.
This is dramatic and completely undermines our future.

Mr President, small-scale fishing should deserve special protection from the common fisheries policy, not only because it promotes socioeconomic cohesion and ensures the livelihood of many families, but also because it is a factor in the fixation of these communities along the coastal areas.
Their economic and social sustainability must be a goal, ensuring a differentiated fishing regime that gives priority to access to resources.
It allows for the management of proximity and protects the fishing rights enjoyed by fishing professionals in these communities against transferable fishing rights.
It is equally important for its sustainability to take into account the water access regime, especially in waters or regions with biogeographical basins.
The marine, with a reduced continental platform, and the scarce resources concentrated in underwater mountains and fishing banks that must have protected access.
In a context of liberalisation and crisis weighing on fragile regions, it must also be ensured that products from international trade meet the same requirements as products imported by the Union.
Mr President, Mr President of the Council of Exercise, Mr Commissioner, I shall be very brief, because I believe that what is at stake here is essentially a political point, not a political point.
The question that arises is whether we want the European Union to make a difference in the context of the crisis or whether we want to worsen the crisis.

Most European countries are now making an enormous effort, from the point of view of their public finances, to overcome the crisis in a competitive way, in a way that can put their countries in a position to do so.
The European Union is globally highly competitive, but it is obvious that without investment there can be no growth and this crisis cannot be overcome.
If the European Union insists on these radical cuts, particularly in cohesion policy and the common agricultural policy, what this will mean is that the countries that are doing a huge
They will not be able to grow and this plan, which we have accepted in all the countries of the European Union, will fail.

The only and great instrument for this is this multiannual financial framework, and that is why, if we want the European Union to succeed and if we want its policy to be an exemplary policy for other countries, we have to invest in the budget for the financial perspectives.
